('56', 0, 1, 2, 43) 1. LETTER TO PARASRAM MEHROTRA
('56', 0, 2, 3, 74) [Before June 16, 1932] 1
('56', 0, 3, 4, 99) PARASRAM, Judging from your letter the children seem to have made good progress.
('56', 0, 3, 5, 180) You speed with the takli is also good.
('56', 0, 3, 6, 219) Do give half an hour daily to it; if you can in what time spin 160 rounds, nothing can be better than that.
('56', 0, 3, 7, 327) What does kule ki haddi 2 mean?
('56', 0, 3, 8, 359) The word Kula is not to be found in the Hindi Dictionary.
('56', 0, 3, 9, 417) Why did the haddi get swollen?
('56', 0, 3, 10, 448) Has the swelling subsided now?
('56', 0, 3, 11, 479) If it has not, you must take immediate steps to cure it.
('56', 0, 3, 12, 536) The replies to the questions which you have put to Mahadev are: 1. I consider a minimum of half an hour’s walk morning and evening essential for you and others.
('56', 0, 3, 13, 697) It is not necessary to sit in one position for more than an hour.
('56', 0, 3, 14, 763) One should stand up for a minute at least, or change the posture.
('56', 0, 3, 15, 829) 2. It is natural that a mother should desire to see her son, but every mother ought to restrain such a with and, if the son is engaged in some activity of service, he must cure his mother of such attachment.
('56', 0, 3, 16, 1037) 3. When a son goes abroad and lives in a foreign country for ten years, his mother has no choice but to bear the separation.
('56', 0, 3, 17, 1162) There are innumerable poor mothers in India who possibly never again see the face of their son after he has gone out to earn a living.
('56', 0, 3, 18, 1297) One may console the mother through a letter, and cheer her as much as one can by reasoning with her and citing other similar instances.
('56', 0, 3, 19, 1433) 4. At the moment my heart has become as hard as stone so that the incidents in Bombay may have affected me, if at all, only unconsciously, and I am not aware that they have.
('56', 0, 3, 20, 1607) I felt sad for a while but I think I have quietened down after that.

('56', 1, 6, 16, 2629) MIRA, Your letter 4 came in only today.

('56', 1, 6, 22, 2934) I have no doubt you will make sure that Shantabai is not embarrassed in any way by harbouring you.
('56', 1, 6, 23, 3033) Yes, I have been saltless since Sunday.
('56', 1, 6, 24, 3073) As the doctors removed the splints and found that there was no relief from their use, I immediately thought of you and knew that you would be more at ease if I gave up salt.
('56', 1, 6, 25, 3247) It was no deprivation to me and so I stopped it at once.
('56', 1, 6, 26, 3304) It meant giving up the loaf and going to chapati.
('56', 1, 6, 27, 3354) Whether it was the chapati or the absence of salt, the bowels became looser than I would care.
('56', 1, 6, 28, 3449) Therefore from yesterday I have been on grapes,

('56', 2, 1, 7, 4122) The condition of saltless ought not to mean reversion to milk.

('56', 2, 1, 28, 5679) It is grand even regarded as a preparation for a better life than the past, as it should be for everyone who this to live in the fear of God.

('56', 3, 4, 6, 6467) 5. LETTER TO PARASRAM MEHROTRA
('56', 3, 5, 7, 6498) June 16, 1932
('56', 3, 6, 8, 6512) PARASRAM, I have not yet received your booklet.
('56', 3, 6, 9, 6560) Mahadev will go through the Press cutting.
('56', 3, 6, 10, 6603) Do something about the swelling 1 and cure it.
('56', 3, 6, 11, 6650) You did quite right in not running up to Vimal’s 2 elder brother, but you yourself should feel so.
('56', 3, 6, 12, 6749) The knowledge that he is under the care of your brother and that the latter is looking after him properly should be enough for you.
('56', 3, 6, 13, 6881) If you have some special remedy for his illness or if you think that your very presence will cure him, then it may be your duty to go.
('56', 3, 6, 14, 7016) That is, if you can become free from your work you should go in such circumstances.
('56', 3, 6, 15, 7100) You should go, however, not only for the sake of Vimal’s brother but for any person who may be ill and whose illness is likely to be cured by your presence.
('56', 3, 6, 16, 7257) It is only thus that one learns to overcome the weakness of one’s heart.
('56', 3, 6, 17, 7330) Let us hope that the child is all right now.
('56', 3, 6, 18, 7375) I think that it would be desirable to fix the maximum number of hours for work, it that is possible.
('56', 3, 6, 19, 7476) But it seems to me that the limit would be different for each person.
('56', 3, 6, 20, 7546) In an institution in which all the members regard one another as members of a family and everybody has the same sense of responsibility, it would not only be impossible, but may even be improper to fix a uniform limit for all.
('56', 3, 6, 21, 7773) How can weframe a rule which would not permit a person, whose health is good enough, who is himself willing and who has no other work of service to claim his time, to give all his time to the service of the institution?
('56', 3, 6, 22, 7993) The conclusion which I draw from this is that, if we exercise discretion
('56', 3, 7, 23, 8066) 1 Vide “Letter to Parasram Mehrotra”, 16 6 1932.

('56', 4, 1, 2, 8176) in all our work, do it calmly and selflessly and without hurry, no one would feel the burden of work.
('56', 4, 1, 3, 8278) We feel work to be a burden only when we do it under compulsion.
('56', 4, 1, 4, 8343) Work done willingly and cheerfully is never felt as a burden.
('56', 4, 1, 5, 8405) But those who have a demoniac nature are impelled by their selfishness to take all manner of work from their body and then break down.
('56', 4, 1, 6, 8540) Such persons have no peace of mind and we should never take them as examples.
('56', 4, 1, 7, 8618) The line about women which you have quoted has no other sense but what I have explained.

('56', 5, 1, 2, 10173) 7. LETTER TO DEVDAS GANDHI
('56', 5, 2, 3, 10200) June 16, 1932
('56', 5, 3, 4, 10214) DEVDAS, I did fear some such thing.
('56', 5, 3, 5, 10250) I had a feeling the day before yesterday that there would be bad news from somewhere.
('56', 5, 3, 6, 10336) And then I got your wire yesterday.
('56', 5, 3, 7, 10372) I immediately asked Vallabhbhai what the wire contained, and on opening it he read the news about your illness.
('56', 5, 3, 8, 10484) It was not likely that you would escape fever in Gorakhpur.
('56', 5, 3, 9, 10544) But I assume that it will have left you before you get this letter.
('56', 5, 3, 10, 10612) I think that, according to your nature, you would like to be surrounded by friends and relations at such a time.
('56', 5, 3, 11, 10725) You would deserve such care becuase you have looked after many people in their illness.
('56', 5, 3, 12, 10813) But I myself am a hard hearted man.
('56', 5, 3, 13, 10849) I, therefore, would not like to ask anybody from the western part to run up to Gorakhpur.
('56', 5, 3, 14, 10939) And if I did feel such a wish, I would suppress it.
('56', 5, 3, 15, 10991) If I don’t practise my philosophy on you, on whom else should I?
('56', 5, 3, 16, 11056) I wish that you should understand this nature of mine and bear it cheerfully.
('56', 5, 3, 17, 11134) God is your relations and your friends and your parents; all others are so only in name.
('56', 5, 3, 18, 11223) Themselves helpless creatures, how can they help you?
('56', 5, 3, 19, 11277) Instead of lookiing to such cyphers for protection and support, seek the protection of the Universal Power.
('56', 5, 3, 20, 11385) He will send you such help as He wills.
('56', 5, 3, 21, 11425) It is my firm faith that, wherever you are, you will draw your neighbours towards you.
('56', 5, 3, 22, 11512) There is no reason to believe that it will be otherwise in jail.
('56', 5, 3, 23, 11577) After saying this, I suggest that, if you want anybody from the Ashram to be near you, send a wire there.
('56', 5, 3, 24, 11683) But my hope is that by the time you get this letter your illness will have been a thing of the past.
('56', 5, 3, 25, 11784) You always have the blessing of us all.
('56', 5, 4, 26, 11824) [From Gujarati]
('56', 5, 5, 27, 11840) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, p.
('56', 5, 6, 28, 11872) 1 Gandhiji, however, was persuaded by Vallabhbhai Patel to request the U.P. Governor for the addressee’s transfer to a jail having less inclement climate.

('56', 6, 2, 3, 12134) June 16, 1932 The story about the snake is correct only to a certain extent.
('56', 6, 2, 4, 12211) The snake was passing over my body.
('56', 6, 2, 5, 12247) At such a moment what could I or anyone else do except to remain still?
('56', 6, 2, 6, 12319) I don’t see that this deserves any such praise as the writer has given me.
('56', 6, 2, 7, 12394) And how do we know if the snake was poisonous or not?
('56', 6, 2, 8, 12448) Having held for years that death is not a frightening event I am not affected for long by the death of anyone.

('56', 7, 3, 4, 13338) PREMA, What else am I to believe but that you are a fool?
('56', 7, 3, 5, 13396) If children have no interest in asking questions and still write, they waste their time.
('56', 7, 3, 6, 13485) If they write with interest, though merely as a formality, there is some meaning in that.
('56', 7, 3, 7, 13575) Children may not expect letters from parents, but are bound to be glad when they get one.
('56', 7, 3, 8, 13665) There will be no trace of selfishness in this.
('56', 7, 3, 9, 13712) In any case, you cannot see in this evidence of hysteria.
('56', 7, 3, 10, 13770) I have explained to you in one of my letters what your hysteria is.
('56', 7, 4, 11, 13838) I have not opposed contemplation of a personal form at the time of prayers, but have given a higher place to the formless.
('56', 7, 4, 12, 13961) Perhaps it is not right to make such a distinction.
('56', 7, 4, 13, 14013) What suits one person will not suit another.
('56', 7, 4, 14, 14058) Comparison is out of place in this matter.
('56', 7, 4, 15, 14101) For me worship of the formless has greater appeal.
('56', 7, 4, 16, 14152) Your explanation regarding Sankara and Ramanuja does not seem correct.
('56', 7, 4, 17, 14223) 2 Personal experience is more important than the influence of external circums tances.
('56', 7, 4, 18, 14310) The latter should have no effect on a votary of truth.
('56', 7, 4, 19, 14365) He ought to see beyond them.
('56', 7, 4, 20, 14394) We often see that opinions formed on the basis of external circumstances are afterwards discovered to be wrong.
('56', 7, 4, 21, 14506) The connection between the atman 3 and the body is a well known instance of this.
('56', 7, 4, 22, 14588) Because the atman is intimately connected with the body in this life, we cannot easily think of it as distinct from the body.
('56', 7, 4, 23, 14714) No one has equalled the power of vision of the person who saw beyond this outward fact and first uttered: “Not this”.
('56', 7, 4, 24, 14832) You will be able to think
('56', 7, 5, 25, 14858) 1 Vide “Letter to Premabehn Kantak”, 3 8 1932 and “Letter to Premabehn Kantak”, 18 8 1932. 2 According to Mahadevbhaini Diary, the addressee had argued that our attitude towards God had changed with the change in social and political conditions.
('56', 7, 5, 26, 15104) Sankara lived in an age of freedom when people talked of equality with God; Ramanuja lived in an age of slavery when people talked of being the slaves of the slaves of God.
('56', 7, 5, 27, 15277) In the book Bapuna Patro 5: Ku.
('56', 7, 5, 28, 15309) Premabehn Kantakne, pp.
('56', 7, 5, 29, 15333) 99 101, however, the addressee, presumably relying on her memory, says that she had argued that both Sankara and Ramanuja could attain greater heights of spirituality because they lived in an age of freedom where as the later saints, being born in slavery, worshipped personal gods and not the abstract Brahman.
('56', 8, 0, 1, 15645) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4 SEPTEMBER, 193 9
('56', 8, 1, 2, 15688) of any number of such instances.
('56', 8, 1, 3, 15721) It is not at all proper to take literally the utterances of Tukaram and other saints.
('56', 8, 1, 4, 15807) Recently I read one such utterance of Tukaram.
('56', 8, 1, 5, 15854) I quote it for your benefit.
('56', 8, 2, 6, 15883) An image of Lord Pashupati is made out of clay: what, then, would clay called?
('56', 8, 3, 7, 15962) The worship of the Lord reaches unto Him, the clay remains clay.
('56', 8, 4, 8, 16027) An image of Vishnu is carved out of stone, yet the stone does not become Vishnu.
('56', 8, 5, 9, 16108) The devotion is offered to Vishnu, the stone remains a stone.
('56', 8, 5, 10, 16170) From this, I draw the lesson that we should pay attention only to the idea behind the words of such saints.
('56', 8, 5, 11, 16278) They may describe personal God and yet worship the formless.
('56', 8, 5, 12, 16339) We ordinary human beings cannot do that and, therefore, we would come to grief if we do not try to understand their real meaning and guide ourselves by it.

('56', 8, 5, 26, 17406) At the same time you should massage the back with your palm.
('56', 8, 5, 27, 17467) If you do this, your pain will be cured and there will also be a beneficial effect on menstruation.

('56', 8, 5, 31, 17744) It is much too heavy.
('56', 8, 5, 32, 17766) You can easily make a few cuts in it.

('56', 8, 5, 34, 17871) That comes to five hours and ten minutes.
('56', 8, 5, 35, 17913) If you reduce this period by one hour, you will get the free time which you need.
('56', 8, 5, 36, 17995) You may retire into privacy and
('56', 9, 0, 1, 18027) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('56', 9, 1, 2, 18068) have a nap or simply lie down for one hour, or do some work which makes you feel that you are resting.
('56', 9, 1, 3, 18171) You should not, however, spend the time in talking or in any serious work.
('56', 9, 1, 4, 18246) If you do not wish to utilize the free hour just then, you may advance the time of those items of the programme for which it is convenient to do so and get an hour in the evening.
('56', 9, 1, 5, 18426) Anyone who feels completely absorbed in his or her work does not feel it a burden or a strain, but to one who feels no interest in his work even a small task seems heavy, as a day seems as long as a year to a prisoner.
('56', 9, 1, 6, 18645) To a person given to worldly enjoyments, a year seems as short as a day!
('56', 9, 1, 7, 18718) In the past, I used to get bored when listening to European music.
('56', 9, 1, 8, 18785) It is only now that I can understand and enjoy it a little.
('56', 9, 1, 9, 18845) You are not right when you say that “one should not hope to do any reading here.” It is quite true that you cannot do much reading.
('56', 9, 1, 10, 18977) It is equally true that reading is given less importance in the Ashram.
('56', 9, 1, 11, 19049) Even so, many prisons in the Ashram have been able to do some reading.
('56', 9, 1, 12, 19120) I do not like your expressions of despair.
('56', 9, 1, 13, 19163) Try to perfect what you find imperfect.
('56', 9, 1, 14, 19203) If, however, on the balance you feel that things are unsatisfactory, if, that is, after weighing the good points against the shortcomings, you feel that the latter exceed, you should leave the Ashram.
('56', 9, 1, 15, 19404) Justice to oneself and to society requires that.
('56', 9, 1, 16, 19453) You need not apologize for your long letters.
('56', 9, 1, 17, 19499) They don’t bore me; on the contrary, I like them.
('56', 9, 1, 18, 19549) I learn something from them, for each of them mirrors the state of your heart at the time of writing it.
('56', 9, 3, 19, 19654) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 10290. Also C.W. 6738. Courtesy: Premabehn Kantak

('56', 10, 1, 2, 20020) 12. A LETTER
('56', 10, 2, 3, 20033) June 17, 1932 You ought not to lose your self confidence.
('56', 10, 2, 4, 20091) One often gets impure thoughts.
('56', 10, 2, 5, 20123) But those who frequently clean out the dust that daily settles in their houses may be said to be clean and keeping their houses clean.
('56', 10, 2, 6, 20258) Similarly, those who drive out impure thoughts from their minds as soon as they come are sure to win in their struggle.
('56', 10, 2, 7, 20378) They should not be called hypocrites.
('56', 10, 2, 8, 20416) To save oneself from hypocrisy, I have already suggested a golden rule, which is that one should speak about one’s impure thoughts and never hide them.
('56', 10, 2, 9, 20568) Of course, you need not trumpt them in public.
('56', 10, 2, 10, 20615) But you should certainly tell some friend about them.
('56', 10, 2, 11, 20669) And, indeed, you should be mentally prepared not to mind even if the whole world knew about them.
('56', 10, 2, 12, 20767) Have faith in the words of Vinoba and do not yeild to despair.
('56', 10, 2, 13, 20830) [From Gujarati]

('56', 10, 4, 15, 20879) 13. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI 1
('56', 10, 5, 16, 20912) June 17, 1932 I, for one, daily realize this truth from experience, that Nature provides for the needs of every living creature from moment to moment, and I also see that, voluntarily or involuntarily, knowingly or unknowingly, we violate this great law every moment of our lives.
('56', 10, 5, 17, 21193) All of us can see that, in consequence of our doing so, on the one hand large numbers suffer through over indulgence and, on the other, countless people suffer through want.
('56', 10, 5, 18, 21367) Our endeavour, therefore is to save mankind from the calamity of widespread starvation on the one hand and, on the other, destruction of food grains by the American millionaires though a false understanding of economic laws.
('56', 10, 5, 19, 21592) It is true, of course, that it is impossible at present to live in perfect conformity with this natural law.
('56', 10, 5, 20, 21701) But that need not worry us.
('56', 10, 5, 21, 21729) [From Gujarati] Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, p.

('56', 11, 12, 19, 22634) 16. A LETTER 1
('56', 11, 13, 20, 22649) June 17, 1932 Nothing as regards the conduct of prisoners can be sent from here for publication.
('56', 11, 13, 21, 22746) As you say clarification on this point is desirable but that must await a suitable opportunity.
('56', 11, 13, 22, 22842) I appreciate your argument against fetters.
('56', 11, 13, 23, 22886) However I still think that the distinction between ordinary and political prisoners is invalid.
('56', 11, 13, 24, 22982) There is need for reform in
('56', 11, 14, 25, 23010) 1 The addressee had suggested satyagraha against politcal prisoners being taken out of jail for work, chained and fettered.
('56', 12, 0, 1, 23134) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4 SEPTEMBER, 193 13
('56', 12, 1, 2, 23178) the administration of prisons.
('56', 12, 1, 3, 23209) A prison should be a house of correction and not punishment.
('56', 12, 1, 4, 23270) If that is so, why should a forger have fetters on his legs in prison?
('56', 12, 1, 5, 23341) The fetters will not improve his character.
('56', 12, 1, 6, 23385) To my mind it is intolerable that anyone should be fettered if there is no likelihood of his trying to escape or becoming unmanageable or wishing to make a nuisance of himself.
('56', 12, 1, 7, 23562) But if a political prisoner is an athlete like you, always thinkinig out means of escape and unable to control his tongue and hands, it will be the duty of the authorities to put him in fetters.
('56', 12, 1, 8, 23757) In short what I mean is that the discrimination between political and other prisoners is not justified.
('56', 12, 1, 9, 23861) We reformers should not seek for any concessions which cannot be justified on ethical grounds and are not granted to all prisoners in the same category.
('56', 12, 1, 10, 24014) I should be unbale to stand an arrangement by which wheat is given to politicals and maize to ordinary prisoners.
('56', 12, 1, 11, 24128) Wheat bread must be issued to a prisoner who is unable to digest maize even if he is a murderer.
('56', 12, 1, 12, 24225) And a political prisoner who has splendid digestion must give up wheat and ask for maize, and thus protect his fellow prisoners.
('56', 12, 1, 13, 24354) But these are only my views upon which I must not insist from where I am.
('56', 12, 1, 14, 24428) Let each follow the dictates of his own conscience.
('56', 12, 1, 15, 24480) [From Gujarati]
('56', 12, 2, 16, 24496) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I ,pp.

('56', 17, 6, 8, 33157) DEAR BOYS AND GIRLS, God never does evil, for He is Truth.
('56', 17, 6, 9, 33216) Hence man himself is responsible for the evil that he does.
('56', 17, 6, 10, 33276) Whatever good we do is inspired by Him, and, therefore, it may be said that He does it.
('56', 17, 6, 11, 33364) As for the degree of proficiency in Sanskrit, you should know the language well enough to be able to understand the Gita.
('56', 17, 6, 12, 33486) This includes grammar.
('56', 17, 6, 13, 33509) If you find that the work has increased so much that you do not get even half an hour every day completely free, you should reduce the period of study.
('56', 17, 6, 14, 33661) Don’t think that you will learn less to that extent.
('56', 17, 6, 15, 33714) By taking half an hour’s rest, you will in crease your capacity for grasping to that extent and so on balance there will be nothing but gain.
('56', 17, 6, 16, 33856) Scientists have proved this by experiments.
('56', 17, 6, 17, 33900) Besides books on religion, there are plenty of books on other subjects in the Ashram which you can read.
('56', 17, 6, 18, 34005) Everybody may select from them and read the books which he likes.
('56', 17, 6, 19, 34071) The books are not only in Gujarati, but also in Urdu, Hindi, even in Sanskrit, and of course in English.

('56', 18, 6, 10, 34890) 25. LETTER TO BHAGWANJI P. PANDYA
('56', 18, 7, 11, 34924) June 18, 1932 You will be surprised, but I would advise you just now to stop reading even the works of Raychandbhai and the Gita.
('56', 18, 7, 12, 35054) 2 Reflect on whatever you understand from the Gita verses and the bhajans which are recited or sung during prayers.
('56', 18, 7, 13, 35170) This self restraint will be difficult to exercise, but you will see its miraculous effect.
('56', 18, 7, 14, 35261) At present, your reading has become your work.
('56', 18, 7, 15, 35308) Whenever you are free, take up some useful work to do.
('56', 18, 7, 16, 35363) Give up trying to understand things with your reason.
('56', 18, 7, 17, 35417) This is the meaning of “one step enough for me”.

('56', 20, 1, 2, 38573) If it were man’s duty to gratify his carnal passion, I would certainly understand the necessity of artificial means of birth control.
('56', 20, 2, 3, 38707) If, however, we regard gratification of passion without a desire for progeny as sin—and according to me it should be so regarded—it would be putting a premium on sin to prevent progeny by artificial means.
('56', 20, 2, 4, 38913) It is Nature’s eternal law that one shall reap as one sows.
('56', 20, 2, 5, 38973) If man idulges his carnal passion, let him bear the burden of progeny.
('56', 20, 2, 6, 39044) The question why the woman should bear it does not arise, since we regard her as completely free.
('56', 20, 2, 7, 39142) The adoption of artificial means of birth control in the West is already producing one result, namely, that the sanctity of marriage is disappearing and men and women gratify their lust without any restraint.
('56', 20, 2, 8, 39351) It is not many years since these means came into vogue, and yet the bond which had been held as sacred all this time is losing its strength.
('56', 20, 2, 9, 39492) Advanced thinkers in the West now look upon marriage as a superstition and see nothing evil even in a brother and a sister feeling passion for each other and gratifying it, but, on the contrary, regard it as completely normal.
('56', 20, 2, 10, 39719) I don’t look upon these views as the swinging of the pendulum to the other extreme.
('56', 20, 2, 11, 39803) I think that they are the direct and natural result of the same attitude of mind which lies at the back of artificial birth control.
('56', 20, 2, 12, 39936) It is possible that the bonds of marriage, etc., which we now regard as spiritually uplifting may actually be spiritually degrading.
('56', 20, 2, 13, 40069) But I simply cannot go beyond conceding such a possibility for the sake of argument.

('56', 20, 2, 15, 40235) These new ideas are raining from the fountain of false compassion and impatience and of the thinkers’ experiences limited to the hour of pleasure.

('56', 22, 1, 2, 43288) 27. LETTER TO SHARDA C. SHAH
('56', 22, 2, 3, 43317) June 18, 1932
('56', 22, 3, 4, 43331) SHARDA It is bad thing to commit a mistake.
('56', 22, 3, 5, 43375) That is why we should be ashamed of it.
('56', 22, 3, 6, 43415) But having committed it, it is a good thing to ask to be forgiven.
('56', 22, 3, 7, 43482) Hence what is there to be ashamed of in asking to be forgiven?
('56', 22, 3, 8, 43545) It implies a determination not to repeat the mistake.
('56', 22, 3, 9, 43599) Once this determination is there, why should one be ashamed?
('56', 22, 3, 10, 43660) Have you understood this?
('56', 22, 3, 11, 43686) Why should truth and non violence be compared?
('56', 22, 3, 12, 43733) But, if one must make the comparison, I would say that truth is superior even to non violence; for, falsehood too is violence.
('56', 22, 3, 13, 43860) And he who loves truth is bound to turn to non violence some day.

('56', 23, 1, 2, 44852) 29. PRAYER 1
('56', 23, 2, 3, 44865) June 19, 1932 Prayer is the very foundation of the Ashram.
('56', 23, 2, 4, 44924) We should, therefore, clearly understand what it means.
('56', 23, 2, 5, 44980) If it is not offered from the heart, it is no prayer at all.
('56', 23, 2, 6, 45041) We rarely see anybody dozing while eating.
('56', 23, 2, 7, 45084) Paryer is a million times more important than food.
('56', 23, 2, 8, 45136) If anybody dozes at prayer time, his condition must be pitiable indeed.
('56', 23, 2, 9, 45208) If we miss the prayer, we should feel deeply pained.
('56', 23, 2, 10, 45261) We should not mind if we miss a meal, but we should never miss a prayer.
('56', 23, 2, 11, 45334) Missing a meal is sometimes beneficial for health.
('56', 23, 2, 12, 45385) Omitting prayer never is.
('56', 23, 2, 13, 45411) If any person dozes at the time of prayer, feels lazy or talks with his neighbours while the prayer is going on, does not fix his attention on it and lets his thoughts wander, he has as good as absented himself from it.
('56', 23, 2, 14, 45631) His physical presence is mere show.
('56', 23, 2, 15, 45667) he is, therefore doubly guilty; he has absented himself from the prayer and has deceived the people.
('56', 23, 2, 16, 45768) To deceive means to act untruthfully, and, therefore, to violate the vow of truth.
('56', 23, 2, 17, 45851) If, however, anybody feels sleepy or bored against his will, what should he do?
('56', 23, 2, 18, 45931) But this can never happen.
('56', 23, 2, 19, 45958) If we run straight from the bed to the prayer meeting, we are bound to feel sleepy.
('56', 23, 2, 20, 46042) Before going to the meeting, we should rouse ourselves fully and brush our teeth, and resolve to remain awake and alert.
('56', 23, 2, 21, 46163) In the meeting we should not sit close to one another, should sit erect like a walking stick, breathe slowly and, if we can speak the words correctly, join in reciting the verses or singing the bhajans, silently to ourselves if not loudly.
('56', 23, 2, 22, 46403) If we can not do even this, we may go on repeating Ramanama.
('56', 23, 2, 23, 46464) If we still cannot control our body, we should keep standing.
('56', 23, 2, 24, 46526) No one, whether a grown up person or a child, should feel shame in doing so.
('56', 23, 2, 25, 46603) Grown up persons should occasionally keep standing, even if they do not feel sleepy, in order to create an atmosphere in which nobody would feel ashamed of standing.
('56', 23, 2, 26, 46769) Everyone should make an effort and understand as soon as possible the meaning of what is recited or sung for prayer.
('56', 23, 2, 27, 46886) Even if a person does not know Sanskrit, he should learn the meaning of each verse and meditate over it.

('56', 28, 4, 8, 56812) 32. LETTER TO JETHALAL G. SAMPAT 1
('56', 28, 5, 9, 56847) June 19, 1932 I consider yours to be a scientific experiment, and therefore I have been watching you all along and have desired to follow your work in full detail.
('56', 28, 5, 10, 57011) You are a seasoned worker and will encounter many more difficulties in the future.
('56', 28, 5, 11, 57094) This is the usual pattern of every great work: once in a while we feel that the line is now clear and we shall be able to make rapid progress.
('56', 28, 5, 12, 57237) We then relax a little, but all at once we notice a deep ditch in front of us.
('56', 28, 5, 13, 57316) Therefore you must settle there permanently.
('56', 28, 5, 14, 57361) The one thing needful is infinite patience with self confidence at the root of it.
('56', 28, 5, 15, 57444) Self confidence means an unflinching faith in one’s work.
('56', 28, 5, 16, 57502) Once this faith is acquired, there is no need to be anxious about the numerous errors we are unconsciously bound to commit from time to time.
('56', 28, 5, 17, 57644) We must not permit ourselves to be paralysed by the fear that we are perhaps on the wrong path.
('56', 28, 5, 18, 57740) I consider your experiment to be scientific, yet I think it is not perfectly scientific now; but your work shares in all the characteristics of a scientific experiment, and you have the patience needed in carrying it out.
('56', 28, 5, 19, 57962) I had noticed one defect in you before, but I think you have remedied it intelligently.
('56', 28, 5, 20, 58050) Or perhaps your devotion to truth has helped you to remedy it without being conscious of it.
('56', 28, 5, 21, 58143) That defect was this: you were satisfied with incomplete data and drew hasty conclusions from them.
('56', 28, 5, 22, 58243) But this is no longer the case.
('56', 28, 5, 23, 58275) A scientific experimenter has profound confidence in himself and is therefore never down hearted.
('56', 28, 5, 24, 58373) At the same time he is so humble that he is never satisfied with his own work, and is not guilty of drawing hasty conclusions.
('56', 28, 5, 25, 58500) On the other hand he measures his progress off and on and declares emphatically that the result of ‘x’ can be ‘y’ only.
('56', 28, 5, 26, 58620) Our workers are
('56', 28, 6, 27, 58636) 1 The addressee had sent a report of his work among the poor of Anantapur, a village in Madhya Pradesh where he had been engaged in constructive work for the last three years.
('56', 29, 0, 1, 58812) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('56', 29, 1, 2, 58853) generally lacking in this humility of the real man of science.
('56', 29, 1, 3, 58916) I was therefore not surprised when I found that you were not an exception to this rule.
('56', 29, 1, 4, 59004) But I do belive that you have the power of persevering till the end.
('56', 29, 1, 5, 59073) Ardently wishing that you may not suffer even from this little limitation, I gently drew your attention to it many years ago.

('56', 29, 1, 21, 60528) I cannot picture your work accurately from this distance.

('56', 34, 1, 2, 67384) 42. LETTER TO HANUMANPRASAD PODDAR
('56', 34, 2, 3, 67419) June 21, 1932 In answering question on spiritual matters it is an advantage to keep in mind the particular inquirer 1. To write for newspapers is a difficult task for me.
('56', 34, 2, 4, 67590) My mind has turned almost blank upon learning that you have asked the questions with a view to publish them in Kalyan.
('56', 34, 2, 5, 67709) It does not mean that the public gains nothing from what I write for the papers.
('56', 34, 2, 6, 67790) I am simply explaining my own point of view.
('56', 34, 2, 7, 67835) That is why I have reiterated many a time in Young India that it was not a journal for me but a weekly letter meant for friends.
('56', 34, 2, 8, 67964) And the spiritual matters discussed in Young India and Navajivan have been almost invariably written with a certain individual in view.
('56', 34, 2, 9, 68100) It has areason behind it.
('56', 34, 2, 10, 68126) I am not well versed in the Shastras.
('56', 34, 2, 11, 68164) Although I make use of reasoning often enough the mainspring of my talks and writings is not the intellect but the heart.
('56', 34, 2, 12, 68286) And the outpourings of the heart cannot be presented in the form of an essay .
('56', 34, 2, 13, 68365) Finding no alternative expression I had used “Disciplined faith”.
('56', 34, 2, 14, 68431) 2 But is does not express all I mean and at present no other expression occurs to my mind.
('56', 34, 2, 15, 68522) What is meant is that faith should not be ignorant, devoid of discrimination and blind.
('56', 34, 2, 16, 68610) For example in a matter where reasoning too applies someone asserts, “I take resort to faith and shall persist in doing so no matter what the reason indicates.” There is no discipline in this kind of faith.
('56', 34, 2, 17, 68817) To determine whether the earth is round or flat is a matter of intellect.
('56', 34, 2, 18, 68891) Despite this someone may say that his faith suggests the earth to be flat.
('56', 34, 2, 19, 68966) This is not disciplined faith.
('56', 34, 2, 20, 68997) [From Hindi] Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, pp.
('56', 34, 3, 21, 69043) 1 The addressee in an earlier letter had asked Gandhiji to narrate some incidents of his life which had awakened and strengthened his faith in God, to which Gandhiji replied on May 23, 1932 and inquired if the question had been put with a view to using the answer in Kalyan, a Hindi journal on religious matters published by the addressee.
('56', 34, 3, 22, 69383) 2 The addressee had requested an explanation of the expression “Sanyamamayi Shradda” used by Gandhiji in his letter May 23, 1932. Mahadev Desai in his diary has reproduced the letter in Gujarati though the original must have been in Hindi.
('56', 34, 3, 23, 69623) The expression “disciplined faith”, however, does not appear in the fragment of the text reproduced in the published diary.

('56', 35, 1, 2, 69788) 43. A LETTER 1
('56', 35, 2, 3, 69803) June 21, 1932 A craving for things of beauty is perfectly natural.
('56', 35, 2, 4, 69870) Only there is no absolute standard of beauty.
('56', 35, 2, 5, 69916) I have therefore come to think that the craving is not to be satisfied, but that from the craving for things outside of us, we must learn to see beauty from within.
('56', 35, 2, 6, 70081) And when we do that, a whole vista of beauty is opened out to us and the love appropriation vanishes.
('56', 35, 2, 7, 70183) I have expressed myself clumsily, but I hope you follow what I mean.
('56', 35, 2, 8, 70252) The purpose of life is undoubtedly to know oneself.
('56', 35, 2, 9, 70304) We cannot do it unless we learn to identify ourselves with all that lives.
('56', 35, 2, 10, 70379) The sum total of that life is God.
('56', 35, 2, 11, 70414) Hence the necessity of realizing God living within every one of us.
('56', 35, 2, 12, 70482) The instrument of this knowledge is boundless selfless service.
('56', 35, 3, 13, 70546) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, pp.

('56', 42, 1, 2, 83497) 51. LETTER TO PARASRAM MEHROTRA
('56', 42, 2, 3, 83529) June 23, 1932
('56', 42, 3, 4, 83543) PARASRAM, I had no fear or anxiety about Kamal’s illness.
('56', 42, 3, 5, 83601) Children often get fever etc.
('56', 42, 3, 6, 83631) If they do not fall into the clutches of illinformed doctors and if the parents do not, through ignorant love, go on loading their stomachs with food, most of them recover without any medicine.
('56', 42, 3, 7, 83825) Children have the vitality to recover from illness and regain strength sooner than grown up people.
('56', 42, 3, 8, 83925) You should ask those who used formely to attend the Ramayana classes but do not do so now, the reason why they do not attend them, not with a view to pressing them to attend but in order that, if they point out any defect in your manner of explaining, you may remove it.
('56', 42, 3, 9, 84196) You may, if you wish, read Saket 1 to all who attend .
('56', 42, 3, 10, 84251) But my suggestion was not that.
('56', 42, 3, 11, 84283) It was that you should teach selected portions from the work to those who had made some advance in the study of Hindi, so that, when their interest was aroused in it, they might read the work by themselves and bring their difficulties to you.
('56', 42, 3, 12, 84526) Anasakti certainly means freedom from attachment to anything concerning oneself and one’s relations, but also such deep attachment to the ‘other’, that is, to Truth, to God, so much so that one must lose oneself in Him, become one with Him.
('56', 42, 3, 13, 84767) It is because we do not understand this that our enthusiasm wanes and other difficulties arise.
('56', 42, 3, 14, 84863) You have used the word nirutsaha 2 as a noun.
('56', 42, 3, 15, 84909) Mahadev immediately pointed out to me that it is an adjective.
('56', 42, 3, 16, 84972) I told him that you had used it as a noun and that you were not likely to make such a mistake.
('56', 42, 3, 17, 85067) But he told me that you had made a mistake.
('56', 42, 3, 18, 85111) So we consulted a small Hindi dictionary which we have and found that it gives the word as an adjective.
('56', 42, 3, 19, 85216) Solve this problem.
('56', 42, 3, 20, 85236) BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 7503. Also C.W. 4980. Courtesy: Parasram Mehrotra

('56', 44, 1, 2, 87747) Your questions about men and women are good.
('56', 44, 1, 3, 87792) We should explain to a child any matter about which it shows curiosity, if we know the answer.
('56', 44, 1, 4, 87887) Otherwise, we should admit our ignorance.
('56', 44, 1, 5, 87929) If we think the child’s question should not be answered, we should restrain it and also tell it not to ask others.
('56', 44, 1, 6, 88044) In any case, we should never give an evasive reply.
('56', 44, 1, 7, 88096) Children know more about these things than we think they do.
('56', 44, 1, 8, 88157) If we refuse to tell them what they do not know, they learn to satisfy their curiosity in improper ways.
('56', 44, 1, 9, 88262) We should, however, take that risk and not tell them what we think they ought not to be told.
('56', 44, 1, 10, 88356) There are, of course, very few such things.
('56', 44, 1, 11, 88400) If they want to know about the obscene act, we should certainly not satisfy their curiosity.
('56', 44, 1, 12, 88493) Don’t mind if they learn the facts in a clandestine manner despite our forbidding it.
('56', 44, 1, 13, 88579) If children see birds engaged in the sex act and want to understand what it means, I would certainly satisfy their curiosity and use the opportunity to teach them the lesson of brahmacharya.
('56', 44, 1, 14, 88770) I would teach them the distinction between man on the one hand and birds and beasts on the other.
('56', 44, 1, 15, 88868) All the men and women who act in thesame manner are, despite their human form, like birds and beasts in that particular respect.
('56', 44, 1, 16, 88997) There is no condemnation of anyone in this; it is only a statement of fact.
('56', 44, 1, 17, 89073) We have been granted the human form and our intelligence so that we may rise above our animal nature.
('56', 44, 1, 18, 89175) All the facts about menstruation should be explained to a girl who has reached puberty; if a younger girl comes to know about the phenomenon and asks you about it, you may explain to her, too, as many facts as she can understand.
('56', 44, 1, 19, 89405) Despite all our precautions, children will not always remain ignorant about these facts.
('56', 44, 1, 20, 89494) Hence, it would be better to impart that knowledge to them at the proper time.
('56', 44, 1, 21, 89573) If brahmacharya is so frail a thing that a person who know the facts about sex cannot observe it, we have no use for such brahmacharya.
('56', 44, 1, 22, 89709) The knowledge of these facts should strengthen one’s brahmacharya.
('56', 44, 1, 23, 89776) That is what happened in my case.
('56', 44, 1, 24, 89810) The motives for seeking or imparting this knowledge differ from person to person.
('56', 44, 1, 25, 89892) One person may seek it in order to gratify his lust.
('56', 44, 1, 26, 89945) Another may learn the facts without his showing any curiosity about the subject.
('56', 44, 1, 27, 90026) A third person may seek the knowledge in order to calm his passions and to help others.
('56', 44, 1, 28, 90114) One should impart this knowledge to others only if one is fit for
('56', 45, 0, 1, 90180) 46 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('56', 45, 1, 2, 90221) the job.
('56', 45, 1, 3, 90230) You should have that ability, and also the confidence that by imprating it to the girls you will not awaken sex thoughts in them.
('56', 45, 1, 4, 90360) You should remember all the time that you impart this knowledge to the girls in order that they may not be disturbed by such thoughts.
('56', 45, 1, 5, 90495) If you yourself are not free from them you should take care that they do not disturb you while you are imparting this knowledge to the girls.
('56', 45, 1, 6, 90637) The primany aim behind the partnership in life of man and woman as husband and wife is physical enjoyment.
('56', 45, 1, 7, 90744) Hinduism has tried to teach in its place the practice of self control, or say, rather that all religions have done so.
('56', 45, 1, 8, 90863) If the husband is Brahma, Vishnu and Maheshwar, so is the wife.
('56', 45, 1, 9, 90927) A wife is not a servant; she is a friend with equal rights, a partner in dharma.
('56', 45, 1, 10, 91008) Each is the guru of the other.
('56', 45, 1, 11, 91039) A daughter’s share should be equal to a son’s.
('56', 45, 1, 12, 91086) A husband and a wife have equal rights in what either earns.
('56', 45, 1, 13, 91147) The husband earns with the wife’s help, even if she does no more than cook for the family.
('56', 45, 1, 14, 91238) She is not a servant, but is an equal partner.
('56', 45, 1, 15, 91285) A wife has the right to live separately from her husband if he ill treats her.
('56', 45, 1, 16, 91364) The two have equal rights over the children.
('56', 45, 1, 17, 91409) After the children have grown up, neither of them has any.
('56', 45, 1, 18, 91468) If the wife is unfit to exercise her right, she loses it.
('56', 45, 1, 19, 91526) And so does the husband.
('56', 45, 1, 20, 91551) In sum, I do not admit any differences between men and women except those created by Nature which all of us can see.

('56', 51, 1, 2, 101790) 61. HOW TO OBSERVE AHIMSA 1
('56', 51, 2, 3, 101818) June 25, 1932 Can we kill a snake?
('56', 51, 2, 4, 101853) Can we use violence against a ruffian attempting to rape a woman?
('56', 51, 2, 5, 101919) Can we plough a field, though knowing that we kill germs thereby?
('56', 51, 2, 6, 101985) A votary of ahimsa need not concern himself with such problems.
('56', 51, 2, 7, 102049) Let them solve themselves when they will.
('56', 51, 2, 8, 102091) If we lose ourselves in this labyrinth, we shall forget ahimsa.
('56', 51, 2, 9, 102155) Those who are sincere in their desire to follow ahimsa will examine their own hearts and look at their neighbours.
('56', 51, 2, 10, 102270) If one finds ill will and hatred in one’s heart, one may know that one has not climbed the first step towards the goal of ahimsa.
('56', 51, 2, 11, 102400) If a person does not observe ahimsa in his relations with his neighbours and his associates, he is thousands of miles away from ahimsa.
('56', 51, 2, 12, 102536) A votary of ahimsa, therefore, should ask himself every day when retiring: “Did I speak harshly today to any co worker?
('56', 51, 2, 13, 102656) Did I give him inferior khadi for myself?
('56', 51, 2, 14, 102698) Did I give him imperfectly baked roti and reserve for myself a fully baked one?
('56', 51, 2, 15, 102778) Did I shirk my duty and throw the burden on my co worker?
('56', 51, 2, 16, 102836) Did I neglect serving the neighbour who was ill today?
('56', 51, 2, 17, 102891) Did I refuse water to a thirsty passer by who asked for it?
('56', 51, 2, 18, 102951) Did I not care even to greet the guest who had arrived?
('56', 51, 2, 19, 103007) Did I scold a labourer?
('56', 51, 2, 20, 103031) Did I go on exacting work from him without thinking that he might be tired?
('56', 51, 2, 21, 103107) Did I goad bullocks with spiked sticks?
('56', 51, 2, 22, 103147) Did I get angry in the kitchen because the rice was half cooked?” All these are forms of intense violence.
('56', 51, 2, 23, 103254) If we do not observe ahimsa spontaneously in such daily acts, we shall never learn to observe it in other fields and, if at all we seem to observe it, our ahimsa will be of little or no value.
('56', 51, 2, 24, 103447) Ahimsa is a great force which is active every moment of our lives.
('56', 51, 2, 25, 103514) It is felt in our every action and thought.
('56', 51, 2, 26, 103558) He who takes care of his pennies may rest assured that his pound is safe.
('56', 51, 2, 27, 103632) But he who does not take care of pennies will lose them, and as for the pound he never had it.
('56', 51, 3, 28, 103727) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./II
('56', 51, 4, 29, 103771) 1 This was sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 22/26 6/1932; vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 22/26 6 1932.

('56', 62, 2, 3, 126306) June 28, 1932
('56', 62, 3, 4, 126320) BHAISHRI KHAMBHATTA, I got your letter.
('56', 62, 3, 5, 126360) I was informed about the arrival of the bottle of medicine, but Major Bhandari hesitates to let me use it.
('56', 62, 3, 6, 126467) He says that it is a camphor liniment described in British Pharmacopoeia and that it smells very strong and may, therefore, injure the skin.
('56', 62, 3, 7, 126608) If there is any ill effect, he would be held responsible.
('56', 62, 3, 8, 126666) If he knows the composition of the solution and thinks that the strength of the ingredients is light enough, he may let me use it.
('56', 62, 3, 9, 126797) That being the position, if you yourself make the oil please let him know its composition and also describe your experience of its effects.
('56', 62, 3, 10, 126937) He may then let me use it.
('56', 62, 3, 11, 126964) I pressed him to permit me to use it, but as he mentioned his responsibility I have kept quiet.
('56', 62, 3, 12, 127060) The pain in the elbow has not increased.
('56', 62, 3, 13, 127101) I give it complete rest, of course.
('56', 62, 3, 14, 127137) Blessings to you both from
('56', 62, 5, 15, 127164) From a photostat of the Gujarati : G.N. 7550. Also C.W. 5025. Courtesy: Tehmina Khambhatta
('56', 62, 6, 16, 127255) 70. LETTER TO NIRMALA GANDHI
('56', 62, 7, 17, 127284) August 28, 1932
('56', 62, 8, 18, 127300) NIMU I have a letter from Ramdas in which he says that it was not proper for you to have given up ghee without corresponding with him.
('56', 62, 8, 19, 127435) He also wishes that I should write to you in the matter and explain to you your duty.
('56', 62, 8, 20, 127521) He says, too, that he had not ordered you to give up cinnamon and clove.
('56', 62, 8, 21, 127594) At any rate, after seeing me he had given up the idea altogether.
('56', 62, 8, 22, 127660) He says moreover, that for the sake of the children also, you ought not to give up ghee.
('56', 62, 8, 23, 127749) I agree with all this.
('56', 62, 8, 24, 127772) It was your duty to have asked Ramdas what was the right thing to do.
('56', 62, 8, 25, 127842) He does not in the least wish to order you.
('56', 62, 8, 26, 127886) He has never believed that you are his subjects.
('56', 62, 8, 27, 127935) Surely you ought to have ascertained the full facts from the person on whose account you wished to take a vow.
('56', 62, 8, 28, 128046) Also, under the Ashram rules, you must obtainthe Manager’s permission to undertake anything by way of expiation.
('56', 62, 8, 29, 128159) You have not
('56', 63, 0, 1, 128172) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('56', 63, 1, 2, 128213) done that either.
('56', 63, 1, 3, 128231) Looking at the matter from every point of view, therefore, I feel that you should give up your resolve not to take ghee.
('56', 63, 1, 4, 128352) I hope the children are all right now.
('56', 63, 1, 5, 128391) Narandas says in his letter that their illness had somewhat frightened you.
('56', 63, 1, 6, 128467) Illness comes and goes.
('56', 63, 1, 7, 128491) Why should it frighten one?
('56', 63, 1, 8, 128519) It is certainly no easy matter to be a mother.
('56', 63, 1, 9, 128566) A mother may look after her children as well as she can.
('56', 63, 1, 10, 128623) Then, whether the children keep good health or bad, live or die, is in the hands of God.
('56', 63, 1, 11, 128712) And this applies to all living beings alike.
('56', 63, 1, 12, 128757) Therefore, why grieve?
('56', 63, 1, 13, 128780) On the contrary, giving way to grief interferes with the nursing of the ill.
('56', 63, 1, 14, 128857) Be regular in writing to me.
('56', 63, 1, 15, 128886) Start taking ghee and inform Ramdas that you have done so.
('56', 63, 1, 16, 128945) You know well enough how Ramdas worries about you.
('56', 63, 3, 17, 128996) From the Gujarati original : Mrs. Sumitra Kulkarni Papers.

('56', 64, 3, 9, 130512) But as yet the picture of the whole subject (lit.
('56', 64, 3, 10, 130562) all things) does not come before me.
('56', 64, 3, 11, 130599) But I am pursuing it and so I hope to be sufficiently acquainted with the subject.
('56', 64, 3, 12, 130682) So far I have been reading (Prof.) Shah’s book on Banking and Exchange.
('56', 64, 3, 13, 130754) In this connection any books which may be considered worth reading may be sent.

('56', 65, 10, 23, 132613) 3 I have read nothing of Hardy or Zola.

('56', 66, 3, 12, 133871) 76. LETTER TO SUMANGAL PRAKASH
('56', 66, 4, 13, 133902) June 29, 1932
('56', 66, 5, 14, 133916) DEAR SUMANGAL, Your letter to hand.
('56', 66, 5, 15, 133952) Your argument with regard to rape seems convincing.
('56', 66, 5, 16, 134004) In circumstances similar to those in which you believe it right for a woman to take her life, it may be right for a trustee to take his life when somebody tries to rob the property under his care.
('56', 66, 5, 17, 134201) But the woman and the trustee themselves should think that it is their dharma to do so.
('56', 66, 5, 18, 134289) You or I have no right to accuse a woman of failingin her dharma if she does not kill herself to prevent herself from being raped.
('56', 66, 5, 19, 134420) If, unlike her, the trustee dies while defending the property under his care, we cannot assume, either, that he has done the right thing.
('56', 66, 5, 20, 134558) We can judge in either case only if we know the mental condition of the person concerned at the time.
('56', 66, 5, 21, 134660) Though I say this from the point of view of justice, personally I believe that a woman, if she has courage, would be ready to die to save her honour.
('56', 66, 5, 22, 134810) In discussing this matter with women, I would, therefore, certainly advise them to kill themselves in such circumstances and explain to them that it was easy to take one’s life if one wished to do so.
('56', 66, 5, 23, 135011) I would do this because many women believe that, if there is no man present to protect them or if they have not learnt to use a dagger or a gun, they have no choice but to submit to the evil doer.
('56', 66, 5, 24, 135208) I would certainly tell a woman who believes so, that she need not depend upon anybody’s weapons to protect her and that her own virtue will protect her.
('56', 66, 5, 25, 135361) Even if that does not happen, instead of using a dagger or any other weapon she can kill herself.
('56', 66, 5, 26, 135459) She need not consider herself weak or helpless.
('56', 67, 0, 1, 135507) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('56', 67, 1, 2, 135548) And now concerning hypothetical questions.
('56', 67, 1, 3, 135591) I had understood your purpose in asking the questions to be exactly what you explain it to be, but I would describe such questions as hypothetical.
('56', 67, 1, 4, 135739) In some cases questions of this nature may be asked, but it would be better not to ask any.
('56', 67, 1, 5, 135831) In any case, you should not make it a habit of asking such questions.
('56', 67, 1, 6, 135901) Anybody who does that commits the same error which a student of geometry who asks his professor to solve riders does.
('56', 67, 1, 7, 136019) Such a student will never learn geometry well.
('56', 67, 1, 8, 136066) That will also be the fate of a person who seeks the solutions of problems arising out of a principle from other people.
('56', 67, 1, 9, 136187) Apart from this, however, there is a great flaw in the very nature of questions raised on the basis of ethical principles, namely, we never come across in life an instance exactly similar to the one we had imagined.
('56', 67, 1, 10, 136403) If there is ever so slight a difference between the hypothetical case and the actual one, the answers in the two cases are likely to be entirely different.
('56', 67, 1, 11, 136559) That is why I have cautioned you that, if you are not confronted with a problem relating to an actual instance which you have come across, you should not make it a habit to seek from me solutions of hypothetical problems in order to be prepared for such eventualities.
('56', 67, 1, 12, 136828) If you do that, my answers to hypothetical questions will, instead of helping you in an emergency, prevent you from finding the right solution.
('56', 67, 1, 13, 136972) The mind of such a person becomes incapable of original thinking.
('56', 67, 1, 14, 137038) The better thing would be to grasp the basic principle thoroughly and to assimilate it, and not to mind if, in applying it in solving your problems or those of other members in your family, you make mistakes.
('56', 67, 1, 15, 137247) You will learn from such mistakes, But you should not approach others, even those who understand the principle better than you do, to seek solutions of hypothetical problems in order to prepare yourself to meet them when they arise.
('56', 67, 1, 16, 137480) Such a procedure destroys one’s self confidence.
('56', 67, 1, 17, 137529) The author of the Gita seems to have written verse 10 of Chapter X because he knew this from experience.
('56', 67, 1, 18, 137634) Doesn’t the Lord tell us in that verse that “to these, ever in tune with Me, worshipping Me with affectionate devotion.
('56', 67, 1, 19, 137754) I give the power of selfless action, whereby they come to Me.” If you substitute “Truth” for “God” in this sentence, the meaning will be perfectly clear.
('56', 67, 1, 20, 137908) I hope you now understand what I meant to say.
('56', 67, 1, 21, 137955) I do not mind your hypothetical questions, but I fear that I may do you harm by encouraging you to put such questions.
('56', 67, 1, 22, 138074) I am sure at any rate that I would not be helping you.
('56', 67, 1, 23, 138129) Take, for instance, your question regarding rape.
('56', 67, 1, 24, 138179) Though I may give a definite reply now to your question regarding a hypothetical instance, I would
('56', 68, 0, 1, 138278) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4 SEPTEMBER, 1932 69
('56', 68, 1, 2, 138323) give quite a different reply if an instance like that actually occurred, and support it with convincing reasons.
('56', 68, 1, 3, 138436) It is also very possible that I would be able to point out a difference between the hypothetical case and the actual incident.
('56', 68, 1, 4, 138563) I write all this from experience about coworkers.
('56', 68, 1, 5, 138613) I will stop here now.
('56', 68, 1, 6, 138635) I am glad to learn that your health has improved.
('56', 68, 2, 7, 138685) Blessings from BAPU [From Gujarati]
('56', 68, 3, 8, 138721) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, pp.

('56', 68, 4, 11, 138859) 77. A LETTER 1
('56', 68, 5, 12, 138874) June 29, 1932 Why should you wish to commit suicide?
('56', 68, 5, 13, 138927) So far as I know, you have not deceived anyone.
('56', 68, 5, 14, 138975) And since you have resolved never to speculate in future, that chapter is closed.
('56', 68, 5, 15, 139057) Even if you have deceived anybody, that is no reason for committing suicide.
('56', 68, 5, 16, 139134) A person who confesses that he has deceived people is better than other who deceive but who are not found out or than those who have not been put in circumstances in which they would feel tempted to deceive.
('56', 68, 5, 17, 139342) You have, therefore, no reason for committing suicide.
('56', 68, 5, 18, 139397) And now about the problem of debt.
('56', 68, 5, 19, 139432) If you hand over everything you have to your creditors, your responsibility will be over.
('56', 68, 5, 20, 139522) If the creditors declare you insolvent, let them do so.
('56', 68, 5, 21, 139578) There is nothing to be ashamed of even in that.
('56', 68, 5, 22, 139626) Manliness lies in facing whatever happens.
('56', 68, 5, 23, 139669) I have already written to you and told you how you may live now.
('56', 68, 5, 24, 139734) Both of you should go and live in the Ashram.
('56', 68, 5, 25, 139780) Do not feel the slightest hesitation in doing so.
('56', 68, 5, 26, 139830) Do not be proud and think that, now that you are a poor man, you cannot go to a place where you often used to go in the days of your prosperity.
('56', 68, 5, 27, 139975) The Ashram exists for good people.
('56', 68, 5, 28, 140010) Write to me from time to time.
('56', 68, 5, 29, 140041) Seek Mirabehn’s company for what comfort it can give you.
('56', 68, 5, 30, 140099) Know that good company is like a philosopher's stone and be near her.
('56', 68, 5, 31, 140169) [From Gujarati]
('56', 68, 6, 32, 140185) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, p.

('56', 70, 7, 21, 143088) 80. LETTER TO THE PRIVATS 2
('56', 70, 8, 22, 143116) June 30, 1932 My dear bhakti and anand, It was a great delight to hear from you both and to know that you were doing so well.
('56', 70, 8, 23, 143242) I had one postcard from Anand whilst you were travelling.
('56', 70, 8, 24, 143300) Nothing beyond it.
('56', 70, 8, 25, 143319) Of course you remember Sardar Vallabhbhai.
('56', 70, 8, 26, 143362) He and Mahadev are with me.
('56', 70, 8, 27, 143390) We are all keeping well trying to made ourselves useful.
('56', 70, 8, 28, 143447) Mahadev and I give fair time to spinning and studying.
('56', 70, 8, 29, 143502) Sardar produces wealth by making envelopes from waste brown paper and the like.

('56', 96, 2, 5, 190728) 116. LETTER TO MAGANBHAI PATEL
('56', 96, 3, 6, 190759) July 2/3, 1932
('56', 96, 4, 7, 190774) BROTHER MAGANBHAI, Raojibhai’s letter about his lands to hand.
('56', 96, 4, 8, 190837) In it he writes that you see the necessity of selling the lands, and also believe that the lands will not fetch as much price in the absence of Raojibhai as they would have, if he were present.
('56', 96, 4, 9, 191031) Instead of coming to a decision himself, Raojibhai has left it to me and Sardar (Vallabhbhai Patel) to decide (the matter).
('56', 96, 4, 10, 191155) On consultation we have decided that you know most in this matter.
('56', 96, 4, 11, 191222) There cannot be enough materials before Raojibhai or ourselves to arrive at a decision.
('56', 96, 4, 12, 191310) Even if you make endeavours and supply us as much information as might be needed, yet it might be considered insufficient.
('56', 96, 4, 13, 191433) In such matters, decision cannot be and should not be reached without one being actually on the spot.
('56', 96, 4, 14, 191535) Hence we have cone to the decision that you should do whatever is proper to be done having regard to the circumstances.
('56', 96, 4, 15, 191655) If you think that is should be sold, you should sell it without any hesitation.
('56', 96, 4, 16, 191735) And if you feel that it can be kept—must be kept—then wait till Raojibhai is released.
('56', 96, 4, 17, 191822) You do without fear whatever is more advantageous.
('56', 96, 4, 18, 191873) We both of us know that Raojibhai is keen on setting apart a piece of land sufficient for building as ashram for the Dharalas.
('56', 96, 4, 19, 192000) But, if in carrying out that object, less price is realized for the lands or if any debt still remains unpaid, it is not necessary to insist on that.
('56', 96, 4, 20, 192150) If there is any need for an ashram, it will be seen through when Raojibhai is released.
('56', 96, 4, 21, 192238) Blessings from MOHANDAS

('56', 97, 0, 1, 192354) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('56', 97, 1, 2, 192395) 117. HOW TO OBSERVE TRUTH 1
('56', 97, 2, 3, 192423) Sunday, July 3, 1932 2
('56', 97, 3, 4, 192446) What I said about ahimsa 3 also applies to truth.
('56', 97, 3, 5, 192496) If we split hairs about issues such as whether one may or may not tell a lie to save a cow and ignore what is daily happening before us, we cannot follow truth.
('56', 97, 3, 6, 192657) By raising such complicated issues we make truth difficult to discover.
('56', 97, 3, 7, 192729) If we follow truth today in solving the problems which confront us in our daily life, we shall know instinctively how to act in difficult situations when they arise.
('56', 97, 3, 8, 192895) Each of us should examine only himself or herself from this point of view.
('56', 97, 3, 9, 192970) Do I deceive anybody knowingly?
('56', 97, 3, 10, 193002) If I believe that B is a bad person but show him that I believe him to be good, I deceive him.
('56', 97, 3, 11, 193097) Do I try to show, in order to win people’s respect or esteem, that I possess certain virtues which in fact.
('56', 97, 3, 12, 193205) I do not possess?
('56', 97, 3, 13, 193223) Do I exaggerate in my speech?
('56', 97, 3, 14, 193253) Do I hide my misdeeds from persons to whom I should confess them?
('56', 97, 3, 15, 193319) If a superior or co worker puts me any question, do I evade him?
('56', 97, 3, 16, 193384) Do I keep back what I ought to declare?
('56', 97, 3, 17, 193424) If I do any of these things, I am guilty of untruth.
('56', 97, 3, 18, 193477) Everybody should examine his conduct daily in this manner and try to overcome his shortcomings.
('56', 97, 3, 19, 193573) One to whom truth has become second nature and who has risen to a state so that he can never speak untruth may not do this.
('56', 97, 3, 20, 193697) But everyone who has the least trace of untruth in him or who can follow truth only with effort should examine himself daily as explained above and put to himself those or any other similar questions which may occur to him and reply to them.
('56', 97, 3, 21, 193939) Anybody who follows this practice even for a month will clearly observe a change having taken place in himself.

('56', 108, 4, 21, 216447) PREMA, I got your letter, By trying to give artistic appearance to the envelope, you spoiled it.
('56', 108, 4, 22, 216544) This is bound to be the result when one tries to create beauty which meets no practical need.
('56', 108, 4, 23, 216638) Sardar makes no effort to give to an envelope artistic appearance for its own sake; such appearance is the by product of practical utility and, therefore, please
('56', 109, 0, 1, 216800) 110 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('56', 109, 1, 2, 216842) the eye.

('56', 109, 1, 5, 217115) But he was not satisfied with this.
('56', 109, 1, 6, 217151) So now he turns the envelopes received from there inside out, so that he need not paste slips over them and the envelops may look as good as new.

('56', 111, 2, 5, 221880) 128. LETTER TO MATHURADAS PURUSHOTTAM
('56', 111, 3, 6, 221918) July 6, 1932
('56', 111, 4, 7, 221931) MATHURADAS, I got your letter.
('56', 111, 4, 8, 221962) You should not belittle your idea of sewing for yajna.
('56', 111, 4, 9, 222017) Its real value lies in turning to use even the poorest quality of khadi.
('56', 111, 4, 10, 222090) We cannot afford to pay for sewing.
('56', 111, 4, 11, 222126) However, those who are ready to do sewing as free service can give even to the most unattr active khadi the value which devotees of God give to flowers by making garlands for the deity from them.
('56', 111, 4, 12, 222322) For instance, one who gives such service should not make shirt from bad khadi, but he can make quilts, bagos or pillows from it.
('56', 111, 4, 13, 222451) We can think of a number of things made from such khadi which would not need to be washed and which could be used for a long time in the same condition.
('56', 111, 4, 14, 222604) I had a hand spun and hand woven wollen blanket with me, which I had received as a gift.
('56', 111, 4, 15, 222693) It had been so much worn out be use that, if used longer, it would have not torn out into pieces.
('56', 111, 4, 16, 222791) But, being of an ingenious turn of mind and having a friend like Janakibehn 1 who is ever ready to help me, I gave the blanket to her and told her how she could make it into a new one.
('56', 111, 4, 17, 222976) The blanket is still with me.
('56', 111, 4, 18, 223006) I deliberately took it with me, when I visited the Royal Palace in England.
('56', 111, 4, 19, 223082) 2 Let me explain, too, how the blanket was made new.
('56', 111, 4, 20, 223135) It was sewn on to a piece of thick khadi, the whole surface being stitched both length wise and breadth wise.
('56', 111, 4, 21, 223245) The wornout woollen blanket, being thus lined with khadi, become as good as new and gave more warmth than before.
('56', 111, 4, 22, 223359) This does not mean that the effort which you are making for improving the quality of yarn is unnecessary.
('56', 111, 4, 23, 223465) I daily realize the necessity of such effort.
('56', 111, 4, 24, 223511) But such improvement will not reduce the importance of sewing for yajna or dispense with it.
('56', 111, 4, 25, 223604) The love of khadi has still not spread widely in the country.
('56', 111, 4, 26, 223666) It means, in other words, that love of the poor has not spread so, or, even where it exists, the people who have it
('56', 111, 5, 27, 223782) 1 Wife of Jamnalal Bajaj 2 During the Round Table Conference in 1931
('56', 112, 0, 1, 223851) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4 SEPTEMBER, 1932 113
('56', 112, 1, 2, 223897) are ignorant and are not yet convinced that the best way of showing their love is by patronizing khadi.
('56', 112, 1, 3, 224001) If they can be convinced of this, your discovery can become very useful.
('56', 112, 1, 4, 224074) I have not, therefore, become indifferent to it in the slightest degree.
('56', 112, 1, 5, 224147) Do write a book on how to spin better yarn.
('56', 112, 1, 6, 224191) But do not make a single statement in it the truth of which you have not tested.
('56', 112, 1, 7, 224272) Nor should you deduce any general principle only on the basis of exclusively your experience.
('56', 112, 1, 8, 224366) Others also must have found it true.
('56', 112, 1, 9, 224403) If you have not checked all your statements in this manner, postpone writing the book.
('56', 112, 1, 10, 224490) I observe again and again that books which have no basis in experience are practically without any value.
('56', 112, 1, 11, 224596) For instance, if anybody translated Charaka 1, the work would not be of any use today since we cannot find many of the herbs and plants described by him and, with regard to those which we do find, cannot prove the properties attributed to them.
('56', 112, 1, 12, 224841) The most important thing therefore is that you yourself should spin the finest possible yarn of different counts and, while doing so, analyse and note the contribution of the spindle, the type of the spinning wheel, the quality of the cotton used, the quality of the carding and your own, that is, the spinner’s skill towards the result.
('56', 112, 1, 13, 225179) Then tally your experience with that of other spinners.
('56', 112, 1, 14, 225235) A book based on such data will accepted without question, like a bar of gold weighed on the scale kept in the market for public use.
('56', 112, 1, 15, 225368) You asked me what limit I have fixed with regard to the count of the yarn spun.
('56', 112, 1, 16, 225448) Previously I had fixed it at 20, then raised it to 40. I do not lay down any limit now.
('56', 112, 1, 17, 225536) If we can get or grow cotton from which we can spin yarn of 400 counts and which we can card well enough for such purpose, and if we can get men or women spinners who have sufficient patience to spin yarn of such quality, I would certainly desire that we should reach that level.
('56', 112, 1, 18, 225816) In short, I think it very important that we should go in this direction as far as we can, for this is likely immediately to enhance the value of the art of hand spinning.
('56', 112, 1, 19, 225987) I am sure you know that a friend of Satis Babu had reached up to 150 counts.
('56', 112, 1, 20, 226064) The khadi woven from it is preserved in Satis Babu’s collection.
('56', 112, 1, 21, 226129) But along with this I also insist that as we progress in spinning yarn of finer and finer count the yarn should always be strong and even.
('56', 112, 1, 22, 226268) I cannot say what marks any specimen of yarn should earn for passing the test in these respects.
('56', 112, 1, 23, 226365) Only you and other experienced spinners can say that.
('56', 112, 1, 24, 226419) I certainly have a rough test for this
('56', 112, 2, 25, 226458) 1 Author of Charakasamhita, a manual of Ayurvedic medicine

('56', 113, 1, 2, 226559) purpose, and it is that any weaver should be able to weave the yarn without difficulty.
('56', 113, 1, 3, 226647) If a weaver rejects a lot, I would treat it as below par though it may have passed our test.

('56', 114, 4, 9, 228987) 131. LETTER TO PARASRAM MEHROTRA
('56', 114, 5, 10, 229020) July 6, 1932
('56', 114, 6, 11, 229033) PARASRAM, I have both your letters.
('56', 114, 6, 12, 229069) Whenever there is doubt about the grammar of a Hindi word, is not consulting a dictionary the right course?
('56', 114, 6, 13, 229177) One who knows Sanskrit will commit fewer mistakes in using his words.
('56', 114, 6, 14, 229247) But a word used in Sanskrit in a particular sense would not, as a rule, be used in the same sense in Hindi.
('56', 114, 6, 15, 229355) We should therefore regard the dictionary as an authority.
('56', 114, 6, 16, 229414) And where the help of the dictionary is not available, we should regard one who knows Sanskrit as an authority.
('56', 114, 6, 17, 229526) I looked up the word nirutsaha [wanting in enthusiasm] in the Hindi dictionary which is with me, and there also it is termed an adjective.
('56', 114, 6, 18, 229665) Hence one who knows Sanskrit and the dictionary both agree about it.
('56', 114, 6, 19, 229734) I write all this merely out the love of language.
('56', 114, 6, 20, 229784) I expect a higher knowledge of the language from those who know a particular language.
('56', 114, 6, 21, 229871) I also expect them to use it correctly.
('56', 114, 6, 22, 229911) Hence I asked about the word nirutsaha in my last letter 1. I have always thought your knowledge of Hindi to be sound and I expect you to be more and more vigilant about it day by day.
('56', 114, 6, 23, 230096) Someone must dedicate his life in the service of Hindi.
('56', 114, 6, 24, 230152) Politics is always on our neck.
('56', 114, 6, 25, 230184) But this cannot be nor should it be an exclusive field.
('56', 114, 6, 26, 230240) We might have willingly or unwillingly plunged into it, but as soon as its activities calm down, we should return to our pursuit.
('56', 114, 6, 27, 230370) Also not all of us need
('56', 114, 7, 28, 230394) 1 Vide “Letter to Parasram Mehrotra”, 23 6 1932.
('56', 115, 0, 1, 230443) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('56', 126, 7, 17, 248874) 155. LETTER TO SHARDA C. SHAH
('56', 126, 8, 18, 248904) July 8, 1932
('56', 126, 9, 19, 248917) SHARDA, It is my belief that nobody really knows the origin of the name Bharatakhanda.
('56', 126, 9, 20, 249004) But it is said the name Bharatakhanda came from Bharat, the son of Shakuntala 2. You need not give any importance to things like the shaking of legs, etc.

('56', 127, 1, 2, 249625) 156. LETTER TO E.E. DOYLE
('56', 127, 2, 3, 249651) July 9, 1932
('56', 127, 3, 4, 249664) DEAR COL.
('56', 127, 3, 5, 249674) DOYLE, Upon inquiring of Major Bhandari why there has been recently irregularity about my post, I find that his orders are to send all my outgoing and incoming post to the Government.
('56', 127, 3, 6, 249858) If this procedure means interminable delay in the despatch of the outgoing post and the delivery to me of the incoming post, I should lose all interest in this, what to me is, healthy mental food.
('56', 127, 3, 7, 250055) I do not write idly.
('56', 127, 3, 8, 250076) Nor, so far as I am aware, do I transgress the limits to which I may go in writing to my friends.
('56', 127, 3, 9, 250174) If the Government intend to continue to let me write the letters I have been writing hitherto, I should like to be sure of regularity about the handing in of my correspondence.
('56', 127, 3, 10, 250351) The letters to and from the Ashram are regularly written.
('56', 127, 3, 11, 250409) I attach the greatest importance to this correspondence, including my letters to and from Shrimati Mirabai.
('56', 127, 3, 12, 250517) I should like to know at the earliest possible moment where I stand in the matter of my post.
('56', 127, 4, 13, 250611) Yours sincerely,
('56', 127, 5, 14, 250628) M. K. GANDHI

('56', 127, 7, 17, 250729) 157. LETTER TO P.G. MATHEW
('56', 127, 8, 18, 250756) July 9, 1932
('56', 127, 9, 19, 250769) MY DEAR MATHEW, In ‘God is Truth’, ‘is’ certainly does not mean ‘equal to’ nor does it merely mean ‘is truthful’.
('56', 127, 9, 20, 250883) Truth is not a mere attribute of God but He is That.
('56', 127, 9, 21, 250936) He is nothing if He is not That.
('56', 127, 9, 22, 250969) Truth in Sanskrit means Sat.
('56', 127, 9, 23, 250998) Sat means ‘Is’.
('56', 127, 9, 24, 251014) Therefore Truth is implied in ‘Is’.
('56', 127, 9, 25, 251050) God is, nothing else is.
('56', 127, 9, 26, 251075) Therefore the more truthful we are, the nearer we are to God.
('56', 127, 9, 27, 251137) We are only to the extent that we are truthful.
('56', 127, 9, 28, 251185) The illustration of hen and her chickens is good.
('56', 127, 9, 29, 251235) But better still is that of the Lord and His serf.
('56', 127, 9, 30, 251286) The latter is far from the former because both are mentally so far apart thought physically so near.
('56', 128, 0, 1, 251387) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4 SEPTEMBER, 1932 129
('56', 128, 1, 2, 251433) Hence Milton’s “mind is its own place” 1 and the Gita’s “man is the author of his own freedom or bondage.” 2
('56', 128, 2, 3, 251542) It is to realize this freedom that I would have us to labour as pariahs and labourers.
('56', 128, 3, 4, 251629) From a photostat: G.N. 1555. Also Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I., p.
('56', 128, 4, 5, 251696) 158. LETTER TO BHAU PANSE
('56', 128, 5, 6, 251722) July 9, 1932
('56', 128, 6, 7, 251735) BHAU, I also did not feel happy about the first stanza 3 in our prayer.
('56', 128, 6, 8, 251807) But on thinking more deeply about it, I realized that reciting it daily with proper understanding of its meaning was useful.
('56', 128, 6, 9, 251932) Our reason certainly tells us that we are not this physical body, but are the witness who dwells in it.
('56', 128, 6, 10, 252036) The stanza describes this witness, and then the seeker asserts that he is that witness—the Brahman.
('56', 128, 6, 11, 252136) Only those who daily strive to become that and loosen the bond of their physical bodies can make such an assertion.
('56', 128, 6, 12, 252252) Whenever one realizes that one has forgotten one’s real nature or is overcome with fear or with the dualities of love and hatred, pleasure and pain, etc., one should remember the qualities of the Brahman and try to become free from the dualities.
('56', 128, 6, 13, 252499) By so doing, one becomes that on which one daily meditates.
('56', 128, 6, 14, 252559) We may, therefore,daily recite that stanza with humility and firm aspiration and keep in mind our assertion in all our actions.
('56', 128, 6, 15, 252687) BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 6733. Also C.W. 4476. Courtesy: Bhau Panse
('56', 128, 7, 16, 252774) 1 Paradise Lost, I. 253 2 “ —–” This, however, is not from the Gita but from the Mahabindu Upanishad.
('56', 128, 7, 17, 252876) 3 “Early in the morning I call to mind that Being which is felt in the heart, which is sat (the eternal),chit (knowledge) and sukham (bliss), which is the state reached by perfect men and which is the super state.
('56', 128, 7, 18, 253090) I am that immaculate Brahman which ever notes the states of dream, wakefulness and deep sleep, not this body, the compound made of the elements—earth, water, space, light and air.”

('56', 133, 9, 22, 262399) 163. LETTER TO DHIRU
('56', 133, 10, 23, 262420) July 9, 1932
('56', 133, 11, 24, 262433) DEAR DHIRU,
('56', 133, 12, 25, 262445) I do not consider your letter to be clear.
('56', 133, 12, 26, 262488) You say that there in no difficulty in spinning yarn of 15 counts, and when you reach 30
('56', 134, 0, 1, 262577) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4 SEPTEMBER, 1932 135
('56', 134, 1, 2, 262623) counts, it is done up.
('56', 134, 1, 3, 262646) But there is a great difference between yarn of 15 and 30 counts.
('56', 134, 1, 4, 262712) Do you say that there is no difficulty in spinning yarn up to 30 counts?
('56', 134, 1, 5, 262785) If you say that, what is the speed for spinning yarn of 30 counts?
('56', 134, 1, 6, 262852) What is the waste in spinning a tola of yarn?
('56', 134, 1, 7, 262898) What is the speed for spinning yarn of 40 counts?
('56', 134, 1, 8, 262948) What is the waste after it?
('56', 134, 1, 9, 262976) What is the reason that there is difficulty in spinning yarn of finer counts?
('56', 134, 1, 10, 263054) Prabhudas has much faith in you.
('56', 134, 1, 11, 263087) If you want to fulfil his hopes, you should be engrossed in the spinning wheel and find out its faults if there be any, and should find out its measure of strengh.
('56', 134, 1, 12, 263251) By spinning on one spindle only, perhaps, yarn of finer quality might be obtained.
('56', 134, 1, 13, 263334) Also find out whether you can obtain as much yarn upon a spindle by the Magan spinning wheel, as you would get on a spindle by an ordinary spinning wheel.
('56', 134, 1, 14, 263489) Many Muslims believe in rebirth.
('56', 134, 1, 15, 263522) There is a great difference between one who tells a falsehood once and one who has formed a habit of telling lies.
