('56', 135, 0, 1, 263725) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 136
('56', 135, 1, 2, 263767) 164. EDUCATION 1
('56', 135, 2, 3, 263784) July 10, 1932 I will explain in brief one central idea about education which has been dominating my thoughts as I am writing the history of the Ashram.
('56', 135, 2, 4, 263936) Some persons see a deficiency in the Ashram, namely, absence of any arrangement for education, that is, for literary education.
('56', 135, 2, 5, 264064) I also can see this deficiency.
('56', 135, 2, 6, 264096) But it will probably remain as long as the Ashram lasts.
('56', 135, 2, 7, 264153) I will not here go into the reasons for that.
('56', 135, 2, 8, 264199) People see this deficiency because we do not know the true meaning of education and the right method of acquiring it, or we assume that the existing system of imparting education is the right one.
('56', 135, 2, 9, 264396) According to me, the present idea of education and the method of imparting and receiving it are both faulty.
('56', 135, 2, 10, 264505) True education is that which helps us to know the atman, our true self, God and Truth.
('56', 135, 2, 11, 264592) To acquire this knowledge, some persons may feel the need for a study of literature, some for a study of physical sciences and some others for art.
('56', 135, 2, 12, 264740) But every branch of knowledge should have as its goal knowledge of the self.
('56', 135, 2, 13, 264817) That is so in the Ashram.
('56', 135, 2, 14, 264843) We carry on numerous activities with that aim in view.
('56', 135, 2, 15, 264898) All of them are, in my sense of the term, true education.
('56', 135, 2, 16, 264956) Those activities can also be carried on without any reference to the goal of knowledge of the self.
('56', 135, 2, 17, 265056) When they are so carried on, they may serve as a means of livelihood or of something else, but they are not education.
('56', 135, 2, 18, 265175) In an activity carried on as education, a proper understanding of its meaning, devotion to duty and the spirit of service are necessary.
('56', 135, 2, 19, 265312) The first necessarily brings about development of the intellect.
('56', 135, 2, 20, 265377) In doing any piece of work, however small, we should be inspired by a holy aim and, while doing it, we should try to understand the purpose which it will serve and the scientific method of doing it.
('56', 135, 2, 21, 265576) There is a science of every type of work—whether it be cooking, sanitation, carpentry or spinning.
('56', 135, 2, 22, 265675) Everybody who does his work with the attitude of a student knows its science or discovers it.
('56', 135, 2, 23, 265769) If the inmates of the Ashram understand this, they would see that the Ashram is a great school in which the inmates receive
('56', 135, 3, 24, 265893) 1 This was sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 6/10 7 1932; vide the following item.
('56', 136, 0, 1, 265987) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4 SEPTEMBER, 1932 137
('56', 136, 1, 2, 266033) education not for a few hours only but all the time.
('56', 136, 1, 3, 266086) Every person who lives in the Ashram to attain knowledge of the self—of Truth—is both a teacher and a pupil.
('56', 136, 1, 4, 266195) He is a teacher in regard to what he knows, and a pupil in regard to anything about which he needs to learn.
('56', 136, 1, 5, 266304) If we know more than our neighbour about anything, we should willingly share our knowledge with him, and equally willingly receive from him what he knows more than we do.
('56', 136, 1, 6, 266475) If we thus regularly exchange knowledge with others, we would not feel the absence of teachers, and education would become a painless and spontaneous process.
('56', 136, 1, 7, 266634) The most important education is the training of character.
('56', 136, 1, 8, 266693) As we advance in our observance of yamaniyamas, our capacity for learning—for knowing Truth—will go on increasing.
('56', 136, 1, 9, 266808) What about literary education, then?
('56', 136, 1, 10, 266845) It is no more a question.
('56', 136, 1, 11, 266871) The rule for this is the same as for the other activities.
('56', 136, 1, 12, 266930) The method explained above dispenses with one superstition, namely, that for education we require a separate building known as school and a teacher to teach.
('56', 136, 1, 13, 267088) When the desire for literary education awakens in us, we should know that we shall have to acquire it through self help.
('56', 136, 1, 14, 267209) There is ample scope for this in the Ashram.
('56', 136, 1, 15, 267254) If I have been able to explain above my idea clearly, literary education should no more be a problem.
('56', 136, 1, 16, 267356) Those who possess it should take every opportunity to impart it to others and the latter should receive it from them.
('56', 136, 2, 17, 267474) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./II
('56', 136, 3, 18, 267518) 165. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('56', 136, 4, 19, 267549) July 6/10, 1932
('56', 136, 5, 20, 267565) NARANDAS, I got your letter and the other mail.
('56', 136, 5, 21, 267613) These day I get them very regularly.
('56', 136, 5, 22, 267650) I had handed over my packet on Monday for being posted and I do not understand why you did not get it till Saturday.
('56', 136, 5, 23, 267767) In future, you should inspect the postmark on every packet.
('56', 136, 5, 24, 267827) It is difficult to understand how a letter posted by you there reaches me the next day but what I send from here reaches you after six days.
('56', 136, 5, 25, 267968) You need not send me just now the register of hours of work.
('56', 136, 5, 26, 268029) It will be quite enough it you send it whenever you observe anything special in the figures, or at the most once a month.
('56', 136, 5, 27, 268151) Among other things, I am sure of this, that when the whole thing has become systematic everybody will do his or her work sincerely and then
('56', 137, 0, 1, 268291) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 138
('56', 137, 1, 2, 268333) nobody will feel any burden.
('56', 137, 1, 3, 268362) If anybody feels a little worried in hismind, that also will and must disappear.
('56', 137, 1, 4, 268443) For a sincere person one thing should be enough.
('56', 137, 1, 5, 268492) Nobody should undertake more than what he can cope with and should wish to do less than what he can.
('56', 137, 1, 6, 268593) He who attempts to do more than what he is capable of suffers from pride, he is attached to work and its fruit.
('56', 137, 1, 7, 268705) He who does less than what he can is a thief.
('56', 137, 1, 8, 268751) By maintaining a register of the hours of work, we can save ourselves from either mistake, may be without knowing it.
('56', 137, 1, 9, 268869) I don’t say that we shall positively save ourselves, for, if we do not help to keep the register willingly and with full appreciation of its need, we cannot derive the fullest benefit from it.
('56', 137, 1, 10, 269062) Did you carefully read Sitala Sahay’s letter?
('56', 137, 1, 11, 269108) I saw nothing objectionable in it.
('56', 137, 1, 12, 269143) I see no anger in it.
('56', 137, 1, 13, 269165) If what he writes about Prabhudas is correct, his demand is not unreasonable.
('56', 137, 1, 14, 269243) But we can decide this justly only in the manner I have explained, that is, by examining his expenses.
('56', 137, 1, 15, 269346) In such matters, examples of others give us no help.

('56', 137, 1, 17, 269559) It is quite possible that such precedents may cause difficulties in future.
('56', 137, 1, 18, 269635) But we may hope that, since our motives are sincere, we shall escape such difficulties.
('56', 137, 1, 19, 269723) He who has protected us up to now will protect us even in future.
('56', 137, 1, 20, 269789) We shall go on paying as long as we have money.
('56', 137, 1, 21, 269837) If we have brought His name into disrepute, He will deprive us even of what we have.
('56', 137, 1, 22, 269922) Whom will we pay then?
('56', 137, 1, 23, 269945) Sitala Sahay says in his letter that Padma has sent some accounts to you.
('56', 137, 1, 24, 270019) I suppose they are all right, are they?
('56', 137, 1, 25, 270059) I also assume that what Sitala Sahay writes about Prabhudas’s expenses is correct.
('56', 137, 1, 26, 270142) If, however, the facts are not as stated by him, it would certainly be necessary to think more about the matter.
('56', 137, 1, 27, 270255) My opinion, thus, is based on the assumption that the information given by Sitala Sahay in his letter is correct.
('56', 137, 1, 28, 270369) You do perfectly right in putting all the facts of a case before me.
('56', 137, 1, 29, 270438) I should go on giving my opinions as long as I can, so that your burden may be lighter.
('56', 137, 1, 30, 270526) Nimu has written a letter to Ramdas which he has sent to me.
('56', 137, 1, 31, 270587) She writes in it about having engaged a boy.
('56', 137, 1, 32, 270632) She believes that she needs his help, but suspects that you may not have approved of her action.
('56', 137, 1, 33, 270729) She also says that you have raised no objection Ramdas has left it to me to do what I think proper.
('56', 137, 1, 34, 270829) I cannot decide in this

('56', 138, 1, 5, 270990) Don’t wait for Nimu to speak to you, but go and meet her yourself and put her mind at rest.
('56', 138, 1, 6, 271082) If you can, do save Shashi, If necessary, you may speak firmly to Ratilal about him.

('56', 139, 1, 2, 273266) 166. LETTER TO NARAYAN M. KHARE
('56', 139, 2, 3, 273298) July 10, 1932
('56', 139, 3, 4, 273312) PANDITJI, I forgot to write about one thing in my letter 1 to you last week, namely, about the time spent in prayers.
('56', 139, 3, 5, 273430) One should not grudge it or feel bored.
('56', 139, 3, 6, 273470) Islam enjoins prayers five times a day, and every prayer lasts for not less than 15 minutes and the substance every time is the same.
('56', 139, 3, 7, 273604) In Christian prayers, one feature is constant, and that also generally takes 15 minutes every time.
('56', 139, 3, 8, 273704) In the Roman Catholic Church and the Established Church of England no prayer lasts for less than half an hour, and the prayers are held in the morning, in the evening and at noon.
('56', 139, 3, 9, 273884) Pious men and women do not feel this irksome.
('56', 139, 3, 10, 273930) In short, none of us has a right to change the established pattern of daily activities in the Ashram, for all of us are imperfect and we have discussed these things long enough.
('56', 139, 3, 11, 274108) We should now learn to take interest in our activities.
('56', 139, 3, 12, 274164) We wish to realize God through them and derive our daily sustenance from them.
('56', 139, 3, 13, 274243) Instead of thinking about making changes in our programme, we should carry it out as best as we can and instil life in our activities.
('56', 139, 3, 14, 274378) This is how I feel as I think more and more about the matter.
('56', 139, 5, 15, 274440) From a photostat of the Gujarati: C.W. 229. Courtesy: Lakshmibehn N. Khare

('56', 139, 7, 21, 274925) I therefore try to preserve my equanimity.
('56', 139, 7, 22, 274968) We may ask only for what we are entitled to.
('56', 139, 7, 23, 275013) If we get it, it is all right.
('56', 139, 7, 24, 275044) If we do not get it, then also it is all right.

('56', 141, 4, 8, 277349) 170. HISTORY OF THE SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM 1
('56', 141, 5, 9, 277389) [July 11, 1932]
('56', 141, 6, 10, 277405) INTRODUCTION Ashram here means a community of men of religion.
('56', 141, 6, 11, 277468) Looking at the past in the light of the present, I feel that an ashram was a necessary of life for me.
('56', 141, 6, 12, 277571) As soon as I had a house of my own, my house was an ashram in this sense, for my life as a householder was not one of enjoyment but of duty discharged from day to day.
('56', 141, 6, 13, 277739) Again, besides the members of my family I always had some friends or
('56', 141, 7, 14, 277808) 1 Gandhiji commenced writing this history in Gujarati in Yeravda Central Prison on April 5, 1932. He worked on it intermittently and wrote the last available instalment on July 11, 1932, though later letters show that the writing continued even after this date.
('56', 141, 7, 15, 278070) On his release, he showed the manuscripts to Kakasaheb Kalelkar and said: “I could not complete this job.
('56', 141, 7, 16, 278176) It badly needs revision.
('56', 141, 7, 17, 278201) I do not know whether I shall ever complete it.
('56', 141, 7, 18, 278249) It is not fit to be published as it is.
('56', 141, 7, 19, 278289) I shall give it only when I have revised it.” Kakasaheb said that he would have copies made of whatever had been written and took the manuscripts from Gandhiji’s hands.
('56', 141, 7, 20, 278458) Since the original could not be traced, Navajivan Publishing House issued Satyagrahashramno Itihas in Gujarati in May 1948 from the copy available with Kakasaheb.
('56', 141, 7, 21, 278621) It was translated into English by Valji G. Desai and published by the Navajivan Publishing House under the title Ashram Observances in Action in 1955. The translator has occasionally changed the paragraphing, omitted a sentence or summarized an argument, but otherwise the translation is faithful and is reproduced here.
('56', 141, 7, 22, 278942) Two paragraphs of the incomplete chapter on satyagraha, which were written on July 11, 1932 and which were omitted in the English version, have been translated from the Gujarati.
('56', 141, 7, 23, 279121) Appendices found in Gujarati and English versions are not reproduced here, since they are placed in their chronological order under the dates February 16, 1916, June 14, 1928 and December 8, 1941. For the first two appendices, vide “Speech on Ashram Vows at Y. M. C. A., Madras”, 16 2 1916 and “Satyagraha ashram”, 14 6 1928.
('56', 142, 0, 1, 279447) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4 SEPTEMBER, 1932 143
('56', 142, 1, 2, 279493) others living with me, whose relation with me was spiritual from the first or became such later on.
('56', 142, 1, 3, 279593) This went on unconsciously till 1904 when I read Ruskin’s Unto This Last, 1 which made a deep impression on me.
('56', 142, 1, 4, 279705) I determined to take Indian Opinion into a forest where I should live with the workers as members of my family.
('56', 142, 1, 5, 279817) I purchased 100 acres of land and founded Phoenix Settlement, which neither we nor anyone else called an ashram.
('56', 142, 1, 6, 279930) It had a religious basis, but the visible object was purity of body and mind as well as economic equality.
('56', 142, 1, 7, 280037) I did not then consider brahmacharya (chastity) to be essential; on the other hand it was expected that co workers would live as family men and have children.
('56', 142, 1, 8, 280196) A brief account of Phoenix will be found in Satyagraha in South Africa.
('56', 142, 1, 9, 280268) This was the first step.
('56', 142, 1, 10, 280293) The second step was taken in 1906. I learnt in the school of experience that brahmacharya was a sine qua non for a life devoted to service.
('56', 142, 1, 11, 280433) From this time onward I looked upon Phoenix deliberately as a religious institution.
('56', 142, 1, 12, 280518) The same year witnessed the advent of satyagraha which was based on religion and implied an unshakable faith in the God of Truth.
('56', 142, 1, 13, 280648) Religion here should not be understood in a narrow sense, but as that which acts as a link between different religions and realizes their essential unity.
('56', 142, 2, 14, 280803) This went on till 1911. All these years the Phoenix Settlement was progressing as an ashram though we did not call it by that name.
('56', 142, 2, 15, 280935) We took the third step in 1911. So far only those people lived at Phoenix who were working in the press and the paper.
('56', 142, 2, 16, 281054) But now as a part of the satyagraha movement we felt the need of an ashram where satyagrahi families could live and lead a religious life.
('56', 142, 2, 17, 281193) I had already come in contact with my German friend Kallenbach.
('56', 142, 2, 18, 281257) Both of us were living a sort of ashram life.
('56', 142, 2, 19, 281303) I was a barrister and Kallenbach an architect.
('56', 142, 2, 20, 281350) However we led a comparatively very simple life in the sparsely populated country, and were religiously minded.
('56', 142, 2, 21, 281462) We might commit mistakes out of ignorance, but we were trying to seek the root of every activity in religion.
('56', 142, 2, 22, 281572) Kallenbach purchased a farm of 1,100 acres and the satyagrahi families settled there.
('56', 142, 2, 23, 281658) Religious problems confronted us now at every step and the whole institution was managed from a religious standpoint.
('56', 142, 2, 24, 281776) Among the settlers there were Hindus, Mussalmans, Christians and Parsis.
('56', 142, 2, 25, 281849) But I do not remember
('56', 142, 3, 26, 281871) 1 Vide “An Autobiography”..
('56', 143, 0, 1, 281899) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 144
('56', 143, 1, 2, 281941) that they ever quarrelled with one another, though each was staunch in his own faith.
('56', 143, 1, 3, 282027) We respected one another’s religion and tried to help everybody to follow his own faith and thus to make spiritual progress.
('56', 143, 1, 4, 282152) This institution was not known as Satyagraha Ashram but as Tolstoy Farm.
('56', 143, 1, 5, 282225) Kallenbach and I were followers of Tolstoy and endeavoured to practise much of his doctrine.
('56', 143, 1, 6, 282318) Tolstoy Farm was closed in 1912 and the farmers were sent to Phoenix.
('56', 143, 1, 7, 282388) The history of Tolstoy Farm will also be found in Satyagraha in South Africa.
('56', 143, 2, 8, 282466) Phoenix now was no longer meant for the workers of Indian Opinion only; it was a satyagraha institution.
('56', 143, 2, 9, 282571) That was only to be expected, for Indian Opinion owed its very existence to satyagraha.
('56', 143, 2, 10, 282659) Still it was a great change.

('56', 146, 3, 21, 291028) TRUTH Whenever someone was found telling a lie in the Ashram, effective steps were taken to deal with the situation as symptomatic of a serious disease.
('56', 146, 3, 22, 291181) The Ashram does not believe in punishing wrongdoers, so much so that hesitation is felt even in asking them to leave the institution.
('56', 146, 3, 23, 291315) Three lines of preventive action were therefore adopted.
('56', 146, 3, 24, 291372) The first thing attended to was the purity of the principal workers in charge, the idea being that if they were free from fault, the atmosphere about them was bound to be affected by their innocence.
('56', 146, 3, 25, 291572) Untruth cannot stand before truth like darkness before the light of the sun.
('56', 146, 4, 26, 291649) 1 Vide “An autobiography”.
('56', 147, 0, 1, 291676) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 148
('56', 147, 1, 2, 291718) Secondly, we had recourse to confession.
('56', 147, 1, 3, 291759) If someone was found practising untruth, the fact was brought to the notice of the congrega tion.
('56', 147, 1, 4, 291857) This is a very useful measure if it is judiciously adopted.
('56', 147, 1, 5, 291917) But one has to be careful about two things.
('56', 147, 1, 6, 291961) The public confession must not be tainted by even a trace of force; and the confession should not lead to the person confessing taking leave of all sense of shame.
('56', 147, 1, 7, 292125) If he comes to believe that mere confession has washed off his sin, he is no longer ashamed of it at all.
('56', 147, 1, 8, 292231) There should be an ever present consciousness of the fact that the least little untruth is a dangerous thing.
('56', 147, 1, 9, 292341) Thirdly, the worker in charge of the Ashram as well as the wrongdoer would fast as a matter of penance.
('56', 147, 1, 10, 292445) Of course it is a matter for the wrongdoer himself to decide whether or not he should undertake a fast.
('56', 147, 1, 11, 292549) But as for the worker in charge, he is clearly responsible for intentional and unintentional wrongdoing in his institution.
('56', 147, 1, 12, 292673) Untruth is more poisonous and more subtle than any poison gas whatever, but it dare not enter where the head of the institution is wide awake and has a spiritual outlook on life.
('56', 147, 1, 13, 292852) Still if it is found to have effected an entrance, it is a warning to the principal worker, who may be sure that he must bear his share of responsibility for this infection.
('56', 147, 1, 14, 293026) I for one believe that spiritual acts have clearly defined results precisely like combinations or processes in the natural sciences.
('56', 147, 1, 15, 293159) Only as we have no such means of measurement in the former case as in the latter, we are not ready to believe or we only half heartedly believe in the spiritual influences.
('56', 147, 1, 16, 293332) Again, we are inclined to be lenient to ourselves with the result that our experiments are unsuccessful and we tend to move only in a circle like the oil miller’s bullock.

('56', 148, 1, 2, 294447) What then is the remedy to be tried to get rid of untruth?
('56', 148, 1, 3, 294506) The only answer which suggests itself to me is bodily penance, that is fasting and the like.
('56', 148, 1, 4, 294599) Bodily penance has a threefold influence, first over the penitent, secondly over the wrongdoer and thirdly over the congregation.
('56', 148, 1, 5, 294729) The penitent becomes more alert, examines the innermost recesses of his own heart and takes steps to deal with any personal weakness that he may discover.
('56', 148, 1, 6, 294884) If the wrongdoer has any pity, he becomes conscious of his own fault, is ashamed of it and resolves never to sin any more in the future.

('56', 148, 1, 10, 295206) It is profitable only if it is accompanied by a certain line of thinking, which is as follows: Man tends to become a slave of his own body, and engages in many activities and commits many sins for the sake of physical enjoyment.
('56', 148, 1, 11, 295435) He should therefore mortify the flesh whenever there is an occasion of sin.
('56', 148, 1, 12, 295511) A man given to physical enjoyment is subject to delusion.

('56', 148, 1, 15, 295879) Merely giving up food does not amount to a fast.

('56', 149, 1, 24, 299149) Penance for another’s wrong doing presupposes purity; and if the guilty man has no respect

('56', 151, 1, 7, 302411) II PRAYER (i) If insistence on truth constitutes the root of the Ashram, prayer is the principal feeder of that root.
('56', 151, 1, 8, 302529) The social (as distinguished from the individual) activities of the Ashram commence every day with the congregational morning worship at 4.15 to 4.45 a.m.
('56', 151, 1, 9, 302684) and close with the evening prayer at 7 to 7.30 p.m.
('56', 151, 1, 10, 302736) Ever since the Ashram was founded, not a single day has passed to my knowledge without this worship.
('56', 151, 1, 11, 302837) I know of several occasions when owing to the rains only one responsible person was present on the prayer ground.
('56', 151, 1, 12, 302951) All inmates are expected to attend the worship except in the case of illness or similar compelling reason for absence.
('56', 151, 1, 13, 303070) This expectation has been fairly well fulfilled at the evening prayer, but not in the morning.
('56', 151, 1, 14, 303165) The time for morning worship was as a matter of experiment fixed at 4, 5, 6 and 7 a.m., one after another.
('56', 151, 1, 15, 303272) But on account of my persistently strong attitude on the subject, it has been fixed at last at 4.20 a.m.
('56', 151, 1, 16, 303377) With the first bell at 4 everyone rises from bed and after a wash reaches the prayer ground by 4.20. I believe that in a country like India the sooner a man rises from bed the better.
('56', 151, 1, 17, 303561) Indeed millions must necessarily rise early.
('56', 151, 1, 18, 303606) If the peasant is a late riser, his crops will suffer damage.
('56', 151, 1, 19, 303668) Cattle are attended to and cows are milked early in the morning.

('56', 151, 1, 21, 303877) In all countries of the world devotees of God and tillers of the soil rise early.
('56', 151, 1, 22, 303959) Devotees take the name of God and peasants work in their fields serving the world as well as themselves.
('56', 152, 0, 1, 304064) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4 SEPTEMBER, 1932 153
('56', 152, 1, 2, 304110) mind both are worshippers.

('56', 163, 1, 2, 331629) IV BRAHMACHARYA OR CHASTITY This observance does not give rise to ever so many problems and dilemmas as ahimsa does.
('56', 163, 1, 3, 331746) Its meaning is generally well understood; but understanding it is one thing, practising it is quite another thing and calls forth all our powers.
('56', 163, 1, 4, 331892) Many of us put forth a great effort but without making any progress.
('56', 163, 1, 5, 331961) Some of us even lost ground previously won.
('56', 163, 1, 6, 332005) None has reached perfection.

('56', 163, 1, 9, 332149) There were many ups and downs.

('56', 163, 1, 12, 332422) Even in the case of a simple machine like the spinning wheel, it is one thing to read the directions for plying it, and it is another thing to put the directions into practice.
('56', 163, 1, 13, 332599) New light dawns upon us as soon as we commence our practice.

('56', 163, 1, 15, 332758) A brahmachari is one who controls his organs of sense in thought, word and deed.

('56', 167, 2, 7, 342520) V NON STEALING AND NON POSSESSION OR POVERTY These two, along with truth, ahimsa and brahmacharya that have gone before, constitute the five mahavratas (primary observances) of old and have been included in the Ashram observances as they are necessary for one who seeks self realization.
('56', 167, 2, 8, 342808) But they do not call for any lengthy discussion.
('56', 167, 3, 9, 342857) 1. NON STEALING To take something from another without his permission is theft of course.
('56', 167, 3, 10, 342947) But it is also theft to use a thing for a purpose different from the one intended by the lender or to use it for a period longer than that which has been fixed with him.
('56', 167, 3, 11, 343117) The profound truth upon which this observance is based is that God never creates more than what is strictly needed for the moment.
('56', 167, 3, 12, 343248) Therefore whoever appropriates more than the minimum that is really necessary for him is guilty of theft.
('56', 167, 3, 13, 343354) 2. NON POSSESSION OR POVERTY This is covered by Non stealing.
('56', 167, 3, 14, 343416) We may neither take nor keep a superfluous thing.
('56', 167, 3, 15, 343466) It is therefore a breach of this observance to possess food or furniture which we do not really need.
('56', 167, 3, 16, 343568) He who can do without chairs will not keep them in his house.
('56', 167, 3, 17, 343630) The seeker will deliberately and voluntarily reduce his wants and cultivate progre ssively simple habits.
('56', 167, 3, 18, 343736) Non stealing and Non possession are mental states only.

('56', 168, 3, 19, 345643) BREAD LABOUR The Ashram holds that every man and woman must work in order to live.
('56', 168, 3, 20, 345726) This principle came home to me upon reading one of Tolstoy’s essays.
('56', 168, 3, 21, 345795) Referring to the Russian writer Bondareff, Tolstoy observes that his discovery of the vital importance of bread labour is one of the most remarkable discoveries of modern times.
('56', 168, 3, 22, 345973) The idea is that every healthy individual must labour enough for his food, and his intellectual faculties must be exercised not in order to obtain a living or amass a fortune but only in the service of mankind.
('56', 168, 3, 23, 346184) If this principle is observed everywhere, all men would be equal, none would starve and the world would be saved from many a sin.
('56', 168, 3, 24, 346314) It is possible that this golden rule will never be observed by the whole world.
('56', 168, 3, 25, 346394) Millions observe it in spite of themselves without understanding it.
('56', 168, 3, 26, 346463) But their mind is working in a contrary direction, so
('56', 169, 0, 1, 346517) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 170
('56', 169, 1, 2, 346559) that they are unhappy themselves and their labour is not as fruitful as it should be.
('56', 169, 1, 3, 346645) This state of things serves as an incentive to those who understand and seek to practise the rule.
('56', 169, 1, 4, 346744) By rendering a willing obedience to it they enjoy good health as well as perfect peace and develop their capacity for service.
('56', 169, 1, 5, 346871) Tolstoy made a deep impression on my mind, and even in South Africa I began to observe the rule to the best of my ability.
('56', 169, 1, 6, 346994) And ever since the Ashram was founded, bread labour has been perhaps its most characteristic feature.
('56', 169, 1, 7, 347096) In my opinion the same principle has been set forth in the third chapter of the Gita.

('56', 186, 1, 14, 389763) This cannot be done by force.
('56', 186, 1, 15, 389793) But Hindu society should keep the cow, treat her and her progeny well so long as they are alive, cherish them in their old age, and fully utilize their carcases when they are dead.
('56', 186, 1, 16, 389974) Thus alone can the cow be saved, and in saving her we shall perhaps learn how to save the rest of the sub human creation.
('56', 186, 1, 17, 390096) Thanks to our ignorance, laziness and hatred, the cow today is hastening to her destruction.
('56', 186, 1, 18, 390189) As for the other cattle, the less said about them the better.
('56', 186, 1, 19, 390251) The Ashram suggests that all goshalas and pinjrapoles should be organized religiously and scientifically.

('56', 186, 1, 21, 390443) Trading in cow’s milk should be looked upon as a sin, and the well to do should manage public goshalas so as to make both ends meet.
('56', 186, 1, 22, 390576) The cow would then soon be saved.
('56', 186, 1, 23, 390610) The Ashram at present has a limited object in view: to conduct a model goshala at the Ashram, to breed good cows and bullocks, to utilize their carcases fully when they are dead so as to show that cow keeping is an economic proposition, to train workers and provide for their employment upon the completion of their training.
('56', 186, 1, 24, 390936) This work is going on at present.
('56', 186, 1, 25, 390970) There are many difficulties, but we are fully confident of success.
('56', 186, 2, 26, 391038) EDUCATION The word is here used in a special as well as the current sense.
('56', 186, 2, 27, 391113) The Ashram experiment in education was a trial for us as
('56', 187, 0, 1, 391170) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 188
('56', 187, 1, 2, 391212) nothing else was.
('56', 187, 1, 3, 391230) We saw at once that the women and children in the Ashram should be taught to read and write, and a little later on that there should be similar facilities for even the illiterate men that came to the Ashram.
('56', 187, 1, 4, 391438) Those who had already joined the Ashram could not undertake to teach.
('56', 187, 1, 5, 391508) If capable teachers were to be attracted to the Ashram, the rule of brahmacharya had to be relaxed in their case.

('56', 187, 1, 21, 393208) I have my own perhaps peculiar views on education which have not been accepted by my colleagues in full, and here they are: 1. Young boys and girls should have co education till they are eight years of age.
('56', 187, 1, 22, 393415) 2. Their education should mainly consist in manual training under the supervision of an educationist.

('56', 200, 7, 14, 417083) 181. INDIVIDUAL PRAYER
('56', 200, 8, 15, 417106) July 17, 1932 Though I have already written once on this subject, 3 I feel that I should again write something about its importance.
('56', 200, 8, 16, 417239) It seems to me that one reason why people feel no interest in community prayers may be that they do not realize the necessity of individual prayer.
('56', 200, 8, 17, 417387) The idea of community prayers arose from the individual’s need for prayer.
('56', 200, 8, 18, 417462) If individuals do not feel such a need, how can a community?
('56', 200, 8, 19, 417523) Community prayers also are for the benefit of individuals.
('56', 200, 8, 20, 417582) They help people in their effort to attain knowledge of the self—for self purification; It is, therefore, necessary that all of us should understand the importance of individual prayer, As soon as a child learns to understand things, its mother ought to teach it to pray.
('56', 200, 8, 21, 417854) This practice is common to all religions.
('56', 200, 8, 22, 417896) There are at least two clear times for such prayer, that is, we should turn our mind to the Lord within immediately on awakening in the morning and when closing our eyes for sleep in the evening.
('56', 200, 8, 23, 418092) During the rest of the day, every man and woman who is spiritually awake will think of God when doing anything and do that with Him as witness.
('56', 200, 8, 24, 418236) Such a person will never do anything evil, and a time will
('56', 200, 9, 25, 418295) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('56', 200, 9, 26, 418322) 2 Vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 16 7 1932. 3 Vide “Prayer”, 19 7 1932.
('56', 201, 0, 1, 418397) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 202
('56', 201, 1, 2, 418439) come when he or she will think every thought with God as witness and as its Master.
('56', 201, 1, 3, 418523) This will be a state in which one will have reduced oneself to a cipher.
('56', 201, 1, 4, 418596) Such a person, who lives constantly in the sight of God, will every moment feel Rama dwelling in his heart.
('56', 201, 1, 5, 418704) For such prayers, no special mantra or bhajan is necessary.
('56', 201, 1, 6, 418764) Though generally a mantra is recited at the commencement and conclusion of every religious act, that is not at all necessary.
('56', 201, 1, 7, 418890) We have only to turn our thoughts to God, no matter by what name we call Him, by what method and in what condition.
('56', 201, 1, 8, 419006) Very few form such a habit.
('56', 201, 1, 9, 419034) If most people followed this practice, there would be less sin and evil in this world and our dealings with one another would be pure.
('56', 201, 1, 10, 419169) In order that we may attain such a pure state, everybody should pray at least at the two times which I have mentioned.
('56', 201, 1, 11, 419288) Each person may fix other hours, too, according to his convenience, and gradually increase their frequency so that, ultimately his every breath will be accompanied with Ramanama.
('56', 201, 1, 12, 419467) Such individual prayer consumes no time at all.
('56', 201, 1, 13, 419515) It requires not time but wakefulness.
('56', 201, 1, 14, 419553) As we don’t feel that the unceasing action of blinking consumes any time, so also we do not feel that praying inwardly does.
('56', 201, 1, 15, 419678) But we are aware that the eye lids are doing their work; similarly prayer should go on constantly in our heart.
('56', 201, 1, 16, 419790) Anybody who wishes to pray in this manner should know that he cannot do with an impure heart.
('56', 201, 1, 17, 419884) He must, therefore, banish all impurity from his heart when praying.
('56', 201, 1, 18, 419953) As one feels ashamed of doing anything wicked when being observed by somebody, so also should one feel ashamed of acting similarly in the sight of God.
('56', 201, 1, 19, 420105) But God watches every action and knows every thought of ours.
('56', 201, 1, 20, 420167) Hence there can be no moment when we can do anything or think any thought unobserved by Him.
('56', 201, 1, 21, 420260) Thus, anybody who prays to God with his heart will in the end become filled with Him and so become sinless.

('56', 203, 1, 24, 423394) We can certainly pray for some person or with a material aim, and such prayer may even be rewarded.

('56', 203, 1, 33, 424117) Prayers remove that obstacle.

('56', 203, 1, 35, 424240) If I pray for Narmada to be delivered from her suffering and if she becomes free from it, I should not assume that that was the result of my prayer.
('56', 203, 1, 36, 424389) Such prayer is never in vain, but we do not know how it bears fruit.

('56', 203, 1, 39, 424644) Prayers should be offered in a spirit of non attachment.
('56', 203, 1, 40, 424701) Even when we have prayed for some person, we can
('56', 204, 0, 1, 424750) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4 SEPTEMBER, 1932 205
('56', 204, 1, 2, 424796) remain, unconcerned with the result.
('56', 204, 1, 3, 424833) We may pray for a person to be delivered from his suffering because we think that is for his good, but we should remain unconcerned whether or not he becomes free.
('56', 204, 1, 4, 424997) Because the effect is the opposite of what we had prayed for, we need not believe that our prayers have not been answered.

('56', 213, 1, 2, 440209) 197. LETTER TO ESTHER MENON
('56', 213, 2, 3, 440237) July 18, 1932
('56', 213, 3, 4, 440251) MY DEAR CHILD, I have your letter.
('56', 213, 3, 5, 440286) Do not fret, if you don’t hear from me at the expected moment.
('56', 213, 3, 6, 440349) My correspondence has been upset a bit.
('56', 213, 3, 7, 440389) I am hoping that the matter will be soon put right.
('56', 213, 3, 8, 440441) However, a prisoner has got to be satisfied with facilities that may be given to him for the natural satisfaction of his healthy wants.
('56', 213, 3, 9, 440577) When you see the invalid sister, you must tell her I often think of her.
('56', 213, 3, 10, 440650) I wonder if you ever visit that little school 1 in your neighbourhood for defective children.
('56', 213, 3, 11, 440744) I thought the institution had earnest workers.
('56', 213, 3, 12, 440791) If you have the time, I would like you to know more of the institution and its managers and tell me how it progresses.
('56', 213, 3, 13, 440910) You tell me how desolate Bajaj’s house looked for want of the woman’s touch.
('56', 213, 3, 14, 440987) I have always considered this a result of our false notions of division of work between men and women.
('56', 213, 3, 15, 441090) Division there must be.
('56', 213, 3, 16, 441114) But this utter helplessness on the man’s part when it comes to keeping a household in good order and woman’s helplessness when it comes to be a matter of looking after herself (more here than in the West) are due to erroneous upbringing.
('56', 213, 3, 17, 441352) Why should man be so lazy as not to keep his house neat, if there is no woman looking after it, or why should a woman feel that she always needs a man protector?
('56', 213, 3, 18, 441514) This anomaly seems to me to be due to the habit of regarding woman as fit primarily for housekeeping and of thinking that she must live so soft as to feel weak and be always in need of protection.
('56', 213, 3, 19, 441711) We are trying to create a different atmosphere at the Ashram.
('56', 213, 3, 20, 441773) It is difficult work.
('56', 213, 3, 21, 441795) But it seems to be worth doing.
('56', 213, 3, 22, 441827) Remember me and Mahadev to Mrs. Winston when you write to her.
('56', 213, 3, 23, 441890) Kisses to the children.

('56', 216, 5, 6, 444962) 202. LETTER TO S. D. SATAVLEKAR
('56', 216, 6, 7, 444994) July 19, 1932
('56', 216, 7, 8, 445008) BHAI SATAVLEKAR, I got your letter only today.
('56', 216, 7, 9, 445055) The Sanskrit Readers came earlier but I was awaiting your letter.
('56', 216, 7, 10, 445121) May I thank you for the Readers?
('56', 216, 7, 11, 445154) I have received so many books from you !
('56', 216, 7, 12, 445195) Purushartha and other things keep coming.
('56', 216, 7, 13, 445237) You will be gratified to learn that Sardar has completed the first two Readers and has gone on to the third.
('56', 216, 7, 14, 445346) We are jotting down the errors that come to our notice.
('56', 216, 7, 15, 445402) We had already decided to inform you of them even before the receipt of your letter.
('56', 216, 7, 16, 445487) There is no doubt that on the whole the Readers are very well planned.
('56', 216, 7, 17, 445558) Whatever mistakes we observe will be pointed out to you only with the purpose of enhancing the utility of the series.
('56', 216, 7, 18, 445676) My arm does not give too much pain.
('56', 216, 7, 19, 445712) The left elbow pains only with a particular movement.
('56', 216, 7, 20, 445766) The Superintendent gave me Lakshadi oil to be used for massage but it did no good.
('56', 216, 7, 21, 445849) In fact, this oil helps only when the pain is caused by rheumatism but the pain in my elbow joint is not reheumatic.
('56', 216, 7, 22, 445966) So far the doctors have diagnosed it as the result of constant employment of the elbow in plying the charkha.
('56', 216, 7, 23, 446076) For that reason I have given up using the left arm in spinning for almost a month.
('56', 216, 7, 24, 446159) It cannot be said that it has resulted in any improvement.
('56', 216, 7, 25, 446218) So now I am to undergo intensive treatment.
('56', 216, 7, 26, 446262) There is no cause for worry; my health is, on the whole, good enough.
('56', 216, 7, 27, 446332) What you have written about Vishwaroopadarshanayoga 1 is quite correct, but it does not in any way contradict what I have written
('56', 216, 8, 28, 446462) 1 “Yoga of the Vision of the Cosmic Form” in the Gita; the addressee had said in his letter that there was not only poetry in Chapter XI of the Gita as Gandhiji had made out, but also the vital truth that God is immanent in all created objects which are only different parts of His body.
('56', 217, 0, 1, 446750) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 218
('56', 217, 1, 2, 446792) in the preface 1 to that chapter.
('56', 217, 1, 3, 446826) The man who sees the whole world as a manifestation of Vasudeva is bound to have a vision of the Cosmic Form but the Form will be that of his own imagining.
('56', 217, 1, 4, 446983) A Christian who considers the creation as a divine manifestation will visualize an image to suit his notions.
('56', 217, 1, 5, 447093) Our way of worship determines the form of God in our mind.
('56', 217, 1, 6, 447152) One born and bred in the Hindu culture will never tire of reading the eleventh chapter and if he be a devotee, he will be able to picture to himself the magnificent form described therein.
('56', 217, 1, 7, 447341) Such imagery is not beyond a man’s imagination in this world.
('56', 217, 1, 8, 447403) We may call the divine force as Brahman, Atman or Vasudeva, yet it remains formless.
('56', 217, 1, 9, 447488) Only for the devotee it acquires dimensions; that is its expression and therein lies its poetic appeal.
('56', 217, 1, 10, 447592) We can make only one deduction which you have already drawn.
('56', 217, 1, 11, 447653) We must be able to see Vasudeva or God even in a dacoit.
('56', 217, 1, 12, 447710) When we have acquired the strength to do that, the dacoit will give up his wickedness.
('56', 217, 1, 13, 447797) And until we acquire this power all our learning and knowledge is worthless.
('56', 217, 1, 14, 447874) You have not expected my comments upon your writing on Vishwaroopadarshana, yet I have written all this as I am engrossed with the same thoughts.
('56', 217, 1, 15, 448020) It gives me great pleasure to carry on such conversations with you through letters.
('56', 217, 1, 16, 448104) I have finished reading ‘Vaidik Vinay’ by Abhayji.
('56', 217, 1, 17, 448155) Now I am reading Swadhyaya Samhita by Vaidikmuni Hariprasadji.
('56', 217, 1, 18, 448218) But I find great difficulty in reading the Vedic hymns.
('56', 217, 1, 19, 448274) You are acquainted with my knowledge of Sanskrit, it is of the most elementary order, and as regards Vedic Sanskrit it is almost nil.
('56', 217, 1, 20, 448408) I know this much, that vedic hymns have been interpreted in several ways by different scholars— by Sanatanis in one way, by Arya Samajists in another and by Western scholars in yet another.
('56', 217, 1, 21, 448598) Even among the sanatanis I find difference of opinion.
('56', 217, 1, 22, 448653) All Arya Samajists too are not agreed upon the same meaning.
('56', 217, 1, 23, 448714) You must be remembering the correspondence between yourself and Vaidyaji that I initiated.
('56', 217, 1, 24, 448805) 2 In the light of all this I feel bewildered when I try to study the Vedic hymns and find myself at a loss to decide upon any interpretation.
('56', 217, 1, 25, 448947) At present I am memorizing Ishopanishad.
('56', 217, 1, 26, 448988) I think Shankara’s interpretation of it differs from that of Aurobindo Babu; and your interpretation that I saw last year while in jail differs from both.
('56', 217, 1, 27, 449143) I have now received a translation in Gujarati.
('56', 217, 1, 28, 449190) This and Hariprasadji’s translation are again at variance.

('56', 218, 4, 14, 450363) 203. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('56', 218, 5, 15, 450394) July 20, 1932
('56', 218, 6, 16, 450408) NARANDAS, Your letter, posted on the 18th, reached me on the 20th.
('56', 218, 6, 17, 450475) But I don’t know what will happen to mine.
('56', 218, 6, 18, 450518) The officials here tell me that the packet which I had handed over on the 4th was dispatched on the 16th.
('56', 218, 6, 19, 450624) All the letters are sent to the Secretariat for censoring, and are posted when received back here after being passed.
('56', 218, 6, 20, 450742) I simply cannot understand why they should do this.
('56', 218, 6, 21, 450794) I have been trying to find out, of course.
('56', 218, 6, 22, 450837) I don’t know if I shall succeed.
('56', 218, 6, 23, 450870) We should go on writing to each other as usual and not worry when the letters will reach their destination.
('56', 218, 6, 24, 450978) We should not think about the matter at all.
('56', 218, 6, 25, 451023) We should be ready in our minds to face the possibility of the correspondence stopping altogether and be sure that we shall not feel upset even then.
('56', 218, 6, 26, 451173) Ask Prabhudas to write to me.
('56', 218, 6, 27, 451203) Two days ago the doctor permitted me to rotate the Gandiva wheel with the left hand, and so I have started spinning on the Gandiva.
('56', 218, 6, 28, 451335) I appreciate it all the more after my experience with the Magan spinning wheel.
('56', 218, 6, 29, 451415) My yarn became fine immediately and the threads also snapped rarely.
('56', 218, 6, 30, 451484) I still draw the thread with the right hand.
('56', 218, 6, 31, 451529) There are some defects in the spinning wheel, and when I have removed them it will work still more smoothly.
('56', 219, 0, 1, 451638) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 220
('56', 219, 1, 2, 451680) Comparing it with the Magan spinning wheel, I see that I cannot acquire speed on the latter.
('56', 219, 1, 3, 451773) Hence I think that for spinning with one spindle only, the Gandiva or the ordinary spinning wheel is better.
('56', 219, 1, 4, 451882) For anybody who cannot use either of his hands for drawing the thread or for rotating the wheel, the Magan spinning wheel is an invaluable invention.
('56', 219, 1, 5, 452032) Obviously, anyone who can use both his hands can spin more.
('56', 219, 1, 6, 452092) But we cannot spin yarn of the highest count on it.
('56', 219, 1, 7, 452144) A few changes may perhaps help us to do it.
('56', 219, 1, 8, 452188) It is also possible that our speed on it may increase if we make some modificatons so that we can spin on it with one spindle only.
('56', 219, 1, 9, 452320) But all this requires experimentation.
('56', 219, 1, 10, 452359) My experience of it in its present form is what I have described it to be.
('56', 219, 1, 11, 452434) I can say that I have now acquired excellent control over the pedals.
('56', 219, 1, 12, 452504) I have been permitted to spin on the Gandiva wheel not because there is any improvement in the condition of my elbow but because complete rest has not benefited it in any way.
('56', 219, 1, 13, 452680) The assumption behind this is that the pain may not have been caused by the strain of [rotating] the wheel when spinning.
('56', 219, 1, 14, 452802) I shall know for certain in a few days.
('56', 219, 1, 15, 452842) I am happy that Dr. Talwalkar charges two rupees for conveyance and gives a bill for the medicines.
('56', 219, 1, 16, 452942) If we call him only once or twice in a year, he can afford to charge us nothing, but he cannot afford to do so when he gives us medicines as frequently as he does.
('56', 219, 1, 17, 453106) He is not so rich.
('56', 219, 1, 18, 453125) As for conveyance, I think we have been paying it for a long time.
('56', 219, 1, 19, 453192) Dr. Talwalkar’s sending us bills for medicines is likely to have one result.
('56', 219, 1, 20, 453269) Through laxity we may have been calling him during all this time even when it might not be necessary.
('56', 219, 1, 21, 453371) If that is so, our laxity should go now.In any case, if we are scrupulous in following dharma, we should feel extremely reluctant to accept anybody’s free services.
('56', 219, 1, 22, 453536) But most people certainly do not behave in that way.
('56', 219, 1, 23, 453589) Because water costs nothing, we use it freely and do not feel ashamed in doing so.
('56', 219, 1, 24, 453672) On the contrary, we ask why we should not use it freely when it costs nothing.
('56', 219, 1, 25, 453751) And as we are careless about using water because it costs nothing, we feel in the same way about other services or things which we get free.
('56', 219, 1, 26, 453892) This is a violation of our vow of nonstealing, besides being a violation of the vow of ahimsa too.

('56', 223, 4, 12, 460271) 207. LETTER TO SONIRAMJI
('56', 223, 5, 13, 460296) July 21, 1932 1
('56', 223, 6, 14, 460312) BROTHER SONIRAMJI, 2
('56', 223, 7, 15, 460333) I am in receipt of your letter.
('56', 223, 7, 16, 460365) 3 I have heard many interpretations of the occult significance of the sacred thread.
('56', 223, 7, 17, 460450) But all these interpretations are only guesses.
('56', 223, 7, 18, 460498) I do not think that all these ideas were present at the time when the sacred thread came into use.
('56', 223, 7, 19, 460597) Those people who described themselves as Aryans adopted the use of the sacred thread in order to distinguish between Aryans and non Aryans.
('56', 223, 7, 20, 460737) This must have happened at the time when the art of making cloth from cotton was discovered.
('56', 223, 7, 21, 460830) Crores of people merely put on the dhoti then, as they do even now, with the rest of the body uncovered.
('56', 223, 7, 22, 460935) In any case those who are believed to be non Aryans did so.
('56', 223, 7, 23, 460995) The Aryans, therefore, adopted the symbol of the sacred thread in order to encourage and improve the art of spinning and prove that it was sacred work.
('56', 223, 7, 24, 461147) I have no evidence from history in support of this statement.
('56', 223, 7, 25, 461209) It is only my conjecture.
('56', 223, 7, 26, 461235) Today there is no distinction— and there ought not to be any—between Aryans and non Aryans.
('56', 223, 7, 27, 461327) An admixture of blood between the races took place thousands of years

('56', 224, 1, 2, 461515) ago and the present inhabitants of India are the progeny of such an admixture.
('56', 224, 1, 3, 461594) If the sacred thread is to be worn to all, all [the castes] should have the right to wear it.
('56', 224, 1, 4, 461688) I see no meaning in such a movement.
('56', 224, 1, 5, 461725) For this reason, after giving up the use of the sacred thread I never tried to wear it again nor do I wish to do so.
('56', 224, 1, 6, 461842) Inasmuch as the practice of wearing the sacred thread is likely to have created the distinction between higher and lower castes, it should be discarded.
('56', 224, 1, 7, 461995) I would advise Gauri Prasad to give up his infatuation for the sacred thread.
('56', 224, 1, 8, 462073) It is the sign of a brahmachari.
('56', 224, 1, 9, 462106) If a person observes brahmacharya that itself is the best sacred thread.
('56', 224, 1, 10, 462179) Why is a cotton thread needed?
('56', 224, 2, 11, 462210) To keep the water in a well clean it should be covered with a wire netting.

('56', 225, 9, 23, 464734) Without pravritti there is no occasion for treading or not treading the path of truth.

('56', 231, 1, 4, 474804) I am familiar with Bhai Hiralal’s ideas.
('56', 231, 1, 5, 474845) I have read all the articles he sent me.

('56', 231, 1, 8, 474957) Looking at the sky the impression we get of infinity, of purity, of order and of grandeur is one that purifies us.

('56', 231, 1, 10, 475223) But truly divine is the peaceful influence of their beauty and coolness at this great distance.
('56', 231, 1, 11, 475319) Also when once we are able to establish communion with the heavens it does not matter where we may happen to be.

('56', 232, 1, 10, 477656) But even then, the thread is finer than the one I could draw on the Magan wheel.

('56', 232, 1, 12, 477852) I visualize a tug of war between my speed and the fineness of the yarn.
('56', 232, 1, 13, 477924) These days, Satyagrahashramno Itihas 1 takes up my time.
('56', 232, 1, 14, 477981) I do not feel like writing anything else before the history is finished.
('56', 232, 1, 15, 478054) The study of Urdu and of the currency problem and Swadhyaya Samhita are of course going on.
('56', 232, 1, 16, 478146) I may not, therefore, be tempted to write on the characteristics of daivi sampat 2. The idea is yours and I think it is proper that you yourself should write on the subject.
('56', 232, 1, 17, 478320) The history of the Ashram is taking a strange shape.
('56', 232, 1, 18, 478373) I find the task is also difficult.
('56', 232, 1, 19, 478408) There is in it very little about individuals.
('56', 232, 1, 20, 478454) I have explained what the Ashram observances are, and how they are being followed.
('56', 232, 1, 21, 478537) Therein I have written at length on non violence, varnashr ama, bread labour and brahmacharya.
('56', 232, 1, 22, 478632) Perhaps the work will be finished in a fortnight.
('56', 232, 1, 23, 478682) I am keeping your suggestions 3 before me.
('56', 232, 1, 24, 478725) But all your suggestions cannot be incorporated in it.
('56', 232, 1, 25, 478780) I myself do not know what shape the history will take finally.
('56', 232, 2, 26, 478843) Blessings from BAPU

('56', 233, 1, 2, 479466) 217. SUPERVISION IS NOT NECESSARY 1
('56', 233, 2, 3, 479502) July 24, 1932 This heading will probably shock the readers.
('56', 233, 2, 4, 479562) I do not intend to suggest through it that we can manage our affairs at present without supervision.
('56', 233, 2, 5, 479663) But I certainly wish to suggest a way of reducing its degree and doing away with it completely by and by.
('56', 233, 2, 6, 479769) If supervision is thought necessary in an institution inspired by the ideals of dharma, to that extent it is deficient in dharma.
('56', 233, 2, 7, 479899) Supervision implies distrust, and distrust kills the spirit of dharma, it kills the soul.
('56', 233, 2, 8, 479989) God watches everybody.
('56', 233, 2, 9, 480012) Why should we then watch anyone?
('56', 233, 2, 10, 480045) Why should a person who has undertaken to cook or to clean lavatories not do the work carefully unless he is watched?
('56', 233, 2, 11, 480163) Why should we not trust that he will do it carefully?
('56', 233, 2, 12, 480217) We may not mind [a rule to the effect that] a person who does not do thoroughly the work which he has undertaken should leave the Ashram, but supervision ought to be unbearable to us.
('56', 233, 2, 13, 480401) The total quantity of work each person does every day is sufficient supervision over him.
('56', 233, 2, 14, 480491) We should understand the meaning of supervision here.
('56', 233, 2, 15, 480545) A child does require supervision.
('56', 233, 2, 16, 480579) It will not know how to do a thing, and should be taught to do the work given to it.
('56', 233, 2, 17, 480664) Even grown ups who do not know how to do a particular thing will require, may even want, supervision.
('56', 233, 2, 18, 480766) Really speaking, such supervision is not supervision, but is guidance by a teacher.
('56', 233, 2, 19, 480850) Novices are able to go forward in their work through the confidence which such guidance gives them.
('56', 233, 2, 20, 480950) But the supervision which is a form of watching in order to know whether or not the other person is doing his work properly is blameworthy.
('56', 233, 2, 21, 481090) Such supervision even over children is a bad thing.
('56', 233, 2, 22, 481142) We should discover some means of doing away with this blameworthy practice.
('56', 233, 2, 23, 481218) This is the first step towards that goal: we should make a list of the activities in which supervision is maintained and note the persons who are working in them.
('56', 233, 2, 24, 481381) The matter should be discussed with them and they should then be left to their sense of honour.
('56', 233, 2, 25, 481477) The manager of the Ashram and all the others should fully realize the God watches everything.
('56', 233, 2, 26, 481571) Children, too, should realize right from now that God is present everywhere.
('56', 233, 2, 27, 481648) This is not a superstition or a matter of doubt.
('56', 233, 3, 28, 481697) 1 This was sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 20 7 1932; vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 20 7 1932.
('56', 234, 0, 1, 481809) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4 SEPTEMBER, 1932 235
('56', 234, 1, 2, 481855) is as much a fact as our own existence is to ourselves.
('56', 234, 1, 3, 481911) Everybody should think carefully over this suggestion It is our moral duty to put it into practice to the utmost extent possible.
('56', 234, 2, 4, 482041) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./II

('56', 234, 5, 11, 482538) The consequences of the policy are disastrous for those who have to suffer from it.
('56', 234, 5, 12, 482622) Those who do not know English and cannot afford to pay for English assistance or who are too proud to avail themselves of it are at once put under a disadvantage.
('56', 234, 5, 13, 482785) My own case is an instance in point.

('56', 238, 2, 3, 489550) July 24, 1932
('56', 238, 3, 4, 489564) PREMA, I got your letter.
('56', 238, 3, 5, 489590) I cannot say how long I shall be able to continue writing letters.
('56', 238, 3, 6, 489657) A sword is hanging over them.
('56', 238, 3, 7, 489687) If the delay in clearing the letters from here continues, I see no benefit in writing them.
('56', 238, 3, 8, 489779) Incoming letters are now handed over to me immediately.
('56', 238, 3, 9, 489835) For outgoing letters, correspondence is going on.
('56', 238, 3, 10, 489885) If these letters stop, you may assume that the train is off the rails.
('56', 238, 3, 11, 489956) But that need not upset you or make you unhappy.
('56', 238, 3, 12, 490005) It is for the Government to permit me or not to permit me to write letters.
('56', 238, 3, 13, 490081) A prisoner cannot demand such permission as a matter of right.
('56', 238, 3, 14, 490144) The fact that I have been writing so long confers no right on me, and the loss of something over which one had no right should not make one unhappy.

('56', 238, 3, 16, 490394) Why should you mind that you got it late?
('56', 238, 3, 17, 490436) Perhaps your getting it late has increased its value.
('56', 238, 3, 18, 490490) You should not have taken it as an ill omen when you did not get it.
('56', 238, 3, 19, 490559) It is impossible that I would not send you my blessings though I had your letter asking for them.
('56', 238, 3, 20, 490657) Why should you take it as an ill omen if, because of unforeseen circumstances, you do not get the letter or get it late?
('56', 238, 3, 21, 490778) Really speaking, there is no such thing as ill omen for a person who has cultivated the spirit of non attachment.
('56', 238, 3, 22, 490892) Do not, therefore, believe for a single moment that this will be bad year for you.
('56', 238, 3, 23, 490975) It will be bad only if we think bad thoughts or speak or do evil.
('56', 238, 3, 24, 491041) And it is in our power not to do that.
('56', 238, 3, 25, 491080) If it is the doctor’s opinion that you should get the tonsils removed, you should do so.
('56', 238, 3, 26, 491169) Wasn’t his opinion the same when you consulted him before?
('56', 238, 3, 27, 491228) The operation takes very little time.
('56', 238, 3, 28, 491266) Nor have I heard that there is any risk in it.
('56', 238, 3, 29, 491313) Your body ought to become completely free from disease.
('56', 238, 3, 30, 491369) I believe that ultimately one is the best judge in regard to one’s body.
('56', 238, 3, 31, 491442) Doctors have to depend much on what their petients tell them.
('56', 238, 3, 32, 491504) This fact itself shows that, if the patient does not know what happens to his body, he cannot give correct replies to the doctor’s question.
('56', 238, 3, 33, 491645) If you merely tell a doctor, “I have a headache”, what can he do?

('56', 243, 1, 2, 498301) 231. LETTER TO MATHURADAS TRIKUMJI
('56', 243, 2, 3, 498336) July 25, 1932
('56', 243, 3, 4, 498350) MATHURADAS, Received your letter on the 23rd.
('56', 243, 3, 5, 498396) It would be better if the weather there agrees (with you).
('56', 243, 3, 6, 498455) Has any companion been given?
('56', 243, 3, 7, 498485) Are sufficient clothes provided?
('56', 243, 3, 8, 498518) I had received Popular Astronomy.
('56', 243, 3, 9, 498552) I could not know who sent it.
('56', 243, 3, 10, 498582) From the name in the book I thought that it must have come from Pranlal.
('56', 243, 3, 11, 498655) It has so happened that a copy of the book has come to my hands for some months past.
('56', 243, 3, 12, 498741) Shivaji (brother of Vinoba) of the Ashram has made a deep study (of the subject).
('56', 243, 3, 13, 498823) I had written to him to send me any book he liked.
('56', 243, 3, 14, 498874) And so this book came to me.
('56', 243, 3, 15, 498903) So I have with me two copies at present.
('56', 243, 3, 16, 498944) It has good maps, but the contents are not of much value.
('56', 243, 3, 17, 499002) At present I have got with me better books (from the point of view of contents) than this.
('56', 243, 3, 18, 499093) There can be no observation of the sky in this season.
('56', 243, 3, 19, 499148) In September or October when the sky clears and the sunset will take place earlier, if you are allowed to remain outside till 7.30 or 8 you can observe the sky.
('56', 243, 4, 20, 499309) I see that your views about social reform are very advanced.
('56', 243, 4, 21, 499370) My attitude in such matters is different.
('56', 243, 4, 22, 499412) I would not discuss any matter which does not seem to be of immediate importance and about which there is the slightest room for doubt.
('56', 243, 4, 23, 499548) Divorce is such a matter.
('56', 243, 4, 24, 499574) For one thing, among the masses divorce is not prohibited, and where it is prohibited many other reforms need to be introduced before we can go as far as divorce.
('56', 243, 4, 25, 499737) I would not therefore spend my energy in discussing the subject and create confusion in the minds of people.
('56', 243, 4, 26, 499846) As regards [artificial] birth control, my mind revolts against it.
('56', 243, 4, 27, 499913) It is possible that old ideas unconsciously influence my views, but reasons for which I oppose it [really] exist today and we can, therefore, see for ourselves the great harm done by [artificial] birth control.
('56', 243, 4, 28, 500124) By adopting artificial means to prevent conception, even those who are strong today are likely to become weak.
('56', 243, 4, 29, 500235) The whole attitude to life behind the practice of birth control is dangerous and mistaken.
('56', 243, 4, 30, 500326) Its supporters believe that it is not only man’s right but also his duty to satisfy his natural sex desire, and that if a man does not discharge this duty his development will be retarded.
('56', 243, 4, 31, 500515) I see great evil in
('56', 243, 5, 32, 500535) 1 This paragraph has been reproduced from the English translation available in Bombay Secret Abstracts.
('56', 244, 0, 1, 500639) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4 SEPTEMBER, 1932 245
('56', 244, 1, 2, 500685) this view.
('56', 244, 1, 3, 500696) I observe it daily in experience.
('56', 244, 1, 4, 500730) It is impossible to expect self control in those who have recourse to these artificial means.
('56', 244, 1, 5, 500824) These means are being advocated on the assumption that self control in this matter is impossible.
('56', 244, 1, 6, 500922) And to regard the control of the sex urge as impossible or unnecessary or harmful is to my mind a denial of dharma, for self control is the very basis of dharma.
('56', 244, 1, 7, 501084) There are many other simple and innocent methods of preventing the birth of weak progeny.
('56', 244, 1, 8, 501174) Leaving them aside, how can a dangerous method like birth control be adopted?
('56', 244, 1, 9, 501252) Almost everybody admits that it is full of dangers.
('56', 244, 1, 10, 501304) Thus, from whatever point of view I think about it, it seems to me highly undesirable.
('56', 244, 1, 11, 501391) I am prompted to write all this again because you have still time to think and, since the subject is very serious, it is necessary that you should examine it carefully.
('56', 244, 1, 12, 501560) I shall have no fear then what conclusion you come to, for I believe that your truthfulness will save you in the end or that, if I am wrong, you will be able to correct my error.
('56', 244, 1, 13, 501739) If you are convinced that birth control is morally right, you will not rest until you have converted me to your view.
('56', 244, 1, 14, 501857) And I am easy to deal with.
('56', 244, 1, 15, 501885) However strongly I may cling to a view, I don’t hesitate to give it up immediately if I discover my error or if it is pointed out to me by somebody.
('56', 244, 1, 16, 502034) All three of us are well.
('56', 244, 1, 17, 502060) I now take milk, but I do not see any benefit.
('56', 244, 1, 18, 502107) I have yielded to the pressure of the doctor here.
('56', 244, 1, 19, 502158) The pain in the elbow persists, but it pains only when it is moved in a certain way, and hence there is no cause for anxiety about it.
('56', 244, 1, 20, 502293) I have already written to Taramati in regard to visits.
('56', 244, 1, 21, 502349) 1 Besides making envelopes, Sardar has taken up two other things, viz., spinning and study of Sanskrit.

('56', 249, 1, 2, 508166) 238. LETTER TO SHIRINBAI 1
('56', 249, 2, 3, 508193) July 26, 1932
('56', 249, 3, 4, 508207) MY DEAR SISTER,
('56', 249, 4, 5, 508223) I received your disconsolate letter only today.
('56', 249, 4, 6, 508271) It had to pass through so many hands before coming to me.
('56', 249, 4, 7, 508329) My whole heart goes out to you and your aged mother.
('56', 249, 4, 8, 508382) God suffers us to blame Him, to swear at Him and deny Him.
('56', 249, 4, 9, 508441) We do it all in our ignorance.
('56', 249, 4, 10, 508472) A very beautiful Sanskrit verse which we recite daily at the morning prayer means: “Miseries are not miseries, nor is happiness truly happiness.
('56', 249, 4, 11, 508617) True misery consists in forgetting God, true happiness consists in thinking of Him as ever enthroned in our hearts.” And has not an English poet said: “Things are not what they seem?” The fact is if we knew all the laws of God we should be able to account for the unaccountable.
('56', 249, 4, 12, 508896) Why should we think that the withdrawal of your brother from our midst is an affliction?
('56', 249, 4, 13, 508985) We simply do not know.
('56', 249, 4, 14, 509008) But we do, or ought to know that God is wholly good and wholly just.
('56', 249, 4, 15, 509077) Even our illnesses such as your other brother’s may be no misfortune.
('56', 249, 4, 16, 509147) Life is a state of discipline.
('56', 249, 4, 17, 509178) We are required to go through the fire of suffering.
('56', 249, 4, 18, 509231) I do so wish that you and your mother could really rejoice in your suffering.
('56', 249, 4, 19, 509309) May you have peace.
('56', 249, 4, 20, 509329) Please forget all about the honey 2 and write to me in English by all means.
('56', 249, 5, 21, 509406) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, p.

('56', 267, 5, 15, 541861) 260. LEARN THE “GITA” BY HEART 1
('56', 267, 6, 16, 541894) July 31, 1932 I have often written and spoken advising people to learn the Gita by heart.
('56', 267, 6, 17, 541984) Since I myself have not been able to do that, it does not become me to advise people that they should.
('56', 267, 6, 18, 542087) But I do not feel ashamed of doing so time and again, because I know the benefits of the practice.
('56', 267, 6, 19, 542186) I am able to face my problems somehow, because I knew once as many as thirteen chapters by heart and have been meditating on the teachings of the Gita for the past many years.
('56', 267, 6, 20, 542362) It may be said, therefore, that I have lived my life under its protecting shade.
('56', 267, 6, 21, 542443) However, if I had been able to learn the whole Gita by heart and had studied it with greater care, I would probably have gained much more than I have.
('56', 267, 6, 22, 542594) But what happened or may happen to me does not matter.
('56', 267, 6, 23, 542649) My life, it may be said, is over, though I would, if I got an opportunity, try once again to learn it by heart.
('56', 267, 7, 24, 542761) 1 This was sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 28/31 7 1932; vide the following item.
('56', 268, 0, 1, 542856) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4, SEPTEMBER, 1932 269
('56', 268, 1, 2, 542903) Here the word Gita should be understood in a wider sense.
('56', 268, 1, 3, 542961) It means the book or work which is our spiritual authority.
('56', 268, 1, 4, 543021) Since for most of us it is the Gita, I have used that name.
('56', 268, 1, 5, 543081) But Amtul, Amina and Qureshi should learn by heart the whole or a part of the Koran e Sharif instead of the Gita.
('56', 268, 1, 6, 543195) Those who do not know any Sanskrit and cannot learn it now may memorize a Gujarati or a Hindi translation.
('56', 268, 1, 7, 543302) Anybody whose faith is not in the Gita but in some other holy book may memorize that.
('56', 268, 1, 8, 543388) We should also know what is meant by “memorizing”.
('56', 268, 1, 9, 543439) We should sincerely attempt to live according to the teaching of the book which we learn by heart.
('56', 268, 1, 10, 543538) That teaching should not be in conflict with certain fundamental principles and we should have understood its meaning fully.
('56', 268, 1, 11, 543663) This practice has its reward.
('56', 268, 1, 12, 543693) If at any time we do not have the book with us or our copy is stolen or burnt, if we are stranded in a strange place or lose our eye sight or power of speech while our mind is clear—we can imagine other similar circumstances—if in such circumstances we know our beloved book by heart, it can give us great peace of mind, show us the right path and act as our friend in our misfortune.
('56', 268, 1, 13, 544078) This is also the experience of the whole world.
('56', 268, 1, 14, 544126) Our fore fathers— whether Hindu, Muslim, Christian or Parsi—used to memo rize certain portions of holy books.
('56', 268, 1, 15, 544236) Many do that even today.
('56', 268, 1, 16, 544261) We should not disregard the precious experience of all these people.

('56', 278, 1, 2, 560000) 278. A LETTER 1
('56', 278, 2, 3, 560016) July 31, 1932 You are suffering from a subtle pride and diffidence at the same time.
('56', 278, 2, 4, 560101) How can you feel lonely in the midst of so many human beings, every one of whom demands your service and in whose midst you have thrown in your lot?
('56', 278, 2, 5, 560250) You are in the midst of books and you will not touch them.
('56', 278, 2, 6, 560309) You are in the midst of Hindi speaking men and women and you will not speak to them.
('56', 278, 2, 7, 560394) You are in the midst of workers and you will not throw yourself into the work and make two blades of grass grow where only one was growing yesterday, make two yards of cloth where only one was woven yesterday.
('56', 278, 2, 8, 560604) All our philosophy is dry as dust if it is not immediately translated into some act of loving service.
('56', 278, 2, 9, 560707) Forget the little self in the midst of the greater you have put yourself in.
('56', 278, 2, 10, 560784) You must shake yourself free from this lethargy.

('56', 282, 1, 3, 566788) Others can suggest mostly external remedies for tour health.
('56', 282, 1, 4, 566849) About internal remedies, you alone can judge.
('56', 282, 1, 5, 566895) I do not have much faith in psychologists.
('56', 282, 1, 6, 566938) How much can even the best trained psychologist know about the human mind?
('56', 282, 1, 7, 567013) Hence, you yourself should try and know what connection your ill health has with your mind and adopt the proper remedies.
('56', 282, 1, 8, 567135) In this very letter, however you say that heavy or light work and proper sleep or its absence do have an effect on health.
('56', 282, 1, 9, 567258) Thus the truth is that both internal and external factors have a bearing on one’s health.
('56', 282, 1, 10, 567348) No one has been able to maintain good health with the help of mind alone, neglecting external measures.
('56', 282, 1, 11, 567452) You should, therefore, listen to Naran das’s advice in regard to sleep, rest and work, and examine the mental cause yourself.
('56', 282, 1, 12, 567578) Take any measures you think necessary but make your body as strong as steel.
('56', 282, 1, 13, 567655) I should have told you at the very beginning that you should not take Kuhne bath in warm water during the period of your monthly course.
('56', 282, 1, 14, 567792) The inner voice is something which cannot be described in words.
('56', 282, 1, 15, 567857) But sometimes we have a positive feeling that something in us prompts us to do a certain thing.
('56', 282, 1, 16, 567953) The time when I learnt to recognize this voice was, I may say, the time when I started praying regularly.
('56', 282, 1, 17, 568059) That is, it was about 1906. I searched my memory and tell you this because you asked the question.
('56', 282, 1, 18, 568158) In fact, however, there was no moment when I suddenly felt that I had some new experience.
('56', 282, 1, 19, 568249) I think my spiritual life has grown without my being conscious of the fact in the same way as hair grows on our body.
('56', 282, 1, 20, 568367) This is how repetition of God’s name wipes out one’s sins.
('56', 282, 1, 21, 568426) Anyone who sincerely follows that practice is bound to have faith.
('56', 282, 1, 22, 568493) He starts with the conviction that such repetition will wipe out his sins.
('56', 282, 1, 23, 568568) Wiping out of sins means self purification.
('56', 282, 1, 24, 568612) One who repeats God’s name daily with faith will never grow tired of doing so, and, therefore, the name which he repeats with his lips to start with sinks ultimately into his heart, and that purifies him.
('56', 282, 1, 25, 568817) This is a universal experience.
('56', 282, 1, 26, 568849) Psychologists also believe that man becomes what he thinks.
('56', 282, 1, 27, 568909) Ramanama follows this law.
('56', 282, 1, 28, 568936) I have unshakable faith in the virtue of repeating God’s name.
('56', 282, 1, 29, 568999) I am convinced that the person who discovered it had first hand experience [of spiritual life] and that his discovery is of the utmost value.
('56', 282, 1, 30, 569141) The door of purification should open even for the illiterate.
('56', 282, 1, 31, 569203) Repetition of God’s name opens it for them.

('56', 285, 2, 3, 572684) August 4, 1932 Brotherhood is just now only a distant aspiration.
('56', 285, 2, 4, 572750) To me it is a test of true spirituality.
('56', 285, 2, 5, 572791) All our prayers, fasting and observances are empty nothings so long as we do not feel a live kinship with all life.
('56', 285, 2, 6, 572907) But we have not even arrived at that intellectual belief, let alone a heart realization.
('56', 285, 2, 7, 572996) We are still selective.
('56', 285, 2, 8, 573020) A selective brotherhood is a selfish partnership.
('56', 285, 2, 9, 573070) Brotherhood requires no consideration or response.
('56', 285, 2, 10, 573121) If it did, we could not love those whom we consider as vile men and women.
('56', 285, 2, 11, 573196) In the midst of strife and jealousy, it is a most difficult per formance.
('56', 285, 2, 12, 573270) And yet true religion demands nothing less from us.
('56', 285, 2, 13, 573322) Therefore each one of us has to endeavour to realize this truth for ourselves irrespective of what others do.

('56', 305, 5, 9, 611548) August 7, 1932
('56', 305, 6, 10, 611563) DEAR BOYS AND GIRLS, The story relating to the significance of the ekadashi is interesting.
('56', 305, 6, 11, 611655) But we observe the ekadashi in a different manner.
('56', 305, 6, 12, 611706) For us, the ekadashi should be a voluntary vow observed both physically and mentally, and its aim should be self purification.
('56', 305, 6, 13, 611833) When a person who is ill does not eat, his aim is to cure his illness and not to observe a fast.
('56', 305, 6, 14, 611930) Similarly, a poor man also who does not eat because he has no food does not observe a fast thereby.
('56', 305, 7, 15, 612030) From a microfilm of the Gujarati : M.M.U./II

('56', 308, 6, 13, 615828) August 7, 1932 I cannot share your sorrow.
('56', 308, 6, 14, 615871) Your wife has been released from suffering.
('56', 308, 6, 15, 615915) She has died at such a time and in such a manner that we should envy her death.
('56', 308, 6, 16, 615995) Why do you feel that you are left an orphan?
('56', 308, 6, 17, 616040) Only a person who is without God’s protection may regard himself as an orphan.
('56', 308, 6, 18, 616119) But God protects everybody.
('56', 308, 6, 19, 616147) Hence it is only because of our utter ignorance that we regard ourselves as orphans.
('56', 308, 6, 20, 616232) The armour which protected you was neither Mani nor your wife.
('56', 308, 6, 21, 616295) Our true armour is not our relations, but our faith in God.
('56', 308, 6, 22, 616355) The capacity of the human body to endure is much less than that of even a glass bangle.
('56', 308, 6, 23, 616443) The latter will remain in tact for hundreds of years if it is carefully preserved.
('56', 308, 6, 24, 616526) The human body, on the other hand, does not endure beyond a certain limit however cerefully it is looked after, and even within that limit it may perish at any moment.
('56', 308, 6, 25, 616694) Why should we put our trust in such a brittle thing?
('56', 308, 6, 26, 616747) You should absorb yourself completely in the Ashram work and think about nothing else.
('56', 308, 6, 27, 616834) You need not at all worry about Mangala, who is now a girl of six years.
