('56', 309, 3, 21, 618551) 321. A LETTER
('56', 309, 4, 22, 618565) August 7, 1932 To us, all useful work is good and worth doing.
('56', 309, 4, 23, 618628) Thus tanning, carpentry, cleaning lavatories, farm work, weaving, cooking, grazing cattle and all similar types of work are of equal value.
('56', 309, 4, 24, 618768) If I could persuade the people, I would have all kinds of work rewarded equally, the work of the educated and of the uneducated, the clerk’s work and the scavenger’s.
('56', 309, 4, 25, 618935) Probably you know that, in order to examine the problem from this point of view, the account of work in the Ashram is being kept only in terms of hours.
('56', 309, 4, 26, 619088) If, therefore, you are not getting sufficient yarn for weaving just now, please do not believe that you are doing work of less importance than farming or similar other work.

('56', 315, 8, 16, 627495) August 11, 1932 I understand that you have not yet resolved to give up cinnamon and cloves.
('56', 315, 8, 17, 627587) I intend to write to Nimu.
('56', 315, 8, 18, 627614) If she has already taken a vow, I will not press her to give it up.
('56', 315, 8, 19, 627682) I will only explain what her dharma is.
('56', 315, 8, 20, 627722) I think that one should not press anybody to give up a vow like this.
('56', 315, 8, 21, 627792) The effect of such persuasion on a person is to tempt him to give up his firmness and in consequence his mind becomes weak.
('56', 315, 8, 22, 627916) I do not regret the strictness which I imposed on the occasions which you

('56', 316, 1, 2, 628458) mention.
('56', 316, 1, 3, 628467) It was justified at that time.
('56', 316, 1, 4, 628498) Now I feel the slightest degree of strictness to be as heavy as the weight of the Himalayas.
('56', 316, 1, 5, 628591) Formerly, I had to fast in order to make people do what I can now persuade them to do with a mere rebuke; and other people, too, had to act more or less similarly.
('56', 316, 1, 6, 628755) If I continue to act as I used to do, I would be a cruel man.
('56', 316, 1, 7, 628817) Does this mean that others also have advanced, as I have done?
('56', 316, 1, 8, 628880) We have no reason to believe this.
('56', 316, 1, 9, 628915) But since I can now influence people close to me, nothing more is necessary.
('56', 316, 1, 10, 628992) In other words, you need not yourself be strict with Nimu or yourself, for I am here to keep a strict watch.
('56', 316, 1, 11, 629101) After my death, all of you will have to be vigilant.
('56', 316, 1, 12, 629154) It is because of this state of affairs that we often find laxity creeping in when I am away.
('56', 316, 1, 13, 629247) That is so all over the world.
('56', 316, 1, 14, 629278) We should, therefore, learn to be fully vigilant in our own lives.
('56', 316, 1, 15, 629345) At present we may be growing as a creeper does with the support of a tree.
('56', 316, 1, 16, 629420) But this is a form of dependence.
('56', 316, 1, 17, 629454) We should shake it off and learn to stand on our own feet.
('56', 316, 1, 18, 629513) The cause of the electric effect on Nimu is what I explained above.
('56', 316, 1, 19, 629581) Conditions were not the same at the time of my life which you remember, because the atmosphere then was not responsive.
('56', 316, 1, 20, 629701) It had not been purified sufficiently to be so.
('56', 316, 1, 21, 629749) If I were to write anything harsh to Nimu, she would feel miserable.
('56', 316, 1, 22, 629818) Do you now understand the reason for my liberal attitude?
('56', 316, 1, 23, 629876) There was the same love behind the strictness of the past as there is behind the liberal attitude of the present.
('56', 316, 1, 24, 629990) What you say, however, is quite correct.
('56', 316, 1, 25, 630031) It would certainly be bad if anybody misunderstood my liberal attitude and became lax.
('56', 316, 1, 26, 630118) The reason for entertaining such fear is different.
('56', 316, 1, 27, 630170) It is that I have become less exacting to myself.
('56', 316, 1, 28, 630220) My former strictness has gone.
('56', 316, 1, 29, 630251) The body does not obey me.
('56', 316, 1, 30, 630278) I naturally feel reluctant to ask others to do what I myself cannot.
('56', 316, 1, 31, 630347) I, therefore, often told the inmates of the Ashram that I was no longer fit to be in charge of it.
('56', 316, 1, 32, 630446) The gate keeper who guards the Ashram must be an ever vigilant and strong man.

('56', 318, 10, 20, 633917) MY DEAR AMTUL, I have your letter.
('56', 318, 10, 21, 633952) There was nothing to hide from anyone in your letter.
('56', 318, 10, 22, 634006) I would like all girls and women to shed this false shame about the monthly sickness.
('56', 318, 10, 23, 634092) There may be a sense of shame on the part of those who want to indulge their animal passions and treat the monthly business in terms of sexuality.
('56', 318, 10, 24, 634239) But those who want to lead a life of continence should discuss this sickness as any other sickness.
('56', 318, 10, 25, 634339) Now for the remedy.
('56', 318, 10, 26, 634359) In the first place you should take perfect rest as soon as there is any symptom of the sickness coming and rest should be continued whilst there is the slightest discharge.
('56', 318, 10, 27, 634532) During the free days of the month regular sitz baths should be taken as also hip baths in order to avoid undue discharge or a discharge beyond three days in pains.
('56', 318, 10, 28, 634696) There should [be] no pains during the sickness.
('56', 318, 10, 29, 634744) If there the treatment does not answer, you should allow the womb to be exa mined by a doctor.
('56', 318, 10, 30, 634839) On this matter you should consult Mrs. Lazarus and be guided by her.
('56', 318, 10, 31, 634908) She is likely to be able to tell you what to do.

('56', 322, 1, 10, 641883) If we purify the relationship of husband and wife of sex and banish from it the distinction of gender, this ideal will apply to every woman in the world, whatever her state may be.
('56', 322, 1, 11, 642064) In other words, love for the husband merges in love of God.
('56', 322, 1, 12, 642124) But I leave this subject now.
('56', 322, 1, 13, 642154) Why are you upset by the news that Dhiru is arriving?
('56', 322, 1, 14, 642208) Have confidence that you will be able to control him too; have that much faith in yourself.
('56', 322, 1, 15, 642300) Let the immortal statement, “Love conquers all”, sink into your heart.
('56', 322, 1, 16, 642371) We should be pleased whoever may arrive.
('56', 322, 1, 17, 642412) Our only wish is to serve everyone as best as we can.
('56', 322, 1, 18, 642466) Why don’t you have faith that, if the other children have become wellbehaved, under their influence Dhiru also will become like them?
('56', 322, 1, 19, 642600) It is also possible that Dhiru has become a wise boy now.
('56', 322, 1, 20, 642658) Personally, I have always hoped much from him.
('56', 322, 1, 21, 642705) You should dedicate your whole life to the service of the girls.
('56', 322, 1, 22, 642770) If they do not talk frankly about themselves to anyone, they are bound to fall ill.
('56', 322, 1, 23, 642854) Read my letter to Anandi.
('56', 322, 1, 24, 642880) If she lets you have that letter, all the other girls who have grown up should be asked to read it.
('56', 322, 1, 25, 642980) I have never observed from my own experience that bananas give rise to gas.
('56', 322, 1, 26, 643056) I have consumed more bananas than anybody else is likely to have done.
('56', 322, 1, 27, 643127) For many years they were my chief food.
('56', 322, 1, 28, 643167) I neither took milk nor ate bread.
('56', 322, 1, 29, 643202) My diet consisted of bananas, olive oil, ground nut and lemon.
('56', 322, 1, 30, 643265) However, I never suffered from gas.
('56', 322, 1, 31, 643301) After many years, I have started eating them again.
('56', 322, 1, 32, 643353) I observe no ill effects.
('56', 322, 1, 33, 643379) You must, of course, observe one rule in eating them.
('56', 322, 1, 34, 643433) Either bananas should be cooked or they should be completely ripe.
('56', 322, 1, 35, 643500) An unripe banana is pure starch, and I saw in Gopal Rao’s experiment that starch should not be eaten uncooked.
('56', 322, 1, 36, 643611) Hence, one should not eat bananas which have not become soft or ripe.
('56', 322, 1, 37, 643681) They will become ripe if kept aside for two or three days.
('56', 322, 1, 38, 643740) If you want to eat bananas before they have become ripe, you should either roast them or boil them in water.
('56', 322, 1, 39, 643849) The book which you read may have been published in 1924, but the theory which it mentions has become outdated.
('56', 323, 0, 1, 643960) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 324
('56', 323, 1, 2, 644002) I had opponents in the past and have them even today.
('56', 323, 1, 3, 644056) But I have never felt angry with them.
('56', 323, 1, 4, 644095) I have not wished them ill even in my dreams.
('56', 323, 1, 5, 644141) The result has been that many opponents have become friends.
('56', 323, 1, 6, 644202) No one’s opposition has had any effect on me.
('56', 323, 1, 7, 644248) On three occasions they sought to take my very life, but I am still alive.
('56', 323, 1, 8, 644323) This does not mean that no opponent would ever succeed against me in his plan.
('56', 323, 1, 9, 644402) Whether he succeeds or does not is no concern of mine.
('56', 323, 1, 10, 644457) My dharma lies in wishing well even to them, and serving them whenever an opportunity offers itself.
('56', 323, 1, 11, 644558) I have tried to live up to this principle to the best of my ability.
('56', 323, 1, 12, 644627) I think this thing is part of my nature.
('56', 323, 1, 13, 644668) I get physically tired by the worship of vast crowds.
('56', 323, 1, 14, 644722) It has never made me happy, nor have I ever felt that I was worthy of it.
('56', 323, 1, 15, 644796) On the contrary, I have always been conscious of my unworthiness.
('56', 323, 1, 16, 644862) I do not remember to have ever hungered for honour.
('56', 323, 1, 17, 644914) I always want work.
('56', 323, 1, 18, 644934) I have tried my best to make people who honour me do work, and, when they refused to work, I have run away from their honour.
('56', 323, 1, 19, 645060) I will feel myself blessed only when I reach my goal.
('56', 323, 1, 20, 645114) But, as the saying goes, will that day ever dawn?
('56', 323, 1, 21, 645164) It is not necessary to cultivate pride or contempt in order that one may be able to stand against the world.
('56', 323, 1, 22, 645273) Jesus stood against the world, Buddha stood against his times and Prahlada also acted in the same way.
('56', 323, 1, 23, 645376) All of them were humility incarnate.
('56', 323, 1, 24, 645413) To have such humility, one must have faith in oneself and in God.
('56', 323, 1, 25, 645479) Those who have opposed the world with pride have ultimately fallen.
('56', 323, 1, 26, 645547) Sometimes your pride and your anger are only pretended.
('56', 323, 1, 27, 645603) But even such pretence in an evil thing.
('56', 323, 1, 28, 645644) It may ultimately become a habit and often gives cause for unnecessary misunderstanding.
('56', 323, 1, 29, 645733) One should be very careful in one’s conduct so as to guard against such possibilities.
('56', 323, 1, 30, 645820) I think it impossible for anyone to have the strength to stand alone against the world at a critical hour unless he or she has the utmost humility.
('56', 323, 1, 31, 645968) And it is such strength which has any value at all.
('56', 323, 1, 32, 646020) It is tested only at such a time.
('56', 323, 1, 33, 646054) Many of those whom the world has believed to be brave, it had no opportunity of judging whether they were really so.
('56', 323, 1, 34, 646171) Now read my letter to Amtulbehn too.

('56', 326, 1, 2, 649000) 342. READING AND REFLECTION—I 1
('56', 326, 2, 3, 649032) August 14, 1932 We are taught at school: “Studying without thinking is useless.” This is literally true.
('56', 326, 2, 4, 649137) Love of reading is good.
('56', 326, 2, 5, 649162) Those who are prevented by lethargy from reading and studying have certainly dull minds.
('56', 326, 2, 6, 649251) But those also who merely read and never reflect on what they read remain more or less dull.
('56', 326, 2, 7, 649344) Some of them lose their eyesight in the bargain.
('56', 326, 2, 8, 649393) Reading without reflecting is only a kind of mental disease.
('56', 326, 2, 9, 649454) Many of us read in that manner.
('56', 326, 2, 10, 649486) They read but never reflect on what they read, much less put it in practice.
('56', 326, 2, 11, 649563) We should, therefore, read less, but think over what we read and put it in practice.
('56', 326, 2, 12, 649648) We may reject what we discover from experience to be unsuitable, and go on with the rest.
('56', 326, 2, 13, 649738) Persons who follow this method will satisfy their needs with less reading, save much time and become fit for creative and responsible work.
('56', 326, 2, 14, 649878) Another benefit which accrues to persons who learn to think is worth nothing.
('56', 326, 2, 15, 649956) One cannot always get books to read or get time to read them.
('56', 326, 2, 16, 650018) Persons to whom reading has become a habit are known to have gone crazy when they could not read.
('56', 326, 2, 17, 650116) If, however, one forms the habit of thinking, the book of thoughts is always available to one, andthere will then be no danger of one becoming crazy when not able to read.
('56', 326, 2, 18, 650288) I have deliberately used the phrase to “learn to think”.
('56', 326, 2, 19, 650345) That way lots of people think, carelessly and unprofitably.
('56', 326, 2, 20, 650405) This is only a form of madness.
('56', 326, 2, 21, 650437) Some get caught in futile speculation and, overcome with despair, even kill themselves.
('56', 326, 2, 22, 650525) This is not the kind of thinking I am advising.
('56', 326, 2, 23, 650573) What I am advising here is only that people should reflect over what they read.
('56', 326, 2, 24, 650653) Suppose we here or read a bhajan today.
('56', 326, 2, 25, 650693) We should then reflect over it.
('56', 326, 2, 26, 650725) We should try to discover its deeper meaning and think what we should accept from it and what we should reject.
('56', 326, 2, 27, 650837) We should see if there is any error in its idea.
('56', 326, 2, 28, 650886) If we have not understood its meaning, we should make an effort to understand it.
('56', 326, 2, 29, 650968) This is called systematic thinking.
('56', 326, 2, 30, 651004) I have given the simplest illus tration.
('56', 326, 2, 31, 651045) Everybody should apply it to his own case and draw necessary conclusions for himself, and may thus progress.
('56', 326, 2, 32, 651154) One who follows this
('56', 326, 3, 33, 651175) 1 This was sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 11/15 8 1932; vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 11/15 8 1932.
('56', 327, 0, 1, 651293) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 328
('56', 327, 1, 2, 651335) method will experience great inner joy and benefit from all that he reads.

('56', 332, 2, 3, 657943) August 14, 1932 Instead of asking what you should do when you get angry, you should ask what you should do in order that you may not get angry.

('56', 333, 1, 2, 659500) 357. A LETTER
('56', 333, 2, 3, 659514) August 14, 1932 One’s respective dharma towards one’s self, family, nation and the world cannot be divided into watertight compartments.
('56', 333, 2, 4, 659651) The harm done to oneself or one’s family cannot bring about the good of the nation.
('56', 333, 2, 5, 659735) Similarly one cannot benefit the nation by acting against the world at large.
('56', 333, 2, 6, 659813) Thus the purport is that we must sacrifice ourselves in the interest of the family, the family must do so for the nation and the nation for the world.
('56', 333, 2, 7, 659964) But the sacrifice has to be pure.
('56', 333, 2, 8, 659998) Therefore it all starts from self purification.
('56', 333, 2, 9, 660046) When the heart is pure, from moment to moment one’s duty becomes apparent effortlessly.

('56', 339, 4, 10, 672348) 363. LETTER TO FELLOW PRISONERS
('56', 339, 5, 11, 672380) August 15, 1932 For those who find it difficult to concentrate their mind on their studies, it is a great help to forget the outside world altogether.
('56', 339, 5, 12, 672531) If a dying man has his heart in the world, he fails to attain release, he is unhappy himself and is the cause of unhappiness in others; the same is the case with a prisoner in jail who should cease to think of the outside world; for imprisonment means civil death.
('56', 339, 5, 13, 672796) One who is civilly dead looks mad himself and maddens others about him if he pokes his nose into the outside world.
('56', 339, 5, 14, 672912) This prescription of mine is no new discovery.
('56', 339, 5, 15, 672959) [John] Bunyan could not have produced his immortal work 1 and Lokamanya Tilak Gitarahasya if in prison they had continued to worry about the outside world.

('56', 339, 8, 18, 673163) 364. A LETTER
('56', 339, 9, 19, 673177) August 15, 1932 Prayer and brahmacharya are not things of the same kind.
('56', 339, 9, 20, 673250) Brahmacharya is one of the five cardinal vows, and prayer is a means of being able to observe them.
('56', 339, 9, 21, 673350) I have said a great deal to explain the necessity of brahmacharya.
('56', 339, 9, 22, 673417) But when I tried to think how one can observe it, I discovered a powerful means in prayer.
('56', 339, 9, 23, 673508) For him who has realized the value of prayer and is able to pray with concentration, brahmacharya becomes quite easy to observe.
('56', 339, 10, 24, 673637) 1 The Pilgrim’s progress
('56', 340, 0, 1, 673662) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4, SEPTEMBER, 1932 341
('56', 340, 1, 2, 673709) My idea of a doctor is a person who has acquired a good knowledge of his profession and gives the benefit of that knowledge to the people without charging fees.
('56', 340, 1, 3, 673870) For his livelihood, he should take up some other work.
('56', 340, 1, 4, 673925) Or he may live on whatever little the people give him voluntarily, but never regard it as fee for his services.
('56', 340, 1, 5, 674037) In an ideal state of affairs, I would fix an annual allowance to be paid to such voluntary workers, in addition to which they would be permitted to charge or accept nothing either from the rich or the poor.
('56', 340, 1, 6, 674244) Japayajna means repeating the Name, so far as I can judge.
('56', 340, 1, 7, 674303) It is difficult to find how much exactly one should eat, but it is easy to eat little, that is to say, resolutely to eat less than one needs, and that is the better way.

('56', 340, 1, 13, 674956) The only limit to the keeping of the vow is that of our capacity.
('56', 340, 1, 14, 675022) So long as there is the distinction of meum and teum between friends and even between husband and wife, since those chained to a body cannot get over it, each may not take anything belonging to the other without permission.
('56', 340, 1, 15, 675246) Your intention that you will put it again in its original place does not meet the case, if only because you can never be sure that you will live long enough to carry it out or that the thing will not be stolen while it is still in your charge.
('56', 340, 1, 16, 675490) In observing this rule, we should not mind if we are accused of pedantry and even worse on that account.
('56', 340, 2, 17, 675595) [From Gujarati]
('56', 340, 3, 18, 675611) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, pp.

('56', 341, 1, 2, 675686) 365. A LETTER
('56', 341, 2, 3, 675700) August 15, 1932 Achara means the outward mode of living and it can change from time to time.
('56', 341, 2, 4, 675793) 1 The rules of inner living must remain the same; that is, one should cling to truth, ahimsa, etc.
('56', 341, 2, 5, 675892) It trying to follow them, we may change the rules of outward mode of living whenever necessary.
('56', 341, 2, 6, 675988) We need not cling to anything, saying or believing that according to the Shastras achara is the first step in dharma.
('56', 341, 2, 7, 676106) All rules given in Sanskrit were not Shastra.
('56', 341, 2, 8, 676152) Even the book entitled Manavdharmashastra is not really speaking a Shastra.
('56', 341, 2, 9, 676228) Shastra is not anything written in a book.
('56', 341, 2, 10, 676271) It should be a living thing.
('56', 341, 2, 11, 676300) Hence the words of a wise man of good character whose actions are in accord with his speech are our Shastra.
('56', 341, 2, 12, 676409) If we do not have any such lighthouse to guide us, what seems truth to us is our Shastra, provided our minds and hearts have been purified.
('56', 341, 2, 13, 676549) [From Gujarati]

('56', 346, 2, 3, 684722) August 18, 1932
('56', 346, 3, 4, 684738) DEAR FRIEND, There can be no doubt that Sir Samuel Hoare has showed you and the Cabinet my letter 1 to him of 11th March on the question of the representation of “depressed” classes.
('56', 346, 3, 5, 684921) That letter should be trea ted as part of this letter and be read together with this.
('56', 346, 3, 6, 685007) I have read the British Government’s decision 2 on the represen tation of minorities and have slept over it.
('56', 346, 3, 7, 685116) 3 In pursuance of my letter to Sir Samuel Hoare and my declaration 4 at the meeting of the Minorities Committee of the Round Table Conference on 13th November, 1931, at St. James’ Palace, I have to resist your decision with my life.
('56', 346, 3, 8, 685349) The only way I can do so is by declaring a perpetual fast unto death from food of any kind save water with or without salt and soda.
('56', 346, 3, 9, 685482) This fast will cease if during its progress the British Government, of its own motion or under pressure of public opinion, revise their decision and withdraw their scheme of communal electorates for the “depre ssed” classes, whose representatives should be elected by the general electorate under the common franchise no matter how wide it is.
('56', 346, 3, 10, 685826) The proposed fast will come into operation in the ordinary course from the noon of 20th September next, unless the said decision is meanwhile revised in the manner suggested above.
('56', 346, 3, 11, 686007) I am asking the authorities here to cable the text of this letter to you so as to give you ample notice.
('56', 346, 3, 12, 686112) But in any case, I am leaving
('56', 346, 4, 13, 686142) 1 Vide “Letter to Sir Samuel Hoare”, 11 3 1932.
('56', 346, 5, 14, 686190) 2 On August 17, 1932. Ramsay MacDonald, the British Prime Minister, announced a provisional scheme of minority representation, known as the Communal Award.
('56', 346, 5, 15, 686346) The scheme fixed the number of seats in the provincial legislatures and retained separate electorates for the minority communities and for the Muslims both in Bengal and the Punjab, despite their numerical majority.
('56', 346, 5, 16, 686562) Weightage was also conceded to the Muslims in the Provinces in which they were in a minority and to the Sikhs and Hindus in the Punjab.
('56', 346, 5, 17, 686698) The Depressed Classes were recognized as a minority community entitled to separate electorate.
('56', 346, 5, 18, 686793) While creating a number of specially reserved constituencies for the Depressed Classes, it gave them the additional right to contest seats in the general constituencies, with this provision that special electorates and reservation would lapse automatically after twenty years.
('56', 346, 5, 19, 687070) 3 Gandhiji commenced writing this letter on the 17th and completed it on the 18th.
('56', 346, 5, 20, 687153) For conversations regarding this letter.
('56', 346, 5, 21, 687194) 4 Vide “Speech at minorities committee meeting”, 13 11 1931.

('56', 347, 1, 2, 687297) sufficient time for this letter to reach you in time by the slowest route.
('56', 347, 1, 3, 687372) I also ask that this letter and my letter to Sir Samuel Hoare, already referred to, be published at the earliest possible moment.
('56', 347, 1, 4, 687502) On my part, I have scrupulously observed the rule of the jail and have communicated my desire or the contents of the two letters to no one, save my two companions, Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel and Sjt.

('56', 347, 1, 14, 688473) If so, I am not likely to be in the right with reference to other parts of my philosophy of life.

('56', 347, 1, 16, 688748) Whereas if my judgment is right, as I have little doubt it is, the contemplated step is but the due fulfilment of the scheme of life, which I have tried for more than a quarter of a century, apparently not without considerable success.

('56', 355, 1, 2, 702562) 382. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI 1
('56', 355, 2, 3, 702596) August 20, 1932 One of the many causes of illness is impatience.
('56', 355, 2, 4, 702661) First the mind becomes impatient, and then the body.
('56', 355, 2, 5, 702714) But it is the universal experience that ‘the impatient get nervous and the calm remain self possessed’.
('56', 355, 2, 6, 702818) If the world is on fire, will impatience help us to put out the fire?
('56', 355, 2, 7, 702888) And is it for us to put out the fire?
('56', 355, 2, 8, 702926) Do you know that firemen do not shoot water at the raging flames when a great fire breaks out?
('56', 355, 2, 9, 703021) They direct their attention to the parts round the flames.
('56', 355, 2, 10, 703080) If they can save them, they should be regarded as efficient, that is, as [karma] yogis.
('56', 355, 2, 11, 703168) If we do our own duty well, we would in effect have put out the fire.
('56', 355, 2, 12, 703238) It may not seem to the physical eye to have been put out, but you may rest assured that it has been put out.
('56', 355, 2, 13, 703347) My long search for truth has revealed to me no other way but this, nor is it likely to reveal any other in future.
('56', 355, 2, 14, 703462) If what I have said is not correct, it would become impossible to follow the path of truth and cling to it scrupulously.
('56', 355, 2, 15, 703583) We can insist only on that which is possible.
('56', 355, 2, 16, 703629) If anyone demands air of the mountains on the moon, we would have to call him a Shaikhchalli 2 for his desire can never be satisfied.
('56', 355, 2, 17, 703763) And this is also true about the scope of our duty.
('56', 355, 2, 18, 703814) Really speaking, everyone’s duty is clear enough for him to see, for one does not have to look far to find it.
('56', 355, 2, 19, 703925) One has to look no farther than the tip of one’s nose.
('56', 355, 2, 20, 703980) We have merely to clean the dirt immediately in front of our feet.
('56', 355, 2, 21, 704047) As we clean it, we shall discover more dirt to be cleaned and will clean that too.
('56', 355, 2, 22, 704130) It does not matter that, at the end of our lives, there will be as much dirt to be cleaned as when we started.
('56', 355, 2, 23, 704241) In truth, however, can we say that life ends?
('56', 355, 2, 24, 704287) The body perishes, but does that matter?
('56', 355, 2, 25, 704328) And if life does not end, we should not feel disheartened to discover that the dirt has not disappeared.
('56', 355, 2, 26, 704433) A tailor’s son goes on stitching all his life.
('56', 355, 2, 27, 704480) If he falls dead with a yawn, a needle in his hand, he would be a man of true devotion to duty.
('56', 355, 3, 28, 704576) [From Gujarati]
('56', 355, 4, 29, 704592) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, p.

('56', 356, 4, 13, 705268) 384. LETTER TO BALKRISHNA 1
('56', 356, 5, 14, 705296) August 20, 1932 I do not know with certainty what Shankaracharya meant by maya.
('56', 356, 5, 15, 705376) This is what I believe.
('56', 356, 5, 16, 705400) The world which we see and believe in is mere appearance; it is a product of our imagination.
('56', 356, 5, 17, 705494) But in its true essence it does exist.
('56', 356, 5, 18, 705533) We do not know what that essence is.
('56', 356, 5, 19, 705570) We say that it is Brahman, but we characterize all descriptions of the latter as inadequate.
('56', 356, 5, 20, 705663) The world also a Brahman and not different from it.
('56', 356, 5, 21, 705715) The difference which we see is mere appearance.
('56', 356, 5, 22, 705763) My view is that the span of our life can be lengthened or shortened.
('56', 356, 5, 23, 705832) The truth is that every species is born with its natural functioning determined.
('56', 356, 5, 24, 705913) We do not know and need not know what they are.
('56', 356, 5, 25, 705961) The divisions of time are man made and they are smaller even than particles of dust in the cosmic cycles of time.
('56', 356, 5, 26, 706075) Even if crores of units of our time as big as the Himalayas were added together, the total would be smaller than a cosmic cycle of time.
('56', 356, 5, 27, 706212) It is very little, therefore, which man commands.
('56', 356, 5, 28, 706262) Let him be pleased with it as much as he will.
('56', 356, 5, 29, 706309) There are innumerable physical causes of dreams.
('56', 356, 5, 30, 706358) I have expe rienced that, while dreaming, we can be conscious of its unreality.
('56', 356, 5, 31, 706438) Such a moment may possibly be the point of transition from the dream state to the waking state.
('56', 356, 5, 32, 706534) Involuntary discharges are sometimes the result of purely physical causes and take place even without impure thoughts in one’s mind.
('56', 356, 5, 33, 706667) They can be stopped by changes in one’s food.
('56', 356, 5, 34, 706713) Mostly they are caused by constipation.
('56', 356, 5, 35, 706753) When such

('56', 357, 1, 2, 706860) discharges are due to milk, mostly the immediate cause is impure thoughts, since milk has a tendency to stimulate passion.
('56', 357, 1, 3, 706983) But that is not the case with you.
('56', 357, 1, 4, 707018) That is, milk cannot stimulate passion in persons whose bodies have become weak even if the person is of a passionate nature.

('56', 357, 5, 17, 707892) August 20, 1932 The plan of voluntary dress making for yajna is not intended to provide the work of stitching khadi clothes for the poor.
('56', 357, 5, 18, 708030) The idea behind it is to promote quicker sale without incurring loss, of khadi woven by the poor and to reduce its price which is felt to be high .

('56', 357, 6, 23, 708533) We should act in the same manner with regard to vows.

('56', 358, 2, 3, 708883) MADALASA, I got your letter.
('56', 358, 2, 4, 708912) You may believe that you are full of envy, pride, etc., but I don’t believe so.

('56', 358, 2, 15, 709396) Other people also are human beings like us.
('56', 358, 2, 16, 709440) The same atman dwells in all of us.
('56', 358, 2, 17, 709476) Hence, getting angry with anybody means getting angry with ourselves.
('56', 358, 2, 18, 709546) Moreover, no short comings remain in anyone in whom a passion for the service of every living creature has been aroused.
('56', 358, 2, 19, 709667) You should, therefore, cultivate greater devotion to service.

('56', 359, 7, 16, 711117) 389. READING AND REFLECTION—II 2
('56', 359, 8, 17, 711150) August 21, 1932
('56', 359, 9, 18, 711166) Awake and arise, O traveller, it is morning now;
('56', 359, 10, 19, 711215) It is no longer night that you still slumber.
('56', 359, 11, 20, 711261) If anybody understands these lines to mean simply: “O traveller, arise, it is morning now.
('56', 359, 11, 21, 711352) Is it night that you are still sleeping?”—then he has read the lines but not reflected over their meaning.
('56', 359, 11, 22, 711459) For such a reader will rise early at dawn and feel satisfied.
('56', 359, 11, 23, 711521) But a reader who wishes to think will ask : Who is this traveller?
('56', 359, 11, 24, 711588) What is meant by “It is morning”?
('56', 359, 11, 25, 711622) What does the poet mean when he says that it is no longer night?
('56', 359, 11, 26, 711687) What does sleeping mean?
('56', 359, 11, 27, 711712) He will then discover daily new meanings in every line, and understand that the traveller represents every human being.
('56', 359, 11, 28, 711832) For one who has faith in God, it is always morning.
('56', 359, 11, 29, 711884) Night may also signify ignorance.
('56', 359, 11, 30, 711918) This line applies to any person who is negligent, be it in ever so small a degree.
('56', 359, 11, 31, 712001) Anybody who tells a lie also slumbers.
('56', 359, 11, 32, 712040) The line is a call to such a
('56', 359, 12, 33, 712069) 1 Wife of Pyare Ali, a businessman from Bombay 2 This was sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 20/21 8 1932; vide the following item.

('56', 360, 1, 3, 712305) We may thus read a wide meaning in the line and learn peace of mind through it.

('56', 361, 1, 8, 714972) I, therefore, stopped milk and ate bananas only for some days.

('56', 361, 1, 10, 715083) This relieved the constipation to some degree.
('56', 361, 1, 11, 715130) But, being eager to eat the same food as ‘C’ class prisoners do, and remembering that in 1930 I had tried rotlas of bajri and that had cured my constipation, for the last three days I have been eating in the evening one rotlo with vegetable.
('56', 361, 1, 12, 715372) That has cured the constipation completely.
('56', 361, 1, 13, 715416) But on the last occasion the continued consumption of bajri had resulted in more than the disappearance of constipation, and so I had to give it up.
('56', 361, 1, 14, 715565) It is possible that the same thing may happen this time.
('56', 361, 1, 15, 715622) I have not decided to exclude milk completely for the present.

('56', 368, 0, 1, 724972) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4 SEPTEMBER, 1932 369
('56', 368, 1, 2, 725018) man, viz., vidvan was synonymous with vedavid, meaning ‘ the knower of the Vedas’, and it was believed that anyone who knew the Vedas was bound to be virtuous.

('56', 370, 1, 2, 727953) 409. LETTER TO SUSHILABEHN GANDHI
('56', 370, 2, 3, 727987) August 22,1932
('56', 370, 3, 4, 728002) SUSHILA, Though your letter of two pages seemed long to you, a lazy woman, I found it much too short.
('56', 370, 3, 5, 728104) Do you know that, whenever I wrote to my brother from England, I used to fill 20 to 25 pages and still I thought the letter was too short?
('56', 370, 3, 6, 728243) I did not feel, either, that Brother would find it too long and that it would be a bother to him to read it.
('56', 370, 3, 7, 728352) I was sure that he would like a long letter.
('56', 370, 3, 8, 728397) I would write about everything I might have done during the week, everyone I might have met and everything I might have read and every foolishness I might have committed.
('56', 370, 3, 9, 728568) No wonder the letter would be so many pages long.
('56', 370, 3, 10, 728618) Moreover, I used to write only to my brother, and so I would unburden myself completely in the letter.
('56', 370, 3, 11, 728721) But you are a princess who would, if she could, write only one line but writes 50 lines with the words written wide apart form one another, and thinks that she has written quite a long letter.
('56', 370, 3, 12, 728914) All right.
('56', 370, 3, 13, 728925) Please yourself and rule Manilal.
('56', 370, 3, 14, 728959) You were married to him because he is a rather simple man and you are deep.
('56', 370, 3, 15, 729035) I always believe that your judgement about people would be correct.
('56', 370, 3, 16, 729103) Exercise a little more control over him.
('56', 370, 3, 17, 729144) Don’t think that, because he is your husband, you have done your duty when you have advised or warned him.
('56', 370, 3, 18, 729251) A good wife should hold the husband back by the ear and save him from falling into a pit.
('56', 370, 3, 19, 729341) I believe that you have that strength.
('56', 370, 3, 20, 729380) There is an agreement between Manilal and me that he should not look upon you as his servant but should regard you as his life companion, his partner in the duties of life and his better half.
('56', 370, 3, 21, 729573) You two, therefore, have equal rights over each other.
('56', 370, 3, 22, 729628) Since you are gifted with greater intuition, you have, to that extent, greater authority over him than he over you in matters which require it.
('56', 370, 3, 23, 729772) He knows more about the press and, therefore, he has greater authority in that field.
('56', 370, 3, 24, 729858) similarly, he knows more about water treatment, and so he may have greater authority in that field too.
('56', 370, 3, 25, 729962) When you read my letter to Manilal, you will understand what all this means.
('56', 370, 3, 26, 730039) How is your ear?
('56', 370, 3, 27, 730056) Does Tara write to you?

('56', 375, 1, 2, 737179) 416. LETTER TO DARBARI SADHU 1
('56', 375, 2, 3, 737210) August 23, 1932 It does not seem correct to me to say that it is part of man’s nature to spend some time in idle thoughts.
('56', 375, 2, 4, 737333) if there is a single exception to this, we cannot say that it is part of man’s nature to do so.
('56', 375, 2, 5, 737429) Actually, we find many exceptions.
('56', 375, 2, 6, 737464) It is true that vast numbers of people are always busy thinking about all manner of things which they will do or will not do, and thus may be said to spend time in idle thoughts.
('56', 375, 2, 7, 737643) If thiswere not so, it would not be necessary to emphasize the importance of concentration.
('56', 375, 2, 8, 737735) What is important for us atpresent is this.
('56', 375, 2, 9, 737779) We ourselves make all kinds of plans and resolutions, most of which we do not even remember aftersome time.
('56', 375, 2, 10, 737887) All such thoughts are mental incontinence.
('56', 375, 2, 11, 737930) Just as man dissipates his physical strength through ordinary incontinence, so he dissipates his mental strength through mental incontinence, and, as physical weakness affects the mind, so mental weakness affects the body.
('56', 375, 2, 12, 738153) That is why I have defined brahmacharya in a wide sense and described even idle thoughts as violation of it.
('56', 375, 2, 13, 738262) By defining brahmacharya in a narrow sense, we have made it more difficult to observe.
('56', 375, 2, 14, 738349) if we accept its wider definition and try to control all the eleven organs 2 , the control of the one most important organwould be much easier.
('56', 375, 2, 15, 738493) You seem to believe in the heart of your hearts that physical activity prevents or hinders us from watching the progress of our inward purfication.
('56', 375, 2, 16, 738641) My experience is the opposite of this.
('56', 375, 2, 17, 738680) Without inward purification, work cannot be done in a spirit of non attachment.
('56', 375, 2, 18, 738760) Hence the degree of inward purification can be judged mainly by the purity of our work.
('56', 375, 2, 19, 738848) Anybody who tries to cultivate inward purity without doing work will more likely that not be in danger of falling into a delusion.
('56', 375, 2, 20, 738979) I have seen many such instances.
('56', 375, 2, 21, 739012) I will give an ordinary example.
('56', 375, 2, 22, 739045) I have known many co workers making all kinds of good resolutions in jail, and also seen
('56', 375, 3, 23, 739134) 1 The addressee had said in his letter that “aimless thoughts were certainly burdensome but it seemed as if even the seeker after truth had to pass through the stage of wandering thoughts.
('56', 375, 3, 24, 739323) It was true that selfless action purified the mind.
('56', 375, 3, 25, 739375) But after some purification has not the seeker quietly to observe his mental activity?
('56', 375, 3, 26, 739462) Or was the selfless action sufficient in itself?
('56', 375, 3, 27, 739511) Buddha recommended a combination of activity and contemplation with some such end in view.
('56', 375, 3, 28, 739602) Bapu however was all for action, which according to him was the royal road to self perfection.
('56', 375, 3, 29, 739697) But did it enable the seeker to understand the activity of the soul?” (The Diary of Mahadev Desai, Vol. I, pp.
('56', 375, 3, 30, 739808) 304 5).
('56', 375, 3, 31, 739816) 2 Five organs of perception, five of action and the mind
('56', 376, 0, 1, 739873) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4 SEPTEMBER, 1932 377
('56', 376, 1, 2, 739919) their resolutions broken at the first blow after they were released.
('56', 376, 1, 3, 739988) In jail they were quite sure that they would never swerve from their resolutions, that they had achieved inward purification, that they had examined themselves in complete peace ofmind and that they had acquired concentration in prayer.
('56', 376, 1, 4, 740225) ButI found that the moment they were outside the jail walls all this evaporated into thin air.
('56', 376, 1, 5, 740320) The fifth verse ofChapter III of the Gita states a profound truth.
('56', 376, 1, 6, 740387) Scientist after scientist has told us that the principle enunciated in it is a universal law.
('56', 376, 1, 7, 740481) It simply means that no human being can cease from karma even for a moment.
('56', 376, 1, 8, 740557) Karma or motion is the universal law of all material things and forms of life.
('56', 376, 1, 9, 740636) Man’s spiritual knowledge and his excellence lie in obeying it in a spirit of non attachment.
('56', 376, 1, 10, 740730) There are two verses in the Ishopanishad 1which state the same truth, and they are equally profound.
('56', 376, 1, 11, 740831) Who am I to criticize a great soul like the Buddha?
('56', 376, 1, 12, 740883) Besides, I love and revere him.
('56', 376, 1, 13, 740915) But did he himself set up the organization [ of monasteries] or did his followers do so?
('56', 376, 1, 14, 741004) whoever did it, the monasteries which were established became, in obedience to this universal law, stagnant and by and by acquired reputation as dens of sloth.
('56', 376, 1, 15, 741164) Even today we find Buddhist monks in Ceylon, Burma and Tibet sunk in ignorance and the veritable images of sloth.
('56', 376, 1, 16, 741278) In India, too, the monks known assannyasis are not found to be shiningspecimens of humanity.
('56', 376, 1, 17, 741371) Personally I am convinced, therefore, that man can achieve real and enduring purfication of heart only through work.
('56', 376, 1, 18, 741488) I again feel tempted to quote the Gita.
('56', 376, 1, 19, 741528) Verse 18 of Chapter IV means that he who sees action in inaction and inaction in action is the wise man, he is the true yogi and the true man of karma.
('56', 376, 1, 20, 741680) I have, however, explained here what I have found in my own experience.
('56', 376, 1, 21, 741752) I have quoted the Gita verses because I have found the truth of their teaching in my experience.
('56', 376, 1, 22, 741849) I never quote anything from Shastras which I have not tested in experience.
('56', 376, 1, 23, 741925) The experience of others may be different from mine and they may even quote verses from the Gita which tend in the opposite direction or they may quote in support of their experience the same verses which I do and interpret them differently.
('56', 376, 1, 24, 742167) All this is possible.
('56', 376, 1, 25, 742189) I, therefore, never insist that all people should accept my experience as the sole guide.
('56', 376, 2, 26, 742279) [From Gujarati]
('56', 376, 3, 27, 742295) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. I, pp.
('56', 376, 4, 28, 742328) 1 Verses 1 and 2

('56', 381, 6, 20, 748516) I do not even sacrifice for any work the short midday nap which I need.

('56', 381, 6, 28, 749279) Nobody has sent me the book on health as yet.

('56', 387, 16, 33, 759173) 1 Major M. G. Bhandari

('56', 388, 1, 2, 759242) Anasaktiyoga , the utterances of poets go on acquiring ever new and revolutionary meanings, and that is as it should be.
('56', 388, 1, 3, 759363) Vinoba has every right to interpret the verses as he has done.
('56', 388, 1, 4, 759426) If, however, you are not satisfied with his interpretation, think over the meaning which I have given.

('56', 388, 1, 6, 759689) And if you cannot do even that, you should leave the verses as ones which you cannot understand just now.

('56', 388, 1, 8, 759885) Your daily programme of work is good.

('56', 403, 2, 5, 790132) According to me, real education consists in learning the art of thinking.
('56', 403, 2, 6, 790206) If we can master it, everything else will follow in beautiful order.
('56', 403, 2, 7, 790275) The woman in the story who, on seeing the face of the mongoose red with blood threw her pot of water at it, acted thought lessly, and repented afterwards for killing the creature which had saved the life of her son.
('56', 403, 2, 8, 790491) She could not wipe the stain of this act from her mind for the whole of her life.
('56', 403, 2, 9, 790573) The loss of the pot and the water are not even worth mentioning, so big was her crime.
('56', 403, 2, 10, 790660) This is an extreme illustration, but it serves to drive home the idea we are discussing.
('56', 403, 2, 11, 790749) If we do all our work in the Ashram after careful thought, there would be more peace, our efficiency would increase much time would be saved and we would find new interest in our work every day.
('56', 403, 2, 12, 790944) We employ cattle for working the water mill and the animal labours the whole day, but its knowledge does not increase and it feels no interest in its work.
('56', 403, 2, 13, 791100) If there was none to goad it, the animal would not go round.
('56', 403, 2, 14, 791161) But we are human beings.
('56', 403, 2, 15, 791186) The [Gujarati] word manas 3 comes from manushya 4, and the latter means, literally, one who thinks, who knows.
('56', 403, 2, 16, 791297) We ought not to live or act like animals.
('56', 403, 2, 17, 791339) We clean lavatories.
('56', 403, 2, 18, 791360) If we don’t think about it, we would feel the work to be low and degrading and eagerly wish that we could be saved from it.
('56', 403, 2, 19, 791484) If , however, we think about it, we would realize that it was our moral duty to do it.
('56', 403, 2, 20, 791571) To clean it means to make the place perfectly clean, to bury the contents of the bucket carefully, to keep in a clean condition the things with which we do the work, and to examine the contents.
('56', 403, 2, 21, 791766) I there is any blood or the stink is very offensive or if there are worms, we may conclude that somebody is ill.
('56', 403, 2, 22, 791879) We should then find out who that person is.
('56', 403, 2, 23, 791923) We would of course know who uses a lavatory.
('56', 403, 2, 24, 791968) If, while cleaning it we discover that the stool is not properly covered with dust or a portion has fallen outside
('56', 403, 3, 25, 792083) 1 This was sent along with “ Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 25/28 8 1932; vide the proceding item.
('56', 403, 3, 26, 792179) 2 Vide “Reading and Reflection I”, 14 8 1932 and “Reading and Reflection II”, 21 8 1932. 3 Human being 4 ibid
('56', 404, 0, 1, 792289) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4 SEPTEMBER, 1932 405
('56', 404, 1, 2, 792335) the bucket or thatthe urine has fallen outside it we should find out the guilty person and explain the matter politely to him.
('56', 404, 1, 3, 792462) All this will be done only by a person who does the work in a spirit of service.
('56', 404, 1, 4, 792543) This means that as we think daily more careully about our work,it will be done better and more easily every day and cease to be boring and become intersting.
('56', 404, 1, 5, 792701) I have not here examined the question of cleaning lavatories from every possible point of view.
('56', 404, 1, 6, 792797) I have merely mentioned it by way of illustration.
('56', 404, 1, 7, 792848) Let us take another example, spinning for yajna.
('56', 404, 1, 8, 792897) If we do this work with careful thought, we would enjoy it, too, immensely and there would be indefinite progress in the art of spinning.
('56', 404, 1, 9, 793035) If everybody spun with careful thought, we would make many discoveries and spin yarn of the finest quality.
('56', 404, 1, 10, 793143) And the same is true about prayer.
('56', 404, 1, 11, 793178) What is prayer?
('56', 404, 1, 12, 793194) Why do we pray?
('56', 404, 1, 13, 793210) Why do we observe silence?
('56', 404, 1, 14, 793237) Why do we use prayers in Sanskrit, and not in Gujarati, Marathi or Hindi?
('56', 404, 1, 15, 793311) We can think about these and many other questions and make our prayer a tremendous force, whereas it seems to me that we think the least about this subject.
('56', 404, 1, 16, 793468) The Gita’s statement, “ Yoga is skill in work” 1 , is a profound thought.
('56', 404, 1, 17, 793542) Yoga means union.
('56', 404, 1, 18, 793560) Union with God is yoga.
('56', 404, 1, 19, 793584) Mother Gita teaches that such union can be achieved without difficulty by skill in work.
('56', 404, 1, 20, 793673) Anyone who aspires to cultivate such skill must become absorbed in the work and devote all his thought to it.
('56', 404, 1, 21, 793783) Somebody who used to spin on the takli and applied his mind to the work made the important invention of the spinning wheel, and somebody who used the spinning wheel with careful thought invented a spinning machine with thousands of spindles.
('56', 404, 1, 22, 794025) According to me, that person exercised his intellect brilliantly, but did not use his heart.
('56', 404, 1, 23, 794118) Hence, it is not enough that we should think.
('56', 404, 1, 24, 794164) Our thinking should be for a good end and should be inspired by concern for dharma.
('56', 404, 1, 25, 794248) However, in contrast to absence of thinking the power of intellect of the inventor of the spinning machine certainly deserves to be admired.

('56', 408, 3, 5, 799682) I could hardly hold my sides with laughter.

('56', 408, 3, 18, 800854) I feel that it can certainly be done.
('56', 408, 3, 19, 800892) God its omnipotent and omniscient.
('56', 408, 3, 20, 800927) Anything that an omniscient Being speaks is perfect truth, and therefore it cannot be described as boasting.
('56', 408, 3, 21, 801036) Such description of himself by a human being would not be proper, since man cannot know his strength and power rightly.
('56', 408, 3, 22, 801156) If, however, in reply to a question, a man gives his correct height, his doing so is not boasting but simple statement of truth.
('56', 408, 3, 23, 801285) If a person who is five feet tall says that he is four feet tall, that is not humility on his part.
('56', 408, 3, 24, 801385) It is either inexcusable ignorance or hypocrisy.
('56', 408, 3, 25, 801434) Lady Cat and her children are always enjoying themselves and turn up at meal times to claim their share.

('56', 411, 8, 24, 805645) 464. A LETTER
('56', 411, 9, 25, 805659) August 28, 1932 The suggestion for five minutes’ silence during the evening prayer was mine.
('56', 411, 9, 26, 805752) It would certainly be fine if this practice was adopted at both times.
('56', 411, 9, 27, 805823) If all those present are sincere about observing silence, the noise is bound to stop.
('56', 411, 9, 28, 805909) The children also will get used to remai ning silent for five minutes.
('56', 411, 9, 29, 805980) I have even attended meetings where
('56', 412, 0, 1, 806016) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4 SEPTEMBER, 1932 413
('56', 412, 1, 2, 806062) silence was observed for half an hour.
('56', 412, 1, 3, 806101) That was in England.
('56', 412, 1, 4, 806122) In our country we attach great importance to voluntary silence.
('56', 412, 1, 5, 806186) Samadhi 1 is a kind of silence.
('56', 412, 1, 6, 806218) The word muni also is derived from a word meaning silence.
('56', 412, 1, 7, 806277) It is true that at first we feel sleepy or all kinds of thoughts come to us during the period of silence.
('56', 412, 1, 8, 806383) But silence is necessary to overcome these very weaknesses.
('56', 412, 1, 9, 806443) We are used to speaking and hearing all the time and, therefore, find it difficult to observe silence.
('56', 412, 1, 10, 806546) After a little practice we shall come to like it and the peace which we shall feel then will be heavenly.
('56', 412, 1, 11, 806652) As lovers of truth, we should understand the true meaning of silence and try to observe it in a manner which will accord with that meaning.
('56', 412, 1, 12, 806792) Even during silence, one can repeat Ramanama.
('56', 412, 1, 13, 806838) The real thing is that our minds should be ready for silence.
('56', 412, 1, 14, 806900) A little reflection will reveal its importance.
('56', 412, 1, 15, 806948) Cannot we sit quietly for five minutes in an assembly?
('56', 412, 1, 16, 807003) Have you gone to see a play at any time?
('56', 412, 1, 17, 807044) In many theatres talking is forbidden.
('56', 412, 1, 18, 807083) An enthusiast like me would take his seat one hour before the time.
('56', 412, 1, 19, 807151) The pleasure from the play would make it possible for him to remain silent for one hour.
('56', 412, 1, 20, 807240) But this is not all.
('56', 412, 1, 21, 807261) A play lasts for four to five hours.
('56', 412, 1, 22, 807298) Do not the spectators have to remain quiet all that time?

('56', 421, 6, 12, 824169) 478. LETTER TO NIRMALA GANDHI August 31, 1932
('56', 421, 7, 13, 824215) NIMU, I learn from a postcard from Narandas that Baba 1 is very ill.

('56', 421, 7, 15, 824314) Do not panic.
('56', 421, 7, 16, 824328) If you do, it will harm Baba.

('56', 435, 1, 2, 844974) 481. LETTER TO ASHRAM BOYS AND GIRLS
('56', 435, 2, 3, 845011) YERAVDA MANDIR, 1
('56', 435, 3, 4, 845029) September 1, 1932
('56', 435, 4, 5, 845047) DEAR BOYS AND GIRLS, I got the letter, written in beautiful handwriting, by your new secretary.
('56', 435, 4, 6, 845143) I hope that the new office bearers will discharge their duties well.
('56', 435, 4, 7, 845212) By assuming responsibilities in this way you will advance very far.
('56', 435, 4, 8, 845280) Associations like yours can run smoothly only if you are tolerant towards one another.
('56', 435, 4, 9, 845367) If you learn to do this, you will get in time the ability to run big associations.
('56', 435, 4, 10, 845450) Keep sending me weekly reports of your work.
('56', 435, 4, 11, 845495) If any disputes arise, you should write about those too.
('56', 435, 4, 12, 845552) The best thing, of course, is that there should be no disputes.
('56', 435, 4, 13, 845616) But in case a dispute does arise, there would be no benefit in keeping it from me.
('56', 435, 4, 14, 845699) If I know about it, I may be able to guide you.
('56', 435, 4, 15, 845747) Moreover, the knowledge that you will have to inform me may itself save you from quarrels.
('56', 435, 5, 16, 845838) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./II
('56', 435, 6, 17, 845882) 482. LETTER TO PURATAN BUCH
('56', 435, 7, 18, 845910) September 1, 1932
('56', 435, 8, 19, 845928) PURATAN, I certainly did not wish to stop you asking me questions.
('56', 435, 8, 20, 845995) After you have thought out in your own mind the answer to a problem, you may certainly ask me to check whether your solution is correct.
('56', 435, 8, 21, 846132) I may say that intellect has had very little share in shaping my life.
('56', 435, 8, 22, 846203) I believe that I have a rather poor intellect.
('56', 435, 8, 23, 846250) I have found it literally true in my case that God shows the means to the man who has faith.
('56', 435, 8, 24, 846343) I always hold elders and men of spiritual knowledge in high respect and put faith in them.
('56', 435, 8, 25, 846434) And my deepest faith is in truth, and because of that I have always found my path easy even when it is beset with difficulties.
('56', 435, 8, 26, 846562) I am happy that your health is improving.

('56', 440, 1, 2, 852772) 491. A LETTER 1
('56', 440, 2, 3, 852788) September 1, 1932 I had asked Dilip to send me your name.
('56', 440, 2, 4, 852846) I have ventured to write to you, though I do not remember that we have met any time.
('56', 440, 2, 5, 852931) It has always been my view regarding children’s education that we obstruct their intellectual growth and spoil their handwriting by beginning with the alphabet.
('56', 440, 2, 6, 853092) I am of the opinion that, before teaching the alphabet, we should give them orally a good deal of general knowledge.
('56', 440, 2, 7, 853209) Beginning with the history and geography of the child’s city or village, we should tell him something of the region, the country and the world as also of Nature’s beauty, the sky, the trees and plants and teach him orally a little of arithmetic, geometry, and literature, i.e., correct pronunciation, grammar, poems, Sanskrit verses, etc.
('56', 440, 2, 8, 853548) For doing any one of these, it is absolutely unnecessary first to teach reading and writing.
('56', 440, 2, 9, 853641) The child should learn to read before he is taught to write.
('56', 440, 2, 10, 853702) Writing should come last.
('56', 440, 2, 11, 853728) Before he starts learning the alphabet, he should learn some drawing.
('56', 440, 2, 12, 853798) After learning thoroughly how to draw straight lines, oblique lines, triangles, etc., the child should begin to draw pictures of the letters of the alphabet.
('56', 440, 2, 13, 853956) If we follow this method, learning will not be a painful process to the child, he will have acquired a considerable amount of general knowledge through oral instruction and the letters drawn by the child will be like pearls.
('56', 440, 2, 14, 854181) There is a chapter on the subject of good handwriting in Dasbodh 2, which is worth reading and pondering over.
('56', 440, 2, 15, 854292) The sight of Dilip’s handwriting prompted me to write this, from which you may accept whatever appeals to you and forget the rest.
('56', 440, 2, 16, 854423) My view is supported by my own very bad handwriting.
('56', 440, 2, 17, 854476) It is the result of a wrong education.
('56', 440, 2, 18, 854515) [From Gujarati]

('56', 445, 5, 15, 862205) As soon as we feel the slightest anger or aversion against a co worker or think that he has done us injustice, we should sink into deep meditation and tell ourselves: ‘I certainly deserve such treatment.
('56', 445, 5, 16, 862409) The fault is not my co worker’s but mine.
('56', 445, 5, 17, 862451) Knowingly or unkn owingly, I must have given him some cause to be angry with me or feel aversion against me.’ When the mind is so persuaded and has calmed down, you should immediately go to the co worker and ask him what fault he had seen in you.
('56', 445, 5, 18, 862698) We should then examine ourselves to see that fault and overcome it.
('56', 445, 5, 19, 862766) If we follow this method, we shall always enjoy peace, feel generous towards the whole world and never feel offended with anyone.

('56', 453, 1, 2, 876352) 508. WHAT WOMEN SHOULD DO IN A DIFFICULT SITUATION
('56', 453, 2, 3, 876403) [September 4, 1932] 1
('56', 453, 3, 4, 876425) Touching upon non violence, if some maniac should try to assault a woman, and if another man should happen to be present, should he not protect her honour with the use of a weapon?
('56', 453, 3, 5, 876606) Should not women train themselves in the use of weapons and learn to protect themselves?
('56', 453, 3, 6, 876695) I have given my opinion.
('56', 453, 3, 7, 876720) Use of weapons would certainly imply violence but I have never permitted anyone to draw from this the inference that a man or woman who happens to be present should not run to the rescue of the woman and should tolerate an outrage on her modesty.
('56', 453, 3, 8, 876967) On the contrary, I have said that the man who allows the modesty of a woman to be thus outraged will be regarded as a coward.
('56', 453, 3, 9, 877093) He will be a partner in violence because violence is implicit in cowardice.
('56', 453, 3, 10, 877169) It is my firm opinion that heroic violence is less sinful than cowardly violence.
('56', 453, 3, 11, 877251) A heroic man or woman can learn the lesson of non violence, it is pretty nearly impossible for a coward to learn it.
('56', 453, 3, 12, 877368) I have not begun this article in order to repeat all this.
('56', 453, 3, 13, 877427) One will find these ideas in many other places in my writings.
('56', 453, 3, 14, 877490) But there is one thing which I think I have not remarked upon anywhere else which I wish to put down.
('56', 453, 3, 15, 877592) I have dissuaded the Ashram women from learning the tricks of jamaiya 2, etc.
('56', 453, 3, 16, 877670) The woman who depends on a jamaiya or a gothi 3 to guard her honour may some day fail to do so.
('56', 453, 3, 17, 877766) When someone snatches away the jamaiya or the gothi from her, she will become defenceless, so that there is a possibility of her falling into the hands of a maniac.
('56', 453, 3, 18, 877931) 4 Sita had no weapons.
('56', 453, 3, 19, 877954) But she had soul force.
('56', 453, 3, 20, 877978) Hence her consent was necessary before Ravana could so much as touch her.
('56', 453, 3, 21, 878052) Our sisters should have self confidence of this kind.
('56', 453, 3, 22, 878106) Hence we have introduced Draupadi’s prayer specially for women.
('56', 453, 3, 23, 878170) But we were discussing an ideal.
('56', 453, 3, 24, 878203) When a woman is faced by a maniac, what is she to do?
('56', 453, 3, 25, 878257) If she truly has courage in her and also compassion, instead of becoming panicky she will melt him with the radiance of her compassion.
('56', 453, 3, 26, 878393) But if that emotion has not arisen in her, she will certainly become enraged.
('56', 453, 3, 27, 878471) In her rage she will slap him
('56', 453, 4, 28, 878501) 1 From Mahadevbhaini Diary.

('56', 454, 1, 26, 880478) Her anger, her alarm, proclaims for herself as well as for the man her preparedness to die.

('56', 460, 6, 16, 889580) 517. DISCUSSION WITH MAHADEV DESAI 1
('56', 460, 7, 17, 889617) September 4, 1932 It then seems you have not understood my article.
('56', 460, 7, 18, 889685) 2 I have actually pointed out that a slap rouses oneself, makes oneself fearless and above all, gives oneself the strength to die.
('56', 460, 7, 19, 889816) A wicked person is not prepared for such, in his eyes senseless, resistance.
('56', 460, 7, 20, 889893) In all probability, therefore, he would run away.
('56', 460, 7, 21, 889943) But I attach less importance to that.
('56', 460, 7, 22, 889981) The strength which is aroused in that woman enables her to end her life.
('56', 460, 7, 23, 890054) By the time that the maniac has overpowered her, the woman has already sought protection in death; for she struggles prepared for death and has no thought of hitting the man.
('56', 460, 7, 24, 890229) All that she has to do is to go on repeating Ramanama.
('56', 460, 7, 25, 890284) I suggest this remedy for all circumstances, and only for those women who are pure and who want to defend themselves against attack non violently.
('56', 460, 7, 26, 890431) This article is based on my own experience.
('56', 460, 7, 27, 890475) When I held on to that bar, 3 I was mentally prepared for death.
('56', 460, 7, 28, 890540) I could not have inflicted any serious injury on my assailant.
('56', 460, 7, 29, 890603) If, however, I had lost hold of the bar, I would have struggled on, would perhaps have slapped or bitten the man and would have resisted till death.
('56', 460, 7, 30, 890752) I would not have committed violence by
('56', 460, 8, 31, 890791) 1 Since it was Gandhiji’s Silence Day, he expressed his views in writing.
('56', 460, 8, 32, 890865) 2 Vide pp.
('56', 460, 8, 33, 890876) “What women should do in a difficult situation”, 4 9 1932. 3 When Gandhiji was attacked at Pardekoph; vide “An Autobiography”.
('56', 461, 0, 1, 891003) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('56', 461, 1, 2, 891045) fighting in this manner.
('56', 461, 1, 3, 891070) For, I could not have inflicted any injury upon him, nor was it my intention.
('56', 461, 1, 4, 891148) I only wished to die and to avoid the necessity of sitting at the opponent’s feet.
('56', 461, 1, 5, 891231) This is the real test of non violence.
('56', 461, 1, 6, 891270) One’s aim should not be to inflict pain nor should pain be the result.
('56', 461, 2, 7, 891341) M. D. I understand, but the purest of girls cannot subdue a hooligan with
('56', 461, 3, 8, 891415) one slap and is helpless if she has to face a number of them.
('56', 461, 4, 9, 891477) GANDHIJI: Not only I but medical jurisprudence holds it impossible for a woman to be outraged so long as she does not relax.
('56', 461, 4, 10, 891602) A woman who is not ready to die relaxes, may be reluctantly, and submits to the hooligan.
('56', 461, 4, 11, 891692) A desperate animal breaks its bonds or else breaks itself, and every animal is capable of exerting so much strength.
('56', 461, 4, 12, 891809) The fact is that love of life is too strong for one to hold fast till death.
('56', 461, 4, 13, 891886) A woman who puts forth the utmost strength will have herself torn to bits and her ribs broken in fighting the assailant.
('56', 461, 5, 14, 892007) M. D. To a woman of such purity it is not necessary to suggest slapping or
('56', 461, 6, 15, 892082) anything of that kind.
('56', 461, 6, 16, 892105) She will herself think out some plan or other.
('56', 461, 7, 17, 892152) GANDHIJI: I may explain it all only after I break the silence.

('56', 462, 1, 2, 892310) APPENDIX
('56', 462, 2, 3, 892319) DISCUSSION ON COMMUNAL AWARD 1
('56', 462, 3, 4, 892350) August 17, 1932
('56', 462, 4, 5, 892366) The communal decision was published today.
('56', 462, 4, 6, 892409) Bapu went about his work till the evening as if nothing had happened.
('56', 462, 4, 7, 892479) I said the new constitution was worse than the Montagu Chelmsford reforms.
('56', 462, 4, 8, 892554) “Certainly”, replied Bapu.
('56', 462, 4, 9, 892581) “Those reforms were based on the Lucknow agreement between Congress and the Muslim League.
('56', 462, 4, 10, 892672) But this constitution seeks to create such divisions in the country that it can never again stand up on its own legs.” Just before the evening prayer he said to me, “Well, you and the Sardar think over the situation and tell me whatever you feel like saying.
('56', 462, 4, 11, 892931) The letter to Samuel Hoare details the steps I should take in order to deal with the present situation.
('56', 462, 4, 12, 893035) I have therefore to serve the British Government with a notice.”.
('56', 462, 4, 13, 893101) and then Bapu began to write the letter to MacDonald.
('56', 462, 4, 14, 893155) August 18, 1932
('56', 462, 5, 15, 893171) After finishing it in the morning Bapu said, “You stop spinning for a while and go through this letter so that it may be sent at once.” The Sardar and I read it.
('56', 462, 5, 16, 893333) Then he [Sardar] said, “There is no reference in the letter to other parts of the decision.
('56', 462, 5, 17, 893425) May not this be misinterpreted to mean that they are approved by you?” “No”, replied Bapu.
('56', 462, 5, 18, 893516) “My views are well known.
('56', 462, 5, 19, 893542) Still if you wish, I will insert one paragraph, although I would then have to enter into argument.
('56', 462, 5, 20, 893641) In this letter I propose to leave out all argument, this having been included in the letter to Samuel Hoare.” I suggested that Bapu should only say his soul rebelled against the decision as a whole, but part of it was so vicious that he would lay down his life in the attempt to get it annulled.
('56', 462, 5, 21, 893937) “No”, said Bapu.
('56', 462, 5, 22, 893954) “No such comparison may fairly be instituted.
('56', 462, 5, 23, 894000) If it were, they would say that I wanted to get the decision annulled in its entirety and had seized upon a certain part of it as a pretext.
('56', 462, 5, 24, 894141) I do want the whole decision to go.
('56', 462, 5, 25, 894177) But at night I thought for a moment over the question whether other points should be included and decided against their inclusion.”
('56', 462, 6, 26, 894309) The same subject was discussed in the evening.
('56', 462, 6, 27, 894356) Bapu observed, “I cannot put in other things at all, for that would be tantamount to mixing politics with religion.
('56', 462, 6, 28, 894472) The two questions are in fact distinct from each other.” He then continued, “I have rehearsed everything in my own mind.
('56', 462, 6, 29, 894593) Everything you have suggested was considered by me before I reached the decision.
('56', 462, 6, 30, 894675) Separate electorates for the Muslims and the rest are fraught with danger.
('56', 462, 6, 31, 894750) They will combine with the British to
('56', 462, 7, 32, 894788) 1 Vide “Letter to Ramsay MacDonald”, 18 8 1932.
('56', 463, 0, 1, 894836) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 464
('56', 463, 1, 2, 894878) suppress the Hindus.
('56', 463, 1, 3, 894899) But I can think of methods by which the combination can be dealt with.
('56', 463, 1, 4, 894970) When once the outsider who foments quarrels is gone, we can tackle our problems with success.
('56', 463, 1, 5, 895064) But as regards the so called untouchables I have no other remedy.
('56', 463, 1, 6, 895130) How possibly am I to explain things to these poor fellows?
('56', 463, 1, 7, 895189) To draw suffering on oneself when misfortune dogs one’s footsteps is no novelty.
('56', 463, 1, 8, 895270) How did Sudhanva fall into the pan full of hot oil and how did Prahlad embrace a pillar of red hot iron?
('56', 463, 1, 9, 895375) There will be many satyagraha movements even after the attainment of swaraj.
('56', 463, 1, 10, 895452) I have often had the idea that after the establishment of swaraj I should go to Calcutta and try to stop animal sacrifice offered in the name of religion.
('56', 463, 1, 11, 895607) The goats at Kalighat are worse off even than untouchables.
('56', 463, 1, 12, 895667) They cannot attack men with their horns.
('56', 463, 1, 13, 895708) They can never throw up an Ambedkar from their midst.
('56', 463, 1, 14, 895762) My blood boils when I think of such violence.
('56', 463, 1, 15, 895808) Why do they not offer tigers instead of goats?”
('56', 463, 2, 16, 895856) In the morning we discussed the possible repercussions of Bapu’s step.
('56', 463, 2, 17, 895927) I said, “It will be misinterpreted in a variety of ways.
('56', 463, 2, 18, 895984) Here in India there will be senseless imitation of it while in America they will say Gandhi obtained his release by his fast.” “I know”, replied Bapu.
('56', 463, 2, 19, 896135) “In America they will swallow anything, and there are British agents ready to help them to do so.
('56', 463, 2, 20, 896233) Many will even say that I am now a bankrupt, that my spirituality is not paying dividends; therefore, I committed suicide like cunning insolvents.
('56', 463, 2, 21, 896380) And in this country there will be blind imitation, and misinterpretation.
('56', 463, 2, 22, 896454) The Government will perhaps release me and let me die outside prison, or perhaps they will let me die in jail, as in the case of MacSwiney.
('56', 463, 2, 23, 896594) Our own men will be critical.
('56', 463, 2, 24, 896624) Jawaharlal will not like it at all.
('56', 463, 2, 25, 896660) He will say we have had enough of such religion.
('56', 463, 2, 26, 896709) But that does not matter.
('56', 463, 2, 27, 896735) When I am going to wield a most powerful weapon in my spiritual armoury, misinterpretation and the like may never act as a check.” August 19, 1932
('56', 463, 3, 28, 896882) The Superintendent came and asked why Bapu was going to take such a drastic step.
('56', 463, 3, 29, 896964) He replied there was no alternative.
('56', 463, 3, 30, 897001) The Superintendent suspected that Hoare had perhaps not even informed the British Cabinet.
('56', 463, 3, 31, 897092) Bapu said, “I believe he must have informed them.
('56', 463, 3, 32, 897142) But your suspicion is not ill placed.
('56', 463, 3, 33, 897180) Hoare is a man of such a type that he might not inform them.
('56', 463, 3, 34, 897241) And when the Cabinet comes to know of it, he will say he did not think he should worry them with the case of a man who was ready to die for such a trifle.
('56', 463, 3, 35, 897396) But I think if he did not inform the Cabinet, he would lose his career as well as reputation.” The Superintendent asked what effect Bapu’s fast would have in England.
('56', 463, 3, 36, 897563) “None”, replied Bapu.
('56', 463, 3, 37, 897585) “Even if all the untouchables in a body ask for joint electorates, the British can say that in the case of a minority which has been suppressed for centuries they alone can decide what is good for it; the suppressors cannot understand its needs.” He then continued, “ My whole life has been passed that way.
('56', 463, 3, 38, 897893) This last step of mine is the crown of my career.
('56', 463, 3, 39, 897943) I had no idea that I
('56', 464, 0, 1, 897964) VOL. 56 : 16 JUNE, 1932 4 SEPTEMBER, 1932 465
('56', 464, 1, 2, 898010) would have to give up my life for this.
('56', 464, 1, 3, 898050) But it is a noble object.
('56', 464, 1, 4, 898076) The beginning was made 50 years ago, when as a child I began to smoke and then felt I was doing the wrong thing and must make a clean breast of it.
('56', 464, 1, 5, 898224) Since then I have made continuous progress in the knowledge and the practice of truth.”
('56', 464, 2, 6, 898312) The Collector came in the afternoon and said : “What can they do if they are not to give such a decision?
('56', 464, 2, 7, 898418) There must be some solution.
('56', 464, 2, 8, 898447) In matters like this you cannot insist upon absolute justice and right.” “No”, replied Bapu.
('56', 464, 2, 9, 898540) “The solution may be unreasonable but it must be acceptable to all.
('56', 464, 2, 10, 898608) But there is no agreement at the back of this decision.
('56', 464, 2, 11, 898664) They asked us for a solution in England but they did not see that they were addressing a packed house, and therefore their demand could never be satisfied.”.
('56', 464, 3, 12, 898822) In the morning Bapu said, “It is a law of satyagraha that when a man has no weapon in his hands and when he cannot think of a way out, he should take the final step of giving up his body.
('56', 464, 3, 13, 899010) What did the Rajput women do?
('56', 464, 3, 14, 899040) What did Kamalavati about whom we were reading the other day do?
('56', 464, 3, 15, 899105) She had resolved that she would not fall alive into the hands of the enemy.
('56', 464, 3, 16, 899181) She therefore embraced death as a dear friend.” August 20, 1932
('56', 464, 4, 17, 899245) The Sardar and I thought today that the news of Bapu’s impending fast should be passed on to the outside world by some means or other.
('56', 464, 4, 18, 899380) But that was impossible without a breach of Bapu’s promise.
('56', 464, 4, 19, 899440) He has promised that he on his part would never send the news out.
('56', 464, 4, 20, 899507) And we could not be disloyal to him.
('56', 464, 4, 21, 899544) The Sardar was very much worried .
('56', 464, 4, 22, 899579) August 21, 1932
('56', 464, 5, 23, 899595) “People will tell us”, said the Sardar, “that we were here with you and should have somehow or other sent the information outside, say, through Dahyabhai who sees me every week.”
('56', 464, 6, 24, 899774) “That is not to be thought of”, replied Bapu.
('56', 464, 6, 25, 899820) “Can we tell them that we would now inform the outside world of this by some means or other?
('56', 464, 6, 26, 899913) We have promised to maintain absolute secrecy from our side, and that is the end of the matter so far as we are concerned.
('56', 464, 6, 27, 900036) You must have noticed that in the letter I have addressed to MacDonald I have said with perfect indifference that if he made it possible, I wanted public opinion to be affected by my letters.
('56', 464, 6, 28, 900228) What can they do, supposing Malaviyaji and Rajagopalachari come to know about the impending fast this very day?
('56', 464, 6, 29, 900340) It is a matter of only a few days.
('56', 464, 6, 30, 900375) I think it is necessary to give a slight shock even to these two leaders.
('56', 464, 6, 31, 900449) Rajaji is a clever man and will at once understand why I was driven to take this step.
('56', 464, 6, 32, 900536) The shock will help him to understand it.
('56', 464, 6, 33, 900578) Don’t you see that I have advanced no argument in this letter?
('56', 464, 6, 34, 900641) Could I not have framed a long indictment?
('56', 464, 6, 35, 900684) But I restricted myse lf to this one point for which I would gladly sacrifice my life.
('56', 464, 6, 36, 900771) I had reserved my life for a nobler purpose, but meanwhile this occasion has arisen.
('56', 465, 0, 1, 900856) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 466
('56', 465, 1, 2, 900898) can I do now?
('56', 465, 1, 3, 900912) The satyagraha is directed not against Congressmen who are in jail, but against non Congressmen in order to make them understand what they are doing.
('56', 465, 1, 4, 901062) Don’t you see none of them is at all perturbed by the British Government’s proposals as regards untouchability?
('56', 465, 1, 5, 901174) This inertia is sickening, and it cannot be dealt with in any other way.
('56', 465, 1, 6, 901247) The possible consequences of separate electorate for Harijans fill me with horror.
('56', 465, 1, 7, 901330) Separate electorate for all other communities will still leave room for me to deal with them, but I have no other means to deal with untouchables.
('56', 465, 1, 8, 901477) These poor fellows will ask why I who claim to be their friend should offer satyagraha simply because they were granted some privileges; they would vote separately but vote with me.
('56', 465, 1, 9, 901659) They do not realize that the separate electorate will create division among Hindus so much so that it will lead to bloodshed.
